('74', 1, 1, 2, 1207) 4. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('74', 1, 2, 3, 1235) September 9, 1938
('74', 1, 3, 4, 1253) KRISHNACHANDRA, The tongue does not readily utter ‘tu’ 1 addressing the boys and ‘tum’ 2 addressing the girls.
('74', 1, 3, 5, 1364) It is something of a family tradition.
('74', 1, 3, 6, 1403) Make any change you think necessary in your diet but never for the sake of taste.
('74', 1, 3, 7, 1485) Instead, enjoy whatever you have to eat.
('74', 1, 3, 8, 1526) It would be better not to accept anything even from your uncle.
('74', 1, 3, 9, 1590) Do not discriminate between big and small books.
('74', 1, 3, 10, 1639) It would be appropriate to give up collecting even books.
('74', 1, 3, 11, 1697) Be content with the books available here.
('74', 1, 3, 12, 1739) As you are not coming with me you have to draw your con tentment from within yourself.
('74', 1, 3, 13, 1826) Wherever I may be my home is here, is it not?
('74', 1, 3, 14, 1872) This ought to suffice.
('74', 1, 4, 15, 1895) Blessings from BAPU

('74', 1, 10, 23, 2194) 6. CONGRESSMEN BEWARE !
('74', 1, 11, 24, 2218) I have been inundated with letters and wires complaining of what the senders have regarded as the Madras Premier’s terrible, mis deeds.
('74', 1, 11, 25, 2354) I pick out two which have been the subject of adverse comment in many quarters in India.
('74', 1, 11, 26, 2443) They are his policy about Hindustani and his employment of the Criminal Law Amendment Act for abating the picketing nuisance.
('74', 1, 12, 27, 2569) 1 Thou 2 You
('74', 2, 0, 1, 2582) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 3
('74', 2, 1, 2, 2629) My correspondents evidently think that I am the keeper of the Premier’s conscience and that I have but to send instructions and they will be obeyed.
('74', 2, 1, 3, 2778) They know my relations with Rajagopalachari.
('74', 2, 1, 4, 2823) But I am not the keeper of anybody’s conscience, much less of Rajaji’s.
('74', 2, 1, 5, 2895) Let the reader share the secret with me that nobody among those who regard the Congress acceptance of truth and non violence as the rule of their lives fights me as strenuously as he does.
('74', 2, 1, 6, 3084) But he has one essential virtue of a soldier.
('74', 2, 1, 7, 3130) I became my own general of satyagraha and my first recruit in 1906. When I announced my generalship in 1918 in India, Rajaji was among those who enlisted themselves at the very commencement.
('74', 2, 1, 8, 3321) It was under his roof that the inspiration of the hartal of 6th April came to me.
('74', 2, 1, 9, 3403) From that day to this his loyalty to his general has been beyond reproach or compare.
('74', 2, 1, 10, 3489) And if as general I asked him to give up his premiership he would do so without demur.
('74', 2, 1, 11, 3576) He may not even agree with my judgment.
('74', 2, 1, 12, 3616) But in battle he knows that a private has no judgement but his general’s.
('74', 2, 1, 13, 3690) But in spite of the exemplary loyalty that Rajaji gives me in common with many others, I will not issue the instructions my correspondents demand.
('74', 2, 1, 14, 3837) Let the complainants know that we rarely correspond with each other.
('74', 2, 1, 15, 3906) I know he has no time and he knows I have equally little for such correspondence.
('74', 2, 1, 16, 3988) The law of satyagraha forbids such action.
('74', 2, 1, 17, 4031) If he has to resign, he will do so in the constitutional manner.
('74', 2, 1, 18, 4096) And there will be no fuss, no complaint.
('74', 2, 1, 19, 4137) What is more to the point, I have boundless faith in his wisdom, his upright ness, and his unsurpassed ability as a parliamentarian among Con gressmen at least.
('74', 2, 1, 20, 4298) He has to his credit no mean achievements.
('74', 2, 1, 21, 4341) And those who think that he is wallowing in the constitution gutter are vastly mistaken.
('74', 2, 1, 22, 4430) We have in our ranks no abler fighter in satyagraha.
('74', 2, 1, 23, 4483) I see nothing wrong in a satyagrahi winning victories without bluster, without wrangling but by conversion, by carrying conviction.
('74', 2, 1, 24, 4615) The world will perhaps never know what Congress Premiers have been doing by forcing conviction upon Governors.
('74', 2, 1, 25, 4726) Rajaji has been in the forefront among these.
('74', 2, 1, 26, 4772) The greater the peaceful penetration, the greater the virtue of satyagraha.
('74', 2, 1, 27, 4848) There is little room for tamasha in a fight for truth with truth and nothing but truth.
('74', 2, 1, 28, 4936) It hurts me, therefore, when Congressmen decry him and think that he is so enamoured of office that he is afraid to do the right thing.
('74', 2, 1, 29, 5072) All Congress Ministers naturally come in for trenchant criticism from those who dislike Congress politics.
('74', 2, 1, 30, 5179) Whatever is sound in such criticism must be accepted with gratefulness.
('74', 2, 1, 31, 5251) There is criticism that springs from party motives.
('74', 2, 1, 32, 5303) Even that has to be borne.
('74', 2, 1, 33, 5330) But when Con 
('74', 3, 0, 1, 5344) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 3, 1, 2, 5384) gressmen take up the same cry, it becomes embarrassing.
('74', 3, 1, 3, 5440) They have their remedy.
('74', 3, 1, 4, 5464) They can complain to their Provincial Committees, and failing redress they can go to the Working Committee and finally to the A.I.C.C. Surely there is no room for criticism if all these remedies fail.
('74', 3, 1, 5, 5665) But my greatest complaint against these critics is that they are too hasty or too lazy to acquaint themselves with facts.
('74', 3, 1, 6, 5787) There is no sin greater than ignorance.
('74', 3, 1, 7, 5827) I see daily verification of this great saying.
('74', 3, 1, 8, 5874) My first advice then is that my numerous correspondents and those who think like them should first study facts as Rajaji and his Cabinet see them.
('74', 3, 1, 9, 6021) If then they are not satisfied, they should move for redress in the manner indicated by me.
('74', 3, 1, 10, 6113) I can give no direct help.
('74', 3, 1, 11, 6140) There are limitations to the use of my influence with Congressmen.
('74', 3, 1, 12, 6207) My retirement does mean non interference with individual Congressmen in the discharge of their daily duty and even with the Working Committee except when it seeks my help or advice.
('74', 3, 1, 13, 6389) Thus when Dr. Khare came to me for guidance, I twice refused, saying that he should approach the Parliamentary Sub committee.
('74', 3, 1, 14, 6515) Shri Shukla and Mishra were in urgent need.
('74', 3, 1, 15, 6559) But to them also I had to say the same thing as I said to Dr. Khare.
('74', 3, 1, 16, 6628) If I do not observe these broad limitations, my retirement becomes meaningless.
('74', 3, 1, 17, 6708) Indeed I do not follow the day to day doings of Congressmen now adays, whereas when I was in the Working Committee nothing escaped me and I used to scan everything and give guidance in detail in so far as my health permitted.
('74', 3, 1, 18, 6934) But now I do not even study all the resolu tions of the Working Committee.
('74', 3, 1, 19, 7009) Let me now say a word about the two main grievances against Rajaji.
('74', 3, 1, 20, 7077) There is nothing wrong in making a knowledge of Hindustani compulsory, if we are sincere in our declarations that Hindustani is or is to be the Rashtrabhasha or the common medium of expression.
('74', 3, 1, 21, 7271) Latin was and probably still is compulsory in English schools.
('74', 3, 1, 22, 7334) The study did not interfere with the study of English.
('74', 3, 1, 23, 7389) On the contrary English was enriched by a knowledge of the noble language.
('74', 3, 1, 24, 7464) The cry of “mother tongue in danger” is either ignorant or hypocritical.
('74', 3, 1, 25, 7537) And where it is sincere it speaks little for the patriotism of those who will grudge our children an hour per day for Hindustani.
('74', 3, 1, 26, 7667) We must break through the provincial crust if we are to reach the core of all India nationalism.
('74', 3, 1, 27, 7764) Is India one country and one nation or many countries and many nations?
('74', 3, 1, 28, 7836) Those who believe that it is one country must lend Rajaji their unstinted support.
('74', 3, 1, 29, 7919) If he has not the people behind him, he
('74', 4, 0, 1, 7959) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 5
('74', 4, 1, 2, 8006) will lose his job.
('74', 4, 1, 3, 8025) But it is strange, if the people are not behind him, that he has his great majority with him.
('74', 4, 1, 4, 8119) But what if he had not the majority behind him?
('74', 4, 1, 5, 8167) He must give up office but not his deepest conviction.
('74', 4, 1, 6, 8222) His majority is worth nothing if it does not represent the Congress will.
('74', 4, 1, 7, 8296) The Congress is wedded not to a majority; it is wedded to all that which will make this nation great and independent in the least possible time.
('74', 4, 1, 8, 8441) And the picketing?
('74', 4, 1, 9, 8460) It is insufferable that youngsters or even grown up people should assail homes and offices and howl unmen tionable imprecations against those who are shouldering their burden amid the greatest difficulty.
('74', 4, 1, 10, 8665) Until we have found the correct remedy in terms of satyagraha the Ministers must be permitted to deal with such offences in the manner they consider best.
('74', 4, 1, 11, 8820) If they are not, the freedom that is possible under Congress Raj will soon dege nerate into goondaism, pure and undefiled.
('74', 4, 1, 12, 8943) That is the way not to salvation but it is the easiest road to perdition.
('74', 4, 1, 13, 9017) And the Minister who is worth his salt will resolutely refuse to be a cause of the country’s perdition.
('74', 4, 1, 14, 9121) Lastly, the Criminal Law Amendment Act.
('74', 4, 1, 15, 9161) We may not make a fetish of Congress resolutions.
('74', 4, 1, 16, 9211) The Congress has objection not to the name but to the contents of an Act going under that name, and then, too, not to every word or section of the Act.
('74', 4, 1, 17, 9363) I have never studied it but I see from Rajaji’s public declarations that it contains a few sections which suit the new situation that the Congress is facing.
('74', 4, 1, 18, 9521) If such is the case, Rajaji will be foolish if he does not make use of them.
('74', 4, 1, 19, 9598) But he will be equally foolish, if not something worse, if he does not summarily repeal the obnoxious clauses of the Act without delay.
('74', 4, 1, 20, 9734) It is a monster created by the fertile brain of the repressor of the country’s liberty.
('74', 4, 1, 21, 9822) It was used as such against satyagrahis.
('74', 4, 1, 22, 9863) The sooner, therefore, those clauses go the better for Rajaji and the country.
('74', 4, 1, 23, 9942) But let Congressmen beware of hanging their trusted servants before they are tried and found wanting.
('74', 4, 1, 24, 10044) Harijan, 10 9 1938
('74', 5, 0, 1, 10063) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 5, 1, 2, 10103) 7. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('74', 5, 2, 3, 10130) September 10, 1938
('74', 5, 3, 4, 10149) MAHADEV, Poor Sushila was ready at 5 o’clock, but I did not let her go.
('74', 5, 3, 5, 10221) I am sending her just now.
('74', 5, 3, 6, 10248) If you are not feeling well, you may detain her.
('74', 5, 3, 7, 10297) You ought not to have let the thought enter your mind at all that you were down with a serious illness.
('74', 5, 3, 8, 10401) Now take com plete rest.
('74', 5, 3, 9, 10426) I for one would put you on fruit juice and try water and earth treatment.
('74', 5, 3, 10, 10500) But Sushila and other doctors know best.
('74', 5, 3, 11, 10541) I am after all a sinking ship.
('74', 5, 3, 12, 10572) Who would choose to sail in such a ship?
('74', 5, 3, 13, 10613) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 5, 4, 14, 10633) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 11644
('74', 5, 5, 15, 10678) 8. LETTER TO BALWANTSINHA
('74', 5, 6, 16, 10704) September 10, 1938
('74', 5, 7, 17, 10723) BALWANTSINHA, My opinion is clear.
('74', 5, 7, 18, 10758) If we are unable to maintain cows we must admit defeat and close down the dairy.
('74', 5, 7, 19, 10839) I kept the cows because of your presence here.
('74', 5, 7, 20, 10886) Now you and Parnerkar must find a way.
('74', 5, 7, 21, 10925) We should give up anything that you both do not endorse.
('74', 5, 7, 22, 10982) We should not have two departments.
('74', 5, 7, 23, 11018) Yes, you have also to consider if the calves, etc., can be housed at a different place.
('74', 5, 7, 24, 11106) I do not enlarge the establishment.
('74', 5, 7, 25, 11142) Quite a few are only temporary inhabitants and none of them will stay on after my death.
('74', 5, 7, 26, 11231) So we need have no worry on that account.
('74', 5, 7, 27, 11273) I want a detailed budget of the medicines and other things required.
('74', 5, 7, 28, 11342) In everything we have to bear in mind that all our activities are conducted with public funds.
('74', 5, 7, 29, 11437) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 5, 8, 30, 11457) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 1909

('74', 7, 6, 14, 13338) 12. LETTER TO PYARELAL
('74', 7, 7, 15, 13361) Unrevised September 11, 1938
('74', 7, 8, 16, 13390) PYARELAL, Yesterday I had a long talk with Mother.
('74', 7, 8, 17, 13441) As I see it she will not be at peace till Sushila goes to Delhi.
('74', 7, 8, 18, 13506) It also seems to me that although Sushila’s heart is here, she cannot stay here in peace so long as Mother is not at ease.
('74', 7, 8, 19, 13629) And that is how it should be.
('74', 7, 8, 20, 13659) Children can hardly find peace by making the parents miserable.
('74', 7, 8, 21, 13723) That would re quire a special reason involving a religious principle as it was in the case of Prahlad.
('74', 7, 8, 22, 13826) Sushila does not have such a reason.
('74', 7, 8, 23, 13863) My idea of Sushila’s good is irrelevant here.
('74', 7, 8, 24, 13909) Hence I feel that Sushila must decide in favour of Delhi.
('74', 7, 8, 25, 13967) Mother insists that I should send a letter to Sushila.
('74', 7, 8, 26, 14022) So if you brother and sister agree with my view I shall send the letter.
('74', 7, 8, 27, 14095) There is no cause for worry about my health.
('74', 7, 8, 28, 14140) I shall take care of it.
('74', 7, 8, 29, 14165) I certainly do not desire to end my life.
('74', 7, 8, 30, 14207) Mahadev being an invalid I certainly wish to take work from you.
('74', 7, 8, 31, 14272) But can you work like him in your present state of mind?
('74', 7, 8, 32, 14329) I do not wish to burden you.
('74', 7, 8, 33, 14358) At the same time, we have to decide what you should do when Mahadev recovers.
('74', 7, 8, 34, 14436) If it is necessary for you to be in Delhi for the sake of the peace of mind of Sushila and Mother, you
('74', 8, 0, 1, 14539) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 9
('74', 8, 1, 2, 14586) must be there.
('74', 8, 1, 3, 14601) It seems to me that none of us, especially I, have given any thought to Mother.
('74', 8, 1, 4, 14681) Only this time I have been able somewhat to understand her.
('74', 8, 1, 5, 14741) I can understand every feeling of hers and I appre ciate it.
('74', 8, 1, 6, 14802) Hence, from now on, in whatever I think about the two of you, I shall always keep in mind Mother’s feelings.
('74', 8, 1, 7, 14911) Do not hurt her feelings.
('74', 8, 1, 8, 14937) Talk to her patiently and cheer her up.
('74', 8, 2, 9, 14977) Blessings from BAPU

('74', 8, 8, 23, 15569) 14. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('74', 8, 9, 24, 15597) September 12, 1938
('74', 8, 10, 25, 15616) MAHADEV, I have not been able to touch the mail at all today.
('74', 8, 10, 26, 15678) After it has been passed on to me, is not your responsibility over?
('74', 8, 10, 27, 15746) I will do what I can and be content.
('74', 8, 10, 28, 15783) Go through today’s articles.
('74', 8, 10, 29, 15812) I have not revised the one about violence.
('74', 8, 10, 30, 15855) I have omitted from your Notes the one about the Frontier Province.
('74', 8, 10, 31, 15923) I will now see your today’s editorial.
('74', 8, 10, 32, 15962) I have already discussed that subject from another point of view.
('74', 8, 10, 33, 16028) I am attending to the other things also.
('74', 8, 10, 34, 16069) And the many responsibilities here, too, take a good deal of my time.
('74', 8, 10, 35, 16139) If you are fully restored it will be great good news indeed for me.
('74', 8, 10, 36, 16207) In any case you and I have had a warning.
('74', 8, 11, 37, 16249) Blessings from BAPU

('74', 9, 0, 1, 16414) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 9, 1, 2, 16455) 15. A CIRCULAR LETTER 1
('74', 9, 2, 3, 16479) September 12, 1938 I hear that the inmates of the Ashram have been complaining quite a lot about the way Sushilabehn serves me.
('74', 9, 2, 4, 16607) One complaint is of partiality.
('74', 9, 2, 5, 16639) The other is that I am crossing my limits.
('74', 9, 2, 6, 16682) For instance, I lean on her shoulders while walking, which cannot be part of the service.
('74', 9, 2, 7, 16772) Even when Krishnachandra is present I prefer Sushila’s shoul ders to lean on.
('74', 9, 2, 8, 16850) I let Sushila have her bath just when I am myself having my bath.
('74', 9, 2, 9, 16916) And I cover myself with her sari when there is no need for it.
('74', 9, 2, 10, 16979) I feel that those who have been talking in this way have betrayed me.
('74', 9, 2, 11, 17049) It is the clear duty of those who have any grudge in this regard to tell me so at once.
('74', 9, 2, 12, 17137) I have never been conscious of any sin in my physical con tacts with women.
('74', 9, 2, 13, 17213) That is why when I accepted service from Sushila, I did not want to exclude my leaning on her shoulders.
('74', 9, 2, 14, 17318) l con sider service from Sushila necessary for me if it is available.
('74', 9, 2, 15, 17388) No one should have the slightest suspicion of partiality in this.
('74', 9, 2, 16, 17454) I have an im pression that I had made all this clear when I discussed this matter the last time.
('74', 9, 2, 17, 17551) There are two new points.
('74', 9, 2, 18, 17577) Why does Sushila have her bath in the same bathroom when I am lying in the bathtub?
('74', 9, 2, 19, 17661) The suggestion was mine.
('74', 9, 2, 20, 17686) I have to be in the bathtub for about 15 minutes.
('74', 9, 2, 21, 17736) If she can get herself ready by that time, it is convenient to me and she can then have her meal early.
('74', 9, 2, 22, 17840) The bathing arrangement is this: she bathes in the space behind the bathtub and while she is bathing I keep my eyes tightly shut.
('74', 9, 2, 23, 17970) I do not know the manner of her bathing—whether she bathes naked or with her underwear on.
('74', 9, 2, 24, 18061) I can tell from the sound that she uses soap.
('74', 9, 2, 25, 18107) I have seen no part of her body which everybody here will not have seen.
('74', 9, 2, 26, 18180) What can be terrible is that she massages me while I am lying naked.
('74', 9, 2, 27, 18249) So long as I have not become wholly free from passion I have to be very alert while I bear with that massage.
('74', 9, 2, 28, 18359) In the hospital, an Englishwoman used to bathe me.
('74', 9, 2, 29, 18410) She had to clean myprivate parts too.
('74', 9, 2, 30, 18448) It never embarrassed me.
('74', 9, 2, 31, 18473) For, I have a somewhat different conception of brahmacharya.
('74', 9, 2, 32, 18534) It is not brahmacharya which cannot bear physical contact with women when it is called for.
('74', 9, 2, 33, 18626) But this is a digression.

('74', 11, 6, 15, 21710) 18. LETTER TO KHWAJA NAZIMUDDIN
('74', 11, 7, 16, 21742) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 13, 1938
('74', 11, 8, 17, 21777) DEAR KHWAJA SAHEB, I am thankful for your letter 2 of the 8th instant regarding the political convicts.
('74', 11, 8, 18, 21881) Much as I should like, if only for the trouble you have taken in the matter, to fall in with your proposal, it would be a breach of faith on my part to do so.
('74', 11, 8, 19, 22040) For, as you know, I am bound by a solemn promise made to these friends when, at my instance, they suspended their hunger strike.
('74', 11, 8, 20, 22169) Consistently with that promise I have to make every reasonable attempt to secure their early release.
('74', 11, 8, 21, 22271) This I cannot do if I identify myself with your proposal.
('74', 11, 8, 22, 22329) I cannot agree with you that if you fixed a time limit it would be

('74', 11, 9, 25, 22793) He had asked Gandhiji whether he accepted the Government scheme, and, if he did not, sought his consent to making public the correspondence on the subject.

('74', 12, 1, 2, 22997) inconsistent with the reference of the very thing to a tribunal.

('74', 12, 1, 4, 23220) Under the terms of your reference the judges need never discharge a single prisoner if, in their opinion, the enormity of their crime did not merit any consideration.

('74', 12, 1, 16, 24780) But that does not in any way mean that I should obstruct you in your endeavour to accelerate the process of discharge.

('74', 16, 4, 9, 30235) 25. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH September 13, 1938
('74', 16, 5, 10, 30285) MUNNALAL, With regard to your previous letter, since you had said you would be coming over I kept silent.
('74', 16, 5, 11, 30391) The views that you have expressed are correct.
('74', 16, 5, 12, 30438) As long as you do not hear the inner voice, you should come to no decision.
('74', 16, 5, 13, 30514) You should, however, try very hard to come to a definite decision.
('74', 16, 5, 14, 30581) I am not weak minded in regard to my resolutions.
('74', 16, 5, 15, 30631) My repu tation is just the opposite of that.
('74', 16, 5, 16, 30676) But when I myself have a doubt, a resolution made in the past cannot be regarded irrevocable.
('74', 16, 5, 17, 30770) Whatever I did here was in the nature of an experiment and there are bound to be changes in an experiment.
('74', 16, 5, 18, 30877) I had no misgiving about my behaviour because it was the result of fifty years of disciplined habit.
('74', 16, 5, 19, 30978) I therefore felt that I should make no distinction between Mataji 1 and Parnerkar’s mother.
('74', 16, 5, 20, 31070) I have observed that my physical touch has some special effect on men and women.
('74', 16, 5, 21, 31151) Mataji had been deeply pained on my account.
('74', 16, 5, 22, 31196) I could remove her pain by putting my hand on her.
('74', 16, 5, 23, 31247) I had not been able to go to see Parnerkar’s mother, but that is not because I did not care for her.
('74', 16, 5, 24, 31348) As the treatment was being carried out under my supervision, I expressed my love for her by putting my hand on her and made her feel at once that I had not been indifferent to her.
('74', 16, 5, 25, 31529) Is there danger of my being pierced with Cupid’s arrows in my letting myself be massaged naked, or in a thousand naked women bathing by my side when I am blind?
('74', 16, 5, 26, 31690) I do feel afraid of my self in letting the pure minded Sushilabehn massage me.
('74', 16, 5, 27, 31769) But if I am lying blind folded and those two are bathing, I would feel no fear at

('74', 19, 2, 3, 34583) MAGANWADI, WARDHA, September 14, 1938
('74', 19, 3, 4, 34621) MY DEAR JAWAHARBHAI,
('74', 19, 4, 5, 34642) Kripalani sent me the other day copy of your letter to him in which you said you want some more definite expression of opinion than this that “Bapu was happy” to read your letter.
('74', 19, 4, 6, 34822) I was in a hurry.
('74', 19, 4, 7, 34840) Bapu was in substantial agreement with all that you had said and indeed he felt that you had amplified certain points in a way he would never be able to do.
('74', 19, 4, 8, 34997) Will this do as a definite opinion?
('74', 19, 4, 9, 35033) The enclosed will help to confirm what I have said.
('74', 19, 5, 10, 35085) Yours affectionately,
('74', 19, 6, 11, 35107) MAHADEV [PS.]
('74', 19, 7, 12, 35121) Bapu is as well as he can be with the overwhelming burden of work that he has to carry.
('74', 19, 7, 13, 35209) I hope Indu is quite well now and that Sarupben is flourishing.
('74', 19, 8, 14, 35273) From a copy: Gandhi Nehru Papers.
('74', 19, 8, 15, 35307) Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('74', 19, 9, 16, 35352) 31. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI September 14, 1938
('74', 19, 10, 17, 35399) DEAR MAHADEV, Shall we say you have a mania for work?
('74', 19, 10, 18, 35453) That is why I had to write severely.
('74', 19, 10, 19, 35490) We should admire the British in this respect.
('74', 19, 10, 20, 35536) Don’t you know that if you were to be disabled, I would be a bird without wings?
('74', 19, 10, 21, 35617) If you become bed ridden, I would have to wind up three fourths of my activities.
('74', 19, 10, 22, 35699) Although I had not apprehended that you would fall ill, I had made up my mind as to what activities to curtail in case you were bed ridden and had thus lightened my mind.
('74', 19, 10, 23, 35870) But would not curtailing work in this manner be like a stab in my heart?
('74', 19, 10, 24, 35943) So I wrote to you to take complete rest and recover fully soon.
('74', 19, 10, 25, 36007) Follow me in the matter of hip bath as much as you do in drinking milk.
('74', 19, 10, 26, 36079) Surely taking hip bath is not my sole prerogative.
('74', 19, 10, 27, 36130) Sushila did not give Jivaraj’s letter to Shivdas.
('74', 19, 10, 28, 36180) Now it is being sent with Shuaib.
('74', 19, 10, 29, 36214) I sent the letter for Rishikesh directly with Radhakisan.
('74', 19, 10, 30, 36272) Thus I do save your labour.
('74', 19, 10, 31, 36300) The note about the letter was sent by an oversight.
('74', 20, 0, 1, 36352) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 21
('74', 20, 1, 2, 36400) I wanted to send the telegram to Raja yesterday, but forgot about it, Here it is: “Tortures inconsistent with your rich humour.
('74', 20, 1, 3, 36528) You must not be grieved over anything.
('74', 20, 1, 4, 36567) Bapu.” 1
('74', 20, 2, 5, 36576) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 20, 3, 6, 36596) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S. N. 11651
('74', 20, 4, 7, 36642) 32. LETTER TO PYARELAL
('74', 20, 5, 8, 36665) September 14, 1938
('74', 20, 6, 9, 36684) PYARELAL, I have already told you as well that Mother had placed the responsibility on me.
('74', 20, 6, 10, 36775) I see therein her sincerity and efficiency.
('74', 20, 6, 11, 36819) It also shows her faith in me.
('74', 20, 6, 12, 36850) I must on my part shoulder the responsibility.
('74', 20, 6, 13, 36897) As a result, I have started wondering whether Sushila should be sacrificed for the sake of serving me.
('74', 20, 6, 14, 37000) It is an agonizing thought.
('74', 20, 6, 15, 37028) Parents, even should they be on death bed, get work from paid ser vants rather than hinder the studies of their children.
('74', 20, 6, 16, 37150) Should I do otherwise?
('74', 20, 6, 17, 37173) I am afraid you too have been intoxicated by the idea of serving me.
('74', 20, 6, 18, 37242) Hence, you have been deceiving yourself with regard to Mother’s state of mind.
('74', 20, 6, 19, 37321) Mother has conveyed to me in clear terms that she wishes to see Sushila become a doctor.
('74', 20, 6, 20, 37410) She must have a degree and also the financial benefit that the degree may bring.
('74', 20, 6, 21, 37491) She tolerated a son becoming a fakir; she cannot the daughter too becoming a fakir.
('74', 20, 6, 22, 37575) There is much weight in this argument.
('74', 20, 6, 23, 37614) Moreover Sushila’s mind is oscillating between renunciation and pursuit of medical skill as the world sees it.
('74', 20, 6, 24, 37725) You sowed the seed of renunciation in her.
('74', 20, 6, 25, 37768) I watered it.
('74', 20, 6, 26, 37782) In all this the only thing tying her to me is the personal service I take from her.
('74', 20, 6, 27, 37866) Should I spoil her future by accepting her?
('74', 20, 6, 28, 37910) I hold the view that it is in her interest to stay with me.
('74', 20, 6, 29, 37970) It can hardly be that you agree with the view.
('74', 20, 6, 30, 38017) Poor Mother is not even aware of it.
('74', 20, 6, 31, 38054) Does Sushila’s boundless love for me stifle her?
('74', 20, 6, 32, 38103) What can I decide in such a difficult situation?
('74', 20, 6, 33, 38152) Think about it if you can.
('74', 20, 6, 34, 38179) I shall keep you informed of whatever I write about Sushila.
('74', 20, 7, 35, 38240) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 20, 8, 36, 38260) From the Gujarati original : Pyarelal Papers.
('74', 20, 8, 37, 38306) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('74', 20, 8, 38, 38341) Courtesy : Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar
('74', 20, 9, 39, 38391) 1 This is in English.

('74', 21, 1, 2, 38454) 33. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('74', 21, 2, 3, 38482) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 14, 1938
('74', 21, 3, 4, 38517) RAMAD, Today I just feel like addressing you as I did when you were a little child .
('74', 21, 3, 5, 38602) 1 is still not ready with me.
('74', 21, 3, 6, 38632) You have returned 2 and you are welcome.
('74', 21, 3, 7, 38673) I will leave from here for Delhi on the 19th.
('74', 21, 3, 8, 38719) I shall be there for atleast eight days.
('74', 21, 3, 9, 38760) You may therefore go to Delhi directly from there or accompany me from here.
('74', 21, 3, 10, 38837) I wish you to come here so that we may go to Delhi together.
('74', 21, 3, 11, 38898) A conch shell or a flute instead of [a clock] 3 will do for Kanam for his [bag] 4. You will then be safe.
('74', 21, 3, 12, 39004) Bring from there a small conch shell or flute.
('74', 21, 3, 13, 39051) Let him blow the conch shell or play on the flute.
('74', 21, 3, 14, 39102) Bhansalibhai teaches him with all love.
('74', 21, 3, 15, 39142) More when we meet.
('74', 21, 3, 16, 39161) I am quite well.
('74', 21, 3, 17, 39178) I keep unbroken silence these days.
('74', 21, 4, 18, 39214) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 21, 5, 19, 39234) From the Gujarati original: Mrs. Sumitra Kulkarni Papers.

('74', 21, 6, 21, 39308) 34. LETTER TO AMTUSSALAAM
('74', 21, 7, 22, 39334) September 14, 1938
('74', 21, 8, 23, 39353) MY DAUGHTER, I do not like your way of working.
('74', 21, 8, 24, 39401) It is difficult even to suggest a cure for you.
('74', 21, 8, 25, 39449) Where was the necessity of your waking up at 3 o’clock?
('74', 21, 8, 26, 39505) You should have rest.
('74', 21, 8, 27, 39527) You should give up the charkha and take such treatment as Sushila prescribes.
('74', 21, 8, 28, 39605) It would be good if you went to Bombay.
('74', 21, 8, 29, 39645) There can be no question of your going to Delhi if Khan Saheb sends a refusal.
('74', 21, 8, 30, 39724) Even otherwise you cannot possibly go to the Frontier afflicted with piles.
('74', 21, 9, 31, 39800) Blessings from BAPU

('74', 22, 7, 8, 40320) [After September 14, 1938] 1
('74', 22, 8, 9, 40349) If you have faith in me, it does not become you to be obstinate.
('74', 22, 8, 10, 40414) Khan Saheb was only joking.
('74', 22, 8, 11, 40442) However, you will not be able to stay in the Frontier Province alone.
('74', 22, 8, 12, 40512) I therefore advise you to go to Bombay; improve your health there and come back here fully restored when I return.

('74', 22, 10, 16, 40770) 37. LETTER TO ATULANAND CHAKRABARTY
('74', 22, 11, 17, 40806) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 15, 1938
('74', 22, 12, 18, 40841) DEAR ATULANAND, I see no inconsistency between my letters 2 to you.
('74', 22, 12, 19, 40909) Your note read like giving stone when bread was wanted.
('74', 22, 12, 20, 40965) I have in mind the growing distrust and bitterness which no writing can possibly remove.
('74', 22, 12, 21, 41054) I have told you you have to be your own missionary.
('74', 22, 12, 22, 41106) I have written as I have felt.
('74', 22, 12, 23, 41137) Please be patient with me and go your way.
('74', 22, 13, 24, 41180) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('74', 23, 6, 12, 41973) 39. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('74', 23, 7, 13, 42003) September 15, 1938
('74', 23, 8, 14, 42022) KANTI, If you write frankly instead of being vague, you would have your desire fulfilled earlier.
('74', 23, 8, 15, 42120) If I have to go to the Frontier Province, I shall not be able to call over Saraswati.
('74', 23, 8, 16, 42206) All the same, I am going to try from today.
('74', 23, 8, 17, 42250) You should go on supplying me with the necessary material.
('74', 23, 8, 18, 42309) You must have received my previous letter.
('74', 23, 8, 19, 42352) It is good that you are devoting yourself to study, but it is foolish to do so by reducing exercise and food.
('74', 23, 8, 20, 42462) You may become a first class doctor but will you consider yourself rewarded if the very next day of your being recognized as such you were to leave the world?
('74', 23, 8, 21, 42621) Degrees, etc., are but a means; they are certainly not the end.
('74', 23, 8, 22, 42685) And if you become a sort of permanent invalid, what service would you be able to render to me?
('74', 23, 9, 23, 42780) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 23, 10, 24, 42800) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 7348. Courtesy: Kantilal Gandhi

('74', 25, 1, 2, 44546) 43. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI
('74', 25, 2, 3, 44574) September 15, 1938
('74', 25, 3, 4, 44593) MAHADEV, I have sent the mail in the morning so today I was not in a hurry to send this.
('74', 25, 3, 5, 44682) Important letters must be despatched.
('74', 25, 3, 6, 44720) I understand about work.
('74', 25, 3, 7, 44745) There is no objection to your working in moderation.
('74', 25, 3, 8, 44798) Are you following Sushila’s instructions on walking about on the terrace twice a day?
('74', 25, 3, 9, 44884) I have learnt a new thing from Durga: that the remedy for scorpion sting is a bhajan.
('74', 25, 3, 10, 44970) What kind of scorpion would it be that permits one to sing a bhajan?
('74', 25, 3, 11, 45039) And what a singer she must be who can sing a bhajan despite the pain of a scorpion sting?
('74', 25, 3, 12, 45129) I did not ask Shuaib to post Jivaraj’s letter.
('74', 25, 3, 13, 45176) He was to give it to you so that you could send it after affixing the late fee stamp.
('74', 25, 3, 14, 45262) When two persons do a job which should be done by one, it is bound to be spoiled.
('74', 25, 3, 15, 45344) I am making this criticism in order that you may have the benefit of our experience here.
('74', 25, 3, 16, 45434) I remember to have sent you yesterday a telegram for Para meshwaran.
('74', 25, 3, 17, 45503) But the memory of a man of 69 cannot be very trust worthy.
('74', 25, 3, 18, 45562) On the back of one telegram a reply was written.
('74', 25, 3, 19, 45611) The remain ing were in a letter.
('74', 25, 3, 20, 45644) Please do inquire.
('74', 25, 4, 21, 45663) I understood from Sushila that what I had written in my letter to Jivaraj was what you desired.
('74', 25, 4, 22, 45759) Behnji was not the cause of my circular.
('74', 25, 4, 23, 45800) It was Mirabehn.
('74', 25, 4, 24, 45817) That day she had lectured Pyarelal and Sushila.
('74', 25, 4, 25, 45865) Though warned she had misunderstood Amtul Salaam.
('74', 25, 4, 26, 45915) There was a violent quarrel.
('74', 25, 4, 27, 45944) I, there fore, thought that if I did not clarify things the poison would spread and so I sent round the circular.
('74', 25, 4, 28, 46058) I see that most of the people here, poor fellows, know nothing.
('74', 25, 4, 29, 46122) So my conclusion is that Mira was the sole cause of the ill feeling which has been generated.
('74', 25, 4, 30, 46216) That is part of her nature.
('74', 25, 4, 31, 46244) What can we do about it?
('74', 25, 4, 32, 46269) I will show you the circular as also the replies received.
('74', 25, 4, 33, 46328) You need not worry about this matter.
('74', 25, 4, 34, 46366) Des pite such shocks, the blood pressure seems to be behaving normally.
('74', 25, 5, 35, 46438) Blessings from BAPU
('74', 26, 0, 1, 46458) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 27

('74', 26, 8, 12, 46902) 45. NOTE TO SUSHILA NAYYAR [Before September 16, 1938] 2
('74', 26, 9, 13, 46959) You should completely stop talking to him.
('74', 26, 9, 14, 47002) What is the use of unnecessary harassing?
('74', 26, 9, 15, 47044) Tell everyone to sit with him for a while, but he should not be allowed to talk.
('74', 26, 9, 16, 47125) As long as Pyarelal is ill, I would not enjoy the massage, etc.
('74', 26, 9, 17, 47189) Where do you even have the time?
('74', 26, 9, 18, 47222) I consider it sinful to take two hours of your time.
('74', 26, 9, 19, 47275) Therefore, I wish that for the time being, you should stop the massage on your own.
('74', 26, 9, 20, 47359) As for bathing, I shall do it myself.
('74', 26, 9, 21, 47397) You must think over all that should be done for Balakrishna.
('74', 26, 9, 22, 47458) Tell Krishnachandra what should be done.
('74', 26, 9, 23, 47499) He would send daily reports to you and Mahadev and also to David if necessary.
('74', 26, 9, 24, 47578) Perhaps Mahodaya can pay even daily visits to Balkoba.
('74', 26, 9, 25, 47633) Discuss everything with him.

('74', 31, 7, 14, 54093) 56. THE STATES AND RESPONSIBILITY
('74', 31, 8, 15, 54127) The partial success of the people of Mysore, instead of libera lizing the other States, seems, so far as one can conclude from known facts, to have stiffened them against the movement for internal respon sible government.
('74', 31, 8, 16, 54349) I have called the Mysore success only partial for nothing has yet been gained in substance by the people.
('74', 31, 8, 17, 54455) The Maha raja and his cultured Dewan have recognized the State Congress, they have instituted an impartial inquiry into the recent tragic happenings and appointed a Reforms Committee with ample powers.
('74', 31, 8, 18, 54657) With pati ence and reasonableness on the part of the Mysore State Congress and with real good will and understanding on the part of the Mysore Government, we may see a large measure of, if not full, responsibility in the government of Mysore.
('74', 31, 8, 19, 54900) But the psychological effect of the Mysore events has been exceedingly great.
('74', 31, 8, 20, 54978) The people of the States have begun to see a new vision of liberty.
('74', 31, 8, 21, 55046) What seemed to them to be a distant goal now appears to be an event to be realized almost in no time.
('74', 31, 8, 22, 55148) I believe that
('74', 31, 9, 23, 55163) 1 The significance of this is not clear.
('74', 31, 9, 24, 55204) 2 Gandhiji had scribbled this on a letter dated September 16 from the addressee who had touchingly described Amtussalaam’s joy when Gandhiji gave her a massage.
('74', 32, 0, 1, 55365) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 33
('74', 32, 1, 2, 55413) if the awakening among the people is genuine and widespread no repression can possibly stay their inevitable march to their cherished goal.
('74', 32, 1, 3, 55553) I have said enough of the Travancore frightfulness.
('74', 32, 1, 4, 55605) I can call it by no other name.
('74', 32, 1, 5, 55637) Here is an extract from a letter from a Travan corean whose testimony I have never had occasion to doubt.
('74', 32, 1, 6, 55743) He says:
('74', 32, 2, 7, 55752) A careful study of the Dewan’s statement shows that he is trying to cloud the issue and mislead outsiders who are not aware of the sequence of events that he narrates.
('74', 32, 2, 8, 55920) Excepting the threats of ‘civil war’ alleged by the Dewan, all the other events or occurrences happened subsequent to the promulgation of the proclamation and the declaration of the State Congress as an illegal body.
('74', 32, 2, 9, 56137) How post war occurrences justify the war itself, it is difficult to understand.
('74', 32, 3, 10, 56217) As regards the violence which we all deplore, the stone throwing and the burning of buses are attributed to rowdies set up by the police according to one version; but without a thorough inquiry, which is impossible under the present circumstances, it is difficult to say what is the truth.
('74', 32, 3, 11, 56507) Anyhow, do you not think that it is rather surprising that though all these occurrences took place in clear daylight and at meetings at which large numbers of police and military forces were present, it was not possible to prevent any of them or arrest a single one of the offenders?
('74', 32, 3, 12, 56791) The explanation of the supporters of the State Congress is that the police dare not arrest any as they and their hirelings commit these atrocities.
('74', 32, 3, 13, 56939) I cannot say how far the explanation can be accepted.
('74', 32, 3, 14, 56993) A volunteer who was subjected to a severe lathi charge at the Quilon meeting says in an interview to the Hindu correspondent (published in The Hindu of 4th Sept.) that he saw with his own eyes some policemen throwing stones.
('74', 32, 3, 15, 57218) Such allegations are generally made by the State Congress members.
('74', 32, 3, 16, 57285) Meetings are being held and speeches made in all parts of the country but the arrests are very few.
('74', 32, 3, 17, 57385) The present policy seems to be to disperse meetings by force.
('74', 32, 3, 18, 57447) This leads to firing and death of innocent persons.
('74', 32, 3, 19, 57499) After the Quilon meeting there was firing again at Puthupally, a village about five miles away from Kottayam.
('74', 32, 3, 20, 57609) One or two died and some were wounded.
('74', 32, 3, 21, 57648) The actual number is not yet known.
('74', 32, 3, 22, 57684) All the provisions of the new Regulation are being openly disobeyed by the people.
('74', 32, 3, 23, 57767) But the Government are not able to bring the offenders to book as there is only one jail in the State and that is already full.
('74', 32, 3, 24, 57895) If the Government desire to arrest and punish all the offenders, then they will have to build more jails as the number willing to court arrest and imprisonment is very large already and is increasing day after day.
('74', 32, 3, 25, 58110) And I am inundated with telegrams describing the fearful repression going on in several parts of Travancore.
('74', 32, 3, 26, 58219) I do not ask that this testimony should be believed as against the State communiques.
('74', 32, 3, 27, 58305) But I do suggest that there are, as usual, two sides to the question and that there is a strong case for an impartial inquiry.
('74', 33, 0, 1, 58432) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 33, 1, 2, 58473) But whether there is an inquiry or not, the duty of the Travancore State Congress is clear—on the one hand to see that there is no violence of any sort done by them or their sympathizers, and on the other to go on with their programme of direct action till the Travancore Government relent or the last member is accounted for.
('74', 33, 1, 3, 58800) I should like here to state one limitation of ahimsa.
('74', 33, 1, 4, 58854) If a wrongdoer banks upon the ahimsa of his victim and goes on heaping wrong upon wrong till every one of the victims is crushed, a cry from the surrounding atmosphere rises and the force of public opinion or the like overtakes the wrongdoer.
('74', 33, 1, 5, 59097) But no satyagrahi should think that he has never to suffer unto death.
('74', 33, 1, 6, 59168) His victory lies in the defiance by his unconquerable spirit of death and loss of property.
('74', 33, 1, 7, 59260) The wrongdoer’s certain defeat lies in his utter failure to bend or break the spirit of his victim.
('74', 33, 1, 8, 59360) If the States persist in their obstinacy and hug their ignorance of the awakening that has taken place throughout India, they are court ing certain destruction.
('74', 33, 1, 9, 59521) I claim to be a friend of the States.
('74', 33, 1, 10, 59559) Their service has been a heirloom in my family for the past three genera tions, if not longer.
('74', 33, 1, 11, 59654) I am no blind worshipper of antiquity.
('74', 33, 1, 12, 59693) But I am not ashamed of the heirloom.
('74', 33, 1, 13, 59731) All the States may not live.
('74', 33, 1, 14, 59760) The biggest ones can live only if they will recognize their limitations, become servants of their people, trustees of their welfare and depend for their existence not on arms, whether their own or British, but solely on the goodwill of their people.
('74', 33, 1, 15, 60010) Frightfulness will feed the fire of violence that one feels smouldering everywhere.
('74', 33, 1, 16, 60094) If the States are badly advised and they rely upon organized violence for resisting the just demands of their people, ahimsa, so far generated in the country as a means of redressing social injustice, will not protect them.
('74', 33, 1, 17, 60318) If it had grown into a Himalayan oak, it would have passed any test however severe.
('74', 33, 1, 18, 60402) But, sad to confess, it has not gone deep enough into the Indian soil.
('74', 33, 1, 19, 60473) The Hyderabad communiques have therefore come upon me as a painful surprise.
('74', 33, 1, 20, 60550) Sir Akbar is a great educationist.
('74', 33, 1, 21, 60585) He is a philoso pher.
('74', 33, 1, 22, 60607) It was a pleasure to read his recent convocation address to the Dacca University.
('74', 33, 1, 23, 60689) It is passing strange that he should have lent himself to the reactionary declarations which condemn an organi zation even before it has begun to function.
('74', 33, 1, 24, 60845) What can be the meaning of communalism in a state which is overwhelmingly one population according to religion?
('74', 33, 1, 25, 60957) What can communalism mean in, say, Kashmir or the Frontier where the population is predominantly of one faith?
('74', 33, 1, 26, 61068) The doctrine of minority is a good hobby to ride up to a point.
('74', 34, 0, 1, 61132) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 35
('74', 34, 1, 2, 61180) must be at least numerically a fair minority.
('74', 34, 1, 3, 61226) Even a minority of one can expect perfect justice.
('74', 34, 1, 4, 61277) But it has no status in the political field.
('74', 34, 1, 5, 61322) When a person belonging to an insignificant minority mounts to power he does so not as a represntative of his group but by sheer merit.
('74', 34, 1, 6, 61458) The State Congress in Hyderabad can never be communal in the sense in which the word is understood in India.
('74', 34, 1, 7, 61567) An institution in the Frontier Province need not be dubbed communal merely because it has no Hindu member.
('74', 34, 1, 8, 61674) Of course an organization may be frankly communal in outlook.
('74', 34, 1, 9, 61736) But the Hyderabad communiques make a subtle distinction and aver that there is presence in the State Congress of persons predominantly communal in outlook.
('74', 34, 1, 10, 61892) What is more, the State Congress has come out with a statement totally repudiating the suggestion of communalism.
('74', 34, 1, 11, 62006) And then comes even the erstwhile progressive Rajkot, Only the other day it had a representative Assembly elected under universal suffrage, and it had complete liberty of speech under its late lamented ruler.
('74', 34, 1, 12, 62215) One may hope that after the recent display (so far as I can see, wholly uncalled for) of force, the political organization of Rajkot will be not only permitted to function undisturbed but that its demands will be met in a spirit of justice.
('74', 34, 1, 13, 62456) Whatever happens in the three States named or on any other, let the people of the States recognize that their salvation depends wholly on their own strength whose generation in turn depends upon an ex hibition in action of complete non violence and truth.
('74', 34, 1, 14, 62712) They must realize that it is utterly impossible openly to organize along violent lines large masses of mankind deprived of arms and almost from time immemorial brought up as a non military nation.
('74', 34, 2, 15, 62909) Harijan, 17 9 1938
('74', 34, 3, 16, 62928) 57. ACCUMULATING EVIDENCE
('74', 34, 4, 17, 62954) A man reaps as he sows.
('74', 34, 4, 18, 62978) Having written on violence, I am getting evidence from all parts of India supporting my statement.
('74', 34, 4, 19, 63077) The saddest case to come under my observation is that of a Congress Committee having incited the ryots of a zemindari simply to take possession of the lands of that zemindari.
('74', 34, 4, 20, 63253) This act of spoliation was preceded by speeches of Congressmen reeking with violence.
('74', 34, 4, 21, 63339) I sent the papers to Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya for investigation.
('74', 34, 4, 22, 63404) He confirms generally the complaints made by my correspondent.
('74', 34, 4, 23, 63467) I am hoping
('74', 35, 0, 1, 63479) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 35, 1, 2, 63520) that the District Committee or the Provincial Committee will be able to right the wrong.
('74', 35, 1, 3, 63609) Failing that, of course, Rajaji’s Government has to give redress.
('74', 35, 1, 4, 63675) In saying this I do not wish to suggest that the land does not belong to the worker on it.
('74', 35, 1, 5, 63766) I endorse the socialist theory of possession.
('74', 35, 1, 6, 63812) But no socialist that I know has defended the usurpation practised in Andhra.
('74', 35, 1, 7, 63890) If all the land in India is ever to belong to or be possessed by the worker alone, it would be either by a bloody revolution or by equitable legislation.
('74', 35, 1, 8, 64044) It must be clear to every sane man that the act of confiscation will never last.
('74', 35, 1, 9, 64125) Had it not been for the Congress Government, the spoliation could never have taken place.
('74', 35, 1, 10, 64215) The Congress Government will dig its grave if it fails to restore the land to the legal possessor.
('74', 35, 1, 11, 64314) I may add in parenthesis that the dis possessed zemindar is reputed to be a docile man with pro Congress tendencies.
('74', 35, 1, 12, 64431) The other piece of evidence is choice cuttings from the U. P., C. P. and Bombay press.
('74', 35, 1, 13, 64518) The singularity of the U. P. cuttings is that they contain incitement to violence in poems and prose.
('74', 35, 1, 14, 64620) A lady writer waxes eloquent over the misdeeds of the zemindars and the wrongs of the kisans.
('74', 35, 1, 15, 64714) She draws a terrible contrast between the opulence of the haves and the penury of the have nots.
('74', 35, 1, 16, 64811) Having prepared the ground she invites the kisans to a feast of blood and thunder.
('74', 35, 1, 17, 64894) “Take any weapon you get hold of, strike and strike hard.
('74', 35, 1, 18, 64952) Don’t be cowards.
('74', 35, 1, 19, 64970) It is all yours and you must seize it by your powerful arms.” This is a mild rendering, all too brief, of the red original.
('74', 35, 1, 20, 65094) Had not the lady’s name stared me in the face as writer, I would not have thought a daughter of India to be capable of incitement to such merciless violence.
('74', 35, 1, 21, 65252) I must confess that even if I screwed myself up properly I could not fill the three columns that she has done with invective.
('74', 35, 1, 22, 65378) If no one has had his head turned by the writing, it is certainly not her fault.
('74', 35, 1, 23, 65459) Fortunately the millions to whom it is addressed cannot read.
('74', 35, 1, 24, 65521) The C. P. and Bombay cuttings contain unthinkable false hoods.
('74', 35, 1, 25, 65584) There is no restraint on the pen.
('74', 35, 1, 26, 65618) No language is foul enough to blacken the character of persons.
('74', 35, 1, 27, 65682) Some of the things said are patent inventions.
('74', 35, 1, 28, 65729) The writings easily come under the law of libel.
('74', 35, 1, 29, 65778) But what can libel proceedings do?
('74', 35, 1, 30, 65813) They invite libel proceedings.
('74', 35, 1, 31, 65844) These advertise the papers.
('74', 35, 1, 32, 65872) Defence would be an additional opportunity for invention.
('74', 35, 1, 33, 65930) There are veiled incitements too.
('74', 35, 1, 34, 65964) And even without incite ment, why should not youths reading the portraiture of persons in blackest colours take it into their heads to go and kill the ‘lepers’ described in the columns?
('74', 35, 1, 35, 66150) To many, their newspapers are their Bible.
('74', 35, 1, 36, 66193) They believe in them.
('74', 35, 1, 37, 66215) And some of these papers are supposed to represent the Congress policy.
('74', 35, 1, 38, 66287) The evil is on the increase during the
('74', 36, 0, 1, 66326) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 37
('74', 36, 1, 2, 66374) Congress regime.
('74', 36, 1, 3, 66391) It is well that what was inside is now coming out.
('74', 36, 1, 4, 66442) But this is not civil liberty; it is criminal licence.
('74', 36, 1, 5, 66497) Swaraj will not come by way of falsehoods and violence.
('74', 36, 1, 6, 66553) And we shall do a double wrong if we do all these things in the name of truth and non violence.
('74', 36, 1, 7, 66649) I adhere to the advice I have tendered to the Congress and Congressmen.
('74', 36, 1, 8, 66721) Harijan, 17 9 1938

('74', 37, 1, 2, 67854) 60. LETTER TO SUSHILA GANDHI
('74', 37, 2, 3, 67883) September 17, 1938
('74', 37, 3, 4, 67902) SUSHILA, Where did you learn all this cunning?
('74', 37, 3, 5, 67949) There are criticisms on three heads and still you say it was only for my information.
('74', 37, 3, 6, 68035) What a way of putting things !
('74', 37, 3, 7, 68066) But you have the right to write whatever you like.
('74', 37, 3, 8, 68117) Chimanlal had asked me whether or not to give you the figure.
('74', 37, 3, 9, 68179) The expenses here are certainly on a royal scale.
('74', 37, 3, 10, 68229) I could not preserve my health without that.
('74', 37, 3, 11, 68274) The experiments in ghee, etc., also mean some expense.
('74', 37, 3, 12, 68329) So the expenses here are not a standard for anybody to follow.
('74', 37, 3, 13, 68392) If anyone were to tell me that friends give me money and I squander it I would listen and laugh.
('74', 37, 3, 14, 68489) No doubt there is scope for im provement but it can be effected only if I get a wise manager like you.
('74', 37, 3, 15, 68592) But you are not going to stay here for ever.

('74', 37, 3, 19, 68814) It would be better, however, to pay as long as you can afford.
('74', 37, 3, 20, 68877) It would be more accurate if you described me as lazy.

('74', 37, 3, 30, 69440) You did not reply to me.
('74', 37, 3, 31, 69465) There is no question of your forcing anything on me.
('74', 37, 3, 32, 69518) In spite of my being not free from passion, do you and Manudi desire that I should let myself be ministered to by and should touch women?
('74', 37, 3, 33, 69656) This question is an important one.
('74', 37, 3, 34, 69691) Manudi will not understand it but you can.
('74', 37, 3, 35, 69734) All of you can say: ‘So long as Bapu is not free from passion, let him be served only by Sushila and Ba.’ Or you can say: ‘When he puts the burden on us, we do wish that he would let us touch him.
('74', 37, 3, 36, 69931) What effect can his passion have on us?’ Either stand can be justified.
('74', 37, 3, 37, 70003) The first is safer from all points of view.
('74', 37, 3, 38, 70047) In fine, the experiment which I had commenced with a particular aim
('74', 38, 0, 1, 70115) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 39
('74', 38, 1, 2, 70163) can be said to have ended, and I invite the views of you all regarding any new step I may take.

('74', 40, 1, 2, 72869) 66. TO THE READERS
('74', 40, 2, 3, 72888) [September 18, 1938] 1
('74', 40, 3, 4, 72911) The readers of Harijan will share my sorrow that Mahadev Desai has become very ill.
('74', 40, 3, 5, 72995) Gilder and Jivaraj Mehta, who with their usual kindness came specially to examine him, have come to the conclusion that he must take prolonged rest.
('74', 40, 3, 6, 73144) He has had the same warnings that I had.
('74', 40, 3, 7, 73185) The doctors think that prolonged overwork has brought about the illness which, if neglected, may bring about paralysis of all activity.
('74', 40, 3, 8, 73321) Let the numerous friends of Mahadev not be alarmed over the news of his illness.
('74', 40, 3, 9, 73402) There is nothing to be alarmed about.
('74', 40, 3, 10, 73440) Only nature has issued a stern warning which he and I may not disregard except at our cost.
('74', 40, 3, 11, 73532) I include myself as an object of warning, for if I do not insist on Mahadev’s taking rest, he is quite capable of cheerfully taking his last breath with the pen in his hand.
('74', 40, 3, 12, 73706) If I am wise and true, he will take the needed rest.
('74', 40, 3, 13, 73759) Therefore, for the time being, the readers must miss the familiar and copious writings over the initials M. D. I am writing this note during the small hours of Sunday mor ning, having got up at 1.30 a.
('74', 40, 3, 14, 73961) for finishing Harijan work.
('74', 40, 3, 15, 73989) But I dare not repeat such liberty without the danger of a sudden collapse.
('74', 40, 3, 16, 74065) I have only limited physical energy left in me.
('74', 40, 3, 17, 74113) It has therefore to be sparingly used.
('74', 40, 3, 18, 74152) The third person who can do Harijan work is Pyarelal.
('74', 40, 3, 19, 74206) He has been hors de combat for some time and just now he is convalescing after the recent attack of enteric fever.
('74', 40, 3, 20, 74321) Harijan is not a newspaper, it is a ‘views’ paper representing those of one man.
('74', 40, 3, 21, 74402) Even Mahadev and Pyarelal may not write any thing independently whilst I am alive.
('74', 40, 3, 22, 74485) I am myself daily growing in the knowledge of satyagraha.
('74', 40, 3, 23, 74543) I have no text book to consult in time of need, not even the Gita which I have called my dictionary.
('74', 40, 3, 24, 74644) Satya graha as conceived by me is a science in the making.
('74', 40, 3, 25, 74703) It may be that what I claim to be a science may prove to be no science at all and may well prove to be the musings and doings of a fool, if not a madman.
('74', 40, 3, 26, 74857) It may be that what is true in satyagraha is as ancient as the hills.
('74', 40, 3, 27, 74927) But it has not yet been acknowledged to be of any value in the solution of world problems or rather the one supreme problem of war.
('74', 40, 3, 28, 75059) It may be
('74', 40, 4, 29, 75069) 1 The Sunday preceding September 24
('74', 41, 0, 1, 75105) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 42
('74', 41, 1, 2, 75146) that what is claimed to be new in it will be proved to be really of no value in terms of that supreme problem.
('74', 41, 1, 3, 75257) It may be that what are claimed to be victories of satyagraha, i.e.,ahimsa, were in reality victo ries not of truth and non violence but of fear of violence.
('74', 41, 1, 4, 75415) These possibilities have always been in front of me.
('74', 41, 1, 5, 75468) I am helpless.
('74', 41, 1, 6, 75483) All I present to the nation for adoption is an answer to prayer or, which is the same thing, constantly waiting on God.
('74', 41, 1, 7, 75603) Such being the case, whilst I am alive Harijan can only be continued so long as I am able to write or Mahadev or Pyarelal can interpret me from week to week.
('74', 41, 1, 8, 75761) The readers need not think that there are not others who can take the place of these two workers.
('74', 41, 1, 9, 75859) There are.
('74', 41, 1, 10, 75870) But they are all en gaged in the respective tasks allotted to them and it would be wrong to remove them from their spheres of work.
('74', 41, 1, 11, 76002) Satyagraha will not stop for want of Harijan, but it will for want of workers to carry on the mighty constructive programme.
('74', 41, 1, 12, 76127) Therefore, whilst Mahadev’s illness lasts, the readers will over look the gaps they will notice in the editing of Harijan.
('74', 41, 1, 13, 76250) This illness in duces a reflection.
('74', 41, 1, 14, 76286) I have often expressed the opinion among friends that in the matter of capacity for detachment Englishmen are far in advance of us.
('74', 41, 1, 15, 76418) No matter how important national affairs may be, they will keep their meal hours and hours of recreation.
('74', 41, 1, 16, 76524) They are not unnerved in the face of dangers or impending calamity.
('74', 41, 1, 17, 76592) This may be called working in the spirit of the Gita.
('74', 41, 1, 18, 76646) Among the political workers in India there are very few who come up to the Englishmen’s standard.
('74', 41, 1, 19, 76744) This English detachment is worthy of emulation.
('74', 41, 1, 20, 76792) That it is used for the exploitation of the so called uncivilized or semi civilized races of the earth is another matter.
('74', 41, 1, 21, 76914) It would be a distinct gain to the national cause if the leaders and workers strictly keep their hours.
('74', 41, 1, 22, 77018) No man is expected to do more than he really can.
('74', 41, 1, 23, 77068) If at the end of the day there is surplus work left or he cannot get through it without missing a meal or encroaching upon the hours of sleep or recreation, there is mismanagement somewhere.
('74', 41, 1, 24, 77259) I have no doubt that if we cultivate the habit of punctuality and acting according to programme, the index of national efficiency will go up, our advance towards our goal will be repaid and the workers will be healthier and longer lived.
('74', 41, 1, 25, 77497) In conclusion, the readers and correspondents will extend their indulgence if they find, as they will more than heretofore, that they
('74', 42, 0, 1, 77631) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 43
('74', 42, 1, 2, 77679) are not served in time or at all.
('74', 42, 1, 3, 77713) The correspondence is increasing, the work to do is also on the increase.
('74', 42, 1, 4, 77787) The capacity for coping with both is diminishing.
('74', 42, 1, 5, 77837) God’s will be done.
('74', 42, 1, 6, 77857) Harijan, 24 9 1938

('74', 53, 5, 10, 96273) 88. DRAFT OF RESOLUTION FOR A.I.C.C. 1
('74', 53, 6, 11, 96312) [Before September 23, 1938] Inasmuch as people including a few Congressmen have been found in the name of civil liberty to advocate murder, arson, looting, and class war by violent means, and several newspapers are carrying on a campaign of falsehood and violence calculated to incite the rea ders to violence and to lead to communal conflicts, the Congress warns the public that civil liberty does not cover acts of or incitement to violence or promulgation of palpable falsehoods.
('74', 53, 6, 12, 96795) In spite, there fore, of the Congress policy on civil liberty remaining unchanged the Congress will, consistently with its tradition, support measures that may be undertaken by the Congress Governments for the defence of life and property.
('74', 53, 6, 13, 97035) Harijan, 1 10 1938
('74', 53, 7, 14, 97054) 1 This was drafted by Gandhiji; vide “Discussion with Communists”, Before 11 11 1938. The resolution was passed by the Working Committee, which met in Delhi from September 23 to September 25 and later, on September 26, by the A.I.C.C. when a group of people walked out.
('74', 53, 7, 15, 97324) Vide also “That Unfortunate Walk out”, 5 10 1938.

('74', 54, 8, 19, 98178) 91. SPEECH AT CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE
('74', 54, 9, 20, 98219) [September 23, 1938] 3
('74', 54, 10, 21, 98242) Mahatma Gandhi began by thanking the members for expressing their views on the questionnaire that he had written out in the last two days.
('74', 54, 10, 22, 98381) He was sure that the members would have read his articles during the last two months in the Harijan on the increase of violence in the Congress organizations.
('74', 54, 10, 23, 98540) He had thought over the subject very carefully.
('74', 54, 11, 24, 98588) First, said Mahatmaji, he had noticed that several Congressmen, who had
('74', 54, 12, 25, 98660) 1 This was in reply to the Trivandrum Law College Union’s message regarding the situation in Travancore.
('74', 54, 12, 26, 98765) 2 The news item carrying the report is dated September 23. 3 From The Bombay Chronicle and Gandhijiki Dilli Diary, Part II
('74', 55, 0, 1, 98888) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 56
('74', 55, 1, 2, 98929) joined the Congress and signed the pledge without understanding or believing in the necessity for observing truth and non violence as essential steps to achieve swaraj, had committed breaches of these two conditions.
('74', 55, 1, 3, 99146) He had recently noted many Congressmen writing leaflets or making speeches in the name of civil liberty, inciting others to violence.
('74', 55, 1, 4, 99280) Such speeches and writings, which were retarding the progress of the Congress towards its goal, should be stopped.
('74', 55, 1, 5, 99395) The Working Committee could do it by defining civil liberty in a resolution.
('74', 55, 1, 6, 99472) Any incitement to violence in the name of civil liberty should be treated as a breach of Congress discipline and as such severely dealt with by the disqualification of the guilty members from holding offices or posts of responsibility in the Congress.
('74', 55, 1, 7, 99724) It was open to the Working Committee to accept his suggestion, but he would emphasize the strict enforcement of discipline in the ranks.
('74', 55, 1, 8, 99861) He would go even to the length of expelling those who committed breaches of discipline from the Congress.
('74', 55, 2, 9, 99967) Gandhiji continued that there should be no compromise with violence or untruth.
('74', 55, 2, 10, 100047) The Congress today was actually manned by those who had lost faith in the creed of non violence and the constructive programme of khaddar, [removal of] untouchability, prohibition and Hindu Muslim unity.
('74', 55, 2, 11, 100251) The real strength of the Congress depended on these twins, non violence and constructive programme.
('74', 55, 2, 12, 100351) When certain power was captured by Congressmen, there was an unhealthy competition to divide the spoils, which indicated that Congressmen were not able to digest power.
('74', 55, 2, 13, 100520) This unseemly rush to capture committees by violence and corrupt methods would make swaraj a distant dream.
('74', 55, 2, 14, 100628) This was not the way to win swaraj; this was not the way to work the office acceptance programme.
('74', 55, 2, 15, 100726) The ministries had been accepted by the Congress in a spirit of service.
('74', 55, 2, 16, 100799) It was, therefore, necessary to apply the purge, as otherwise the Congress would collapse under its own weakness.
('74', 55, 2, 17, 100913) Incitement to violence should be checked.
('74', 55, 2, 18, 100955) Otherwise it would soon degenerate into undignified goondaism.
('74', 55, 3, 19, 101018) So far as Congress organizations were concerned, Mahatma Gandhi suggested that only those who had been in the Congress registers for five years should be eligible to hold offices or posts of responsibility in the Congress.
('74', 55, 3, 20, 101241) He is reported to have added that the yarn franchise which was abandoned in 1926 should be restored.
('74', 55, 3, 21, 101342) All office bearers in Congress organizations should annually contribute 5,000 yards of hand spun yarn to the Congress.
('74', 55, 3, 22, 101461) He would make yarn franchise a compulsory clause.
('74', 55, 3, 23, 101511) He knew that it was found unworkable in 1926 by many Congressmen but he would not care for the volume of Congress membership.
('74', 55, 3, 24, 101637) He would not mind a fall in membeship of the Congress.
('74', 55, 3, 25, 101692) Ten thousand true and non violent Congressmen could bring swaraj and work wonders rather than ten million Congressmen on the rolls committing violence.
('74', 55, 4, 26, 101844) It had been argued, said Mahatma Gandhi, that Congress would cease to be a democratic organization and would be reduced to a closed corporation.
('74', 55, 4, 27, 101989) Democracy, he said, would not live in the atmosphere of untruth and violence.
('74', 55, 4, 28, 102067) It would flourish only if truth and non violence existed.
('74', 55, 4, 29, 102125) Congressmen should develop a higher degree of non violence.
('74', 55, 4, 30, 102185) The Provincial Ministers should soon develop peaceful methods of
('74', 56, 0, 1, 102250) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 57
('74', 56, 1, 2, 102298) dealing with violence.
('74', 56, 1, 3, 102321) The Peace Brigade was one of such methods.
('74', 56, 1, 4, 102364) Until a correct remedy was found, the Ministers would be permitted to deal with offences in the manner they considered best, but they could not depend on the military to quell riots for long.
('74', 56, 1, 5, 102556) If they were unable to establish peace by non violent methods in the near future, they should resign their offices.
('74', 56, 1, 6, 102672) The idea of the military was opposed to the Congress creed of non violence and should be supplanted by stages.
('74', 56, 2, 7, 102783) When asked how non violence could check foreign aggression, Mahatma Gandhi is reported to have replied that if India had one crore of non violent volunteers, he was confident that no nation could conquer India.
('74', 56, 2, 8, 102994) If they failed in their attempt to prevent aggression, then the fault was theirs, not in the philosophy of non violence but in their methods of practising it.
('74', 56, 2, 9, 103153) Mahatma Gandhi was convinced that non violence, if properly applied, could not only solve India’s problems but also the world’s.
('74', 56, 3, 10, 103282) Gandhiji concluded that these were his views.
('74', 56, 3, 11, 103328) The members could ponder over them and tell him whether they could accept and work them.
('74', 56, 3, 12, 103417) If they were not in agreement with his views, they were at liberty to reject them.
('74', 56, 3, 13, 103500) The Hindu, 24 9 1938
('74', 56, 4, 14, 103521) 92. CORRUPTION IN THE CONGRESS
('74', 56, 5, 15, 103552) It is difficult to cope with the correspondence that I am having from several places about violence, untruth and corruption in the Congress.
('74', 56, 5, 16, 103693) Whilst I must continue to publish typical correspondence about the weaknesses of Congresmen, I must issue a warning against hasty deduction being drawn that all is ill with the Congress.
('74', 56, 5, 17, 103880) I know it is not.
('74', 56, 5, 18, 103898) But it is true that violence, untruth and corruption have made inroads enough to warrant drastic measures in order to prevent decay overtaking the great organization.
('74', 56, 5, 19, 104065) Here are extracts from two typical letters :
('74', 56, 6, 20, 104110) (1) Perhaps you are aware how the enrolment of bogus Congress members is going on unimpeded everywhere, and how rich and unscrupulous persons are controlling the affairs of the Congress organization, keeping skilfully the genuine and devoted workers out of their way.
('74', 56, 6, 21, 104378) Some are paying the membership subscription of annas 4 for others under their control out of their own pockets, and some are going a step forward and are not paying a single pie to the Congress committees and instead making the primary committees under their clutches prepare false accounts of their apparent collections and thereby evading the supervising eye of the sub divisional as well as district committees.
('74', 56, 7, 22, 104793) Primary committees having less than 25 members are not required, under the rules framed by it, to pay anything to higher committees out of the membership fee.
('74', 56, 7, 23, 104952) The result is that a good many paper committees are being
('74', 57, 0, 1, 105010) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 58
('74', 57, 1, 2, 105051) set up with less than 25 members to deprive the sub divisional and district committees of their quota of the membership subscription as also to secure a larger proportion of representation in these Committees.
('74', 57, 2, 3, 105261) (2) It is my duty to bring to your notice the open and scandalous corruption in enrolling Congress members.
('74', 57, 2, 4, 105369) The Congress authorities here, especially the Executives, know this state of things well, but it is difficult to know why the necessary steps are not being taken.
('74', 57, 2, 5, 105532) If steps are not taken, things will go from bad to worse and the whole Congress institution will be disgraced and the hold on people will be lost.
('74', 57, 3, 6, 105679) (i) Every party is trying to capture the Congress office—whether Primary, Sub divisional, District or Provincial.
('74', 57, 3, 7, 105793) And for this purpose bogus members are being enrolled by practically every group.
('74', 57, 4, 8, 105875) (ii) There are a good many names of persons on the Congress rolls, but on scrutiny it can be easily found out that there are no such persons in existence at all.
('74', 57, 4, 9, 106037) During election time the same group of persons is mobilized at elections of primary Congress committees of different wards.
('74', 57, 5, 10, 106161) (iii) The members are enrolled sometimes without their own signatures on application forms and in most cases without taking payment of the annual subscription of four annas.
('74', 57, 6, 11, 106335) (iv) The question arises how the account of collection of subscription by the primary, sub divisional and district Congress committees is maintained.
('74', 57, 6, 12, 106485) In almost all cases where a group is in possession of the office and necessarily the office account, collection of the annual subscription for all the bogus members is shown to the credit side, and at the same time nearly the whole amount is shown to the debit side on the different heads of expenses, such as travelling expense, meeting expense, allowance expense, etc.
('74', 57, 6, 13, 106856) Really they do not collect the subscription and maintain a false account.
('74', 57, 7, 14, 106930) I do not know how all these corruptions can be stopped.
('74', 57, 7, 15, 106986) There wil be, I hope, changes of rules at the next A. I. C. C. meeting at Delhi.
('74', 57, 7, 16, 107067) Some steps should be immediately taken to stop the corruption.
('74', 57, 7, 17, 107130) Identification of Congress members, signatures of the members on the application forms, actual realization of subscription from the members and true accounts should be enforced.
('74', 57, 7, 18, 107308) These statements have been made by responsible parties.
('74', 57, 7, 19, 107364) The letters are meant for publication.
('74', 57, 7, 20, 107403) But I have purposely suppressed the names of my correspondents as also of the province in which the corruption is said to exist.
('74', 57, 7, 21, 107532) It is to be hoped that the Working Committee and the A. I. C. C. will deal with this as well as the other serious questions that will come
('74', 58, 0, 1, 107671) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 59
('74', 58, 1, 2, 107719) up for discussion and decision.
('74', 58, 1, 3, 107751) It would be a tragedy if the session of the A. I. C. C. were to be frittered away in orations or mutual wran glings.
('74', 58, 1, 4, 107868) Harijan, 24 9 1938

('74', 59, 6, 12, 109474) 96. INTERVIEW TO F. S. YOUNG 1
('74', 59, 7, 13, 109505) September 24, 1938
('74', 59, 8, 14, 109524) I 2 first of all related the whole position to Gandhiji and then asked Young to say what he had to say.
('74', 59, 8, 15, 109628) He then at great length stated the whole position and asked Gandhiji’s help.
('74', 59, 8, 16, 109705) The first two paragraphs are in reply to that.
('74', 59, 8, 17, 109752) (1) All I can say is that somehow or other the authorities should be made to see that in Seth Jamnalalji and Pandit Hiralal they have men who are true as steel and who believe in non violence as their creed.
('74', 59, 8, 18, 109960) (2) Surely it will be unwise to imprison them instead of holding them as willing hostages for peace.
('74', 59, 8, 19, 110061) To ban the Praja Mandal is to invite trouble where there is none today.
('74', 59, 9, 20, 110133) In reply to the first two paragraphs, Young said that there was no question of imprisoning anyone.
('74', 59, 9, 21, 110232) That position had not yet arrived and he hoped that it would never arrive.
('74', 59, 9, 22, 110307) To this Gandhiji replied in the third paragraph.
('74', 59, 9, 23, 110356) (3) You will reach that stage in a moment, if you have an organization which is working [un]constitutionally and with which they are identified.
('74', 59, 9, 24, 110501) I do not think they can surrender the right to agi tate for responsible government.
('74', 59, 9, 25, 110585) The authorities may or may not grant it.
('74', 59, 9, 26, 110626) But they should not ban an activity which is in its nature peaceful.
('74', 59, 9, 27, 110695) You may take all precautions to ensure peace.
('74', 59, 10, 28, 110741) 1 D. B. Kalelkar explains : “By the efforts of Shri G. D. Birla a meeting was brought about between Gandhiji and Mr. Young, I. G. P., Jaipur State, to talk about the Jaipur Rajya Praja Mandal.
('74', 59, 10, 29, 110934) Gandhiji gave his answers in writing.
('74', 59, 10, 30, 110972) Later Shri G. D. Birla prepared a note explaining Gandhiji’s answers.
('74', 59, 10, 31, 111042) .” 2 G. D. Birla
('74', 60, 0, 1, 111059) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 61
('74', 60, 1, 2, 111107) In reply to this, Young pointed out the activities of the Mandal in enlisting Congress members.
('74', 60, 1, 3, 111203) He said the Council had a suspicion that the Praja Mandal was only another name for the Congress and after having seen the disturbances in Travancore and Mysore, they were rather afraid of Congress creating trouble in Jaipur.
('74', 60, 1, 4, 111429) Could not the Praja Mandal keep itself separate from the Congress?
('74', 60, 1, 5, 111496) The fourth paragraph is in reply to that.
('74', 60, 1, 6, 111538) (4) You can’t prevent natural affinities.
('74', 60, 1, 7, 111580) People are drawn towards the Congress.
('74', 60, 1, 8, 111619) You seek its assistance in order to promote peace as Sir Mirza did wisely and as Sir Akbar is already doing and Sir C. P. will do presently.
('74', 60, 2, 9, 111760) In reply to this, Young said, “But what if they start trouble?
('74', 60, 2, 10, 111823) If their consitution is something different, then there should be no difficulty in recognizing it but with this constitution, if they start trouble, peace might be disturbed.” The penultimate and the last paragraph are in reply to this.
('74', 60, 2, 11, 112060) (5) You can ask them to meet you a long way as to how they should shape their activity.
('74', 60, 2, 12, 112148) You stifle opinion if you say they may not even ask for responsible government.
('74', 60, 2, 13, 112228) You should shed the fear of the Congress.
('74', 60, 2, 14, 112270) (6) What I have suggested is this.
('74', 60, 2, 15, 112305) Don’t interfere with their objective but regulate the speed with which they move.
('74', 60, 2, 16, 112387) You may, for instance, regulate the demonstrative part of their programme.
('74', 60, 2, 17, 112462) You will control their language.
('74', 60, 2, 18, 112495) But to ask them to change their objective is like asking a man to change his religion.
('74', 60, 3, 19, 112582) In the end, Mr. Young profusely thanked Gandhiji and made a request for taking the notes with him as a sort of souvenir to which Gandhiji agreed subject to his being provided with a copy of the same.
('74', 60, 3, 20, 112782) The last three lines are in reply to my question whether Sir Akbar had already written for help and whether C. P. also had applied for help.
('74', 60, 3, 21, 112923) I whould like you to give me a copy of the notes.
('74', 60, 3, 22, 112973) I have Sir Akbar’s letter asking for help.
('74', 60, 3, 23, 113016) More than a hope.
('74', 60, 3, 24, 113034) He has wired to Pattabhi asking him to meet him.
('74', 60, 3, 25, 113083) (This is about C. P.)
