('74', 61, 3, 13, 114188) 98. DRAFT OF RESOLUTION FOR A. I. C. C. 3
('74', 61, 4, 14, 114230) [On or before September 26, 1938] The A. I. C. C. notes with sorrow and dismay the repression that has been going on in Travancore for some days.
('74', 61, 4, 15, 114376) The evidence that has come to the Congress office, if it is to be believed, goes to show that the movement led by the State Congress in Travancore is strictly constitutional and for a constitutional purpose, viz., attainment of res ponsible government under the aegis of His Highness the Maharaja.
('74', 61, 4, 16, 114674) The repudiation published on behalf of the State is categorically con tradicted by the spokesmen of the Stage Congress.
('74', 61, 4, 17, 114794) In the circumstances the A. I. C. C. recommends to the Travan core Government for adoption the following policy, viz., assurance on the one hand that the State Congress is free to carry on the movement for responsible government in a constitutional manner; appointment of a commitee containing, among others, representatives of the State Congress to explore the possibility of granting responsible govern ment, and an inquiry conducted by a jurist outside the State of unim peachable impartiality into the recent happenings including the charges made by the State of provocations justifying the State mea 
('74', 61, 5, 18, 115400) 1 Mother of Brijkrishna Chandiwala 2 Harijan Nivas.
('74', 61, 5, 19, 115452) Brijkrishna Chandiwala in his book, Gandhijiki Dilli Diary, Part II, writes that a suggestion to build a prayer hall in Harijan Nivas had come from Viyogi Hari.
('74', 61, 5, 20, 115613) 3 Published in Harijan under the title “Indian States”.
('74', 61, 5, 21, 115669) This was drafted by Gandhiji; vide “Note to Jamnalal Bajaj”, 26 9 1938
('74', 62, 0, 1, 115740) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 63
('74', 62, 1, 2, 115788) sures including firing on unarmed people resulting in deaths and inju ries, and an amnesty to the prisoners.
('74', 62, 1, 3, 115897) The A. I. C. C. regrets that the Hyderabad State has issued ordinances which appear to give to the State power altogether in excess of requirements.
('74', 62, 1, 4, 116046) The A. I. C. C. has also received complaints of severe repression in the States like Dhenkanal, Talchar and Kashmir.
('74', 62, 1, 5, 116163) In all these cases the people of the States have appealed to the Congress for advice, guidance and help.
('74', 62, 1, 6, 116268) The A. I. C. C. can but reiterate its policy of non interference, and, consistently with the resources, to help the people in every way open to the Congress.
('74', 62, 1, 7, 116426) The policy of non interference is an admission of the limitations of the Congress.
('74', 62, 1, 8, 116509) The Congess policy has been one of friendliness to the States.
('74', 62, 1, 9, 116572) In spite of the declarations of some Con gressmen to the contrary, the corporate policy of the Congress, so long as it holds by truth and non violence, must be one of continuous attempt to convert the Princes to the view that their true welfare con sists in a voluntary surrender of power to the people so as to bring them in a line with the people of the so called British India, consis tently with the existence of the constitutional heads of the respective States.

('74', 69, 2, 5, 126896) 113. FEDERATION
('74', 69, 3, 6, 126912) A well known correspondent tells me that in London the common talk is that Gandhi counts for everything and it does not matter what the Congress or Congressmen may say or do.
('74', 69, 3, 7, 127087) The critics embellish the statement by saying that there is a wide difference of opinion between Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and myself, and that while he will not touch Federation with a pair of tongs, I am prepared to submit to it if some trifles are conceded.
('74', 69, 3, 8, 127346) I have paraphrased in my own words a longish letter 1 giving details which I may not share with the readers at least at the present juncture.
('74', 69, 3, 9, 127488) Evidently my critics know more of me than I seem to know myself.
('74', 69, 3, 10, 127553) For instance I know how little I count among Congressmen; the critics know how much I count among them.
('74', 69, 3, 11, 127657) Whatever influence I still possess among Congressmen is solely due to my constant appeal to reason and never to authority.
('74', 69, 3, 12, 127780) But if I had the influence the critics attribute to me, I make bold to say that India would have gained her independence long ago and there would be no repression that is going on unchecked in some of the States.
('74', 69, 3, 13, 127993) I know the art of winning inde pendence and stopping the frightfulness of which one reads in the papers.
('74', 69, 3, 14, 128098) If I had my way with the Congressmen, there would be no corruption, no untruth and no violence amongst them.
('74', 69, 3, 15, 128207) If I had my way with them, they would all be enthusiastic khaddarites and there would be no surplus khadi in the A.I.S.A. bhandars.
('74', 69, 3, 16, 128339) But I am going astray.
('74', 69, 3, 17, 128362) I had intended to write about Federation.
('74', 69, 3, 18, 128404) In the first place, in all my talks, which have been very few, I have made it clear that I represent nobody and that I have not even aired my views to any Congressman.
('74', 69, 3, 19, 128572) I have also made it clear that what the Congress says and does is of consequence, whatever I may say is of no value unless it represents the Congress view.
('74', 69, 3, 20, 128728) As a matter of fact, too, I have said that the Congress will never have Federation forced upon it, and that there was no hope of peace in India till there was indepen 
('74', 69, 4, 21, 128896) 1 The reference presumably is to a letter from Carl Heath; vide “Letter to Carl Heath”, 13 9 1938
('74', 70, 0, 1, 128994) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 71
('74', 70, 1, 2, 129042) dence in virtue of a constitution framed by a duly convened Constituent Assembly.
('74', 70, 1, 3, 129124) I have also made it clear that so far as Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and I are concerned, though we may talk in different language, we are one in most things that matter to India.
('74', 70, 1, 4, 129300) On the question of Federation there never has been any difference of opinion between us.
('74', 70, 1, 5, 129389) And I have made a rule for myself that so far as the Congress in concerned, if there is an unbridgeable gulf between him and me his view should prevail.
('74', 70, 1, 6, 129542) And this for the very good reason that I am not in the Congress and he is in the centre of it, and very much in touch with everything relating to the Congress.
('74', 70, 2, 7, 129702) Harijan, 1 10 1938
('74', 70, 3, 8, 129721) 114. NON INTERVENTION
('74', 70, 4, 9, 129743) Congress non intervention in the affairs of the States was con ceived in 1920 and has been more or less its policy since that time in spite of many onslaughts made on it.
('74', 70, 4, 10, 129914) But I see that it has become the fashion in the States to quote against the Congress and Congressmen the self imposed restraint even when there is any attempt to criticize or offer advice or help.
('74', 70, 4, 11, 130111) It is therefore necessary to examine the impli cations of non intervention.
('74', 70, 4, 12, 130187) It was never regarded as a principle.
('74', 70, 4, 13, 130225) It was a limitation imposed on itself by the Congress for its own sake and that of the people of the States.
('74', 70, 4, 14, 130334) The Congress had no sanction behind its resolutions regarding the States.
('74', 70, 4, 15, 130408) Its advice might be ignored, its intervention resented and the people of the States might be harassed without gaining anything.
('74', 70, 4, 16, 130536) There was certainly a friendly motive behind that policy.
('74', 70, 4, 17, 130594) It was a wise recognition of the limited capacity of the Congress for doing good.
('74', 70, 4, 18, 130676) The restraint exercised by the Congress in this and many other ways has given it a prestige and power which it would be unwise for it not to use.
('74', 70, 4, 19, 130822) Any hesitation in this respect would be like that of the foolish steward who would not use the talents which were placed at his disposal.
('74', 70, 4, 20, 130960) Up to a point the States are beginning to recognize the power of the Congress be it ever so reluctantly.
('74', 70, 4, 21, 131065) It is becoming sufficiently clear that the people of the States are looking to the Congress for guidance and help.
('74', 70, 4, 22, 131180) I think that it is the duty of the Congress to give them the guidance and help wherever it can.
('74', 70, 4, 23, 131276) I wish I could convince every Congressman that the prestige and power of the Congress are in exact proportion to its inner purity, its sense of exact justice and its all round goodwill.
('74', 71, 0, 1, 131462) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 71, 1, 2, 131503) people of the States feel safe in entrusting their welfare to the Con gress, the Princes should feel equally safe in trusting the Congress.
('74', 71, 1, 3, 131643) All the prestige built up by patient effort of years will certainly be under mined if the warnings uttered by me to the Congressmen go un heeded.
('74', 71, 1, 4, 131789) Even at the risk of tiresome repetition let me say to the people of the States that they must not set much store by the Congress help.
('74', 71, 1, 5, 131924) It is not enough that they are truthful and non violent.
('74', 71, 1, 6, 131981) It is necessary also for them to know their own capacity for suffering.
('74', 71, 1, 7, 132053) Liberty is a dame exacting a heavy price from her wooers.
('74', 71, 1, 8, 132111) And unless there are many who are prepared to pay the price, the few enthusiasts that are to be found everywhere would do well to conserve their energy.
('74', 71, 1, 9, 132264) They will do well to undertake constructive service of the people without having an ambitious political programme.

('74', 71, 1, 11, 132458) Wisdom and patience will give them a power which in time will become irresistible.

('74', 72, 3, 13, 134177) 117. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('74', 72, 4, 14, 134205) October 3, 1938 Correspondents have been writing and wiring to me about the events in Travancore 1. Shri Changanacheri K. Parameswaran Pillai has been specially to see me and acquaint me with the situation.
('74', 72, 4, 15, 134412) He has erred in giving his version of my talk with him.
('74', 72, 4, 16, 134468) Whilst the situation remains delicate, every word has to be weighed before it is uttered.
('74', 72, 4, 17, 134558) Shri Pillai was clear that mob violence in the shape of stone throwing had occured.
('74', 72, 4, 18, 134642) He, however, made it perfectly clear that the State Congress people had no part in it and that it was contrary to their wish.
('74', 72, 4, 19, 134768) I have wires denying mob violence and definitely saying that violence was instigated by agents provocateurs.
('74', 72, 4, 20, 134877) I am unable to decide between the two opposite versions.
('74', 72, 4, 21, 134934) But I can say this that satyagraha demands extraordinary caution, even to the extent of suspension of civil disobedience, if the resisters have not full control over forces of violence.
('74', 72, 4, 22, 135120) What exactly should be done I cannot advise from this distance.
('74', 72, 4, 23, 135184) The responsibility for right decision must be shouldered by local leaders.
('74', 72, 4, 24, 135259) In coming to their decision they will remember that any the slightest deviation from truth and non violence, whether in themselves or by connivance in others, is bound to affect the movement adversely.
('74', 72, 4, 25, 135461) As to the charges against the Dewan, I telegraphed 2 the
('74', 72, 5, 26, 135518) 1 Where the demand of the State Congress for responsible government had been met with shootings and imprisonments on a large scale with the State Congress itself having been declared a subversive organization; vide “Statement to the Press”, 6 9 1938 and “The states and Responsibility”, 17 9 1938 2 This telegram is not traceable.
('74', 73, 0, 1, 135849) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 73, 1, 2, 135890) imprisoned leaders who were responsible for making them.
('74', 73, 1, 3, 135947) This is their reply:
('74', 73, 2, 4, 135968) Your kind telegram advising withdrawal of the State Congress memorandum.
('74', 73, 2, 5, 136041) We consulted T. M. Verghese and others.
('74', 73, 2, 6, 136081) The Working Committee feels satisfied that the Dewan’s continuance in office is detrimental to the people’s interests.
('74', 73, 2, 7, 136200) The withdrawal of the memorandum may unmeritedly discredit the State Congress and cause an irretrievable setback to the movement.
('74', 73, 2, 8, 136330) Pray for support and guidance.
('74', 73, 2, 9, 136361) I appreciate the spirit behind the reply.
('74', 73, 2, 10, 136403) The leaders would be lowered in my estimation if, for the sake of purchasing their liberty, they withdrew the charges.
('74', 73, 2, 11, 136522) But if the conviction has gone home that in a demand for responsible government such charges could have only a subordinate place, if any at all, and if they saw with me that persistence in them, especially without the ability to prove them, can but seriously harm the movement, it is their clear duty to withdraw the charges and thus free the movement of the initial blunder and handicap.
('74', 73, 2, 12, 136911) There is no discredit greater than the refusal to acknowledge errors.
('74', 73, 2, 13, 136981) I have wires alleging tortures by the authorities.
('74', 73, 2, 14, 137032) It is hard to believe them.
('74', 73, 2, 15, 137060) I hope they are baseless, and if isolated cases have happened, I should hope that the Travancore Government will prevent any future recurrence.
('74', 73, 2, 16, 137204) I observe that the movement promises to be protracted if only because of violence, whether spontaneous though unconnected with the Congress, or engineered as alleged.
('74', 73, 2, 17, 137371) I can only entertain the hope that the authorities will relent and magnanimously allow the move ment to run its course without the ban which I consider to be wholly unnecessary.
('74', 73, 2, 18, 137549) A movement in itself wholly noble, which claims cul tured men and women as willing and enthusiastic sufferers, should be fostered.
('74', 73, 2, 19, 137680) It can never be crushed.

('74', 74, 11, 18, 138696) 121. NOTE TO P. SREEDHARAN NAIR 2

('74', 80, 3, 11, 146487) 132. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('74', 80, 4, 12, 146515) October 4, 1938 I should have given my opinion on the Bengal Government’s communique 1 on the question of the release of the political convicts earlier.
('74', 80, 4, 13, 146668) But pressure of work made it physically impossible for me to do so.
('74', 80, 4, 14, 146736) Though the Bengal Government have not seen their way to accede to my proposal contained in my letter 2 of 13th April last, I gratefully recognize that from their own standpoint they have endeavoured to make an approach to the letter of 13th April.
('74', 80, 4, 15, 146984) But having paid this tribute to the Bengal Government I must say that their rejection of my proposal is a severe disapointment to me.
('74', 80, 4, 16, 147118) For I claim that my proposal was made after considering and weighing the Bengal Government’s difficulties.
('74', 80, 4, 17, 147225) The decision seems to me to be due to their failure to recognize three factors.
('74', 80, 4, 18, 147305) However reprehensible the crimes committed by the prisoners were, there can be no doubt that the crimes were not a result of personal or selfish motive, the motive behind them was purely political.
('74', 80, 4, 19, 147503) Whatever the limitations of the Government of India Act, it has transferred power to a parliament responsible to the people and elec ted under a fairly wide franchise.
('74', 80, 4, 20, 147671) Apart, therefore, from the decla rations of non violence made by the prisoners, the transfer of power to a popularly elected legislature takes the ground from under the feet of the advocates of terrorism.
('74', 80, 4, 21, 147876) In as much as the Congress has chosen to enter the legislatures and even to accept ministerial responsibility, Congressmen are bound to examine the possibilities of the machinery to respond to the popular will.
('74', 80, 4, 22, 148087) In this particular instance, as we have seen in what may
('74', 80, 5, 23, 148144) 1 Vide “Lettter to Khwaja Nazimuddin”, 11 5 1938 2 Vide “Lettter to Khwaja Nazimuddin”, 13 4 1938
('74', 81, 0, 1, 148242) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 81, 1, 2, 148283) be described as Congress provinces, the Provincial Governments have been able to release political prisoners.
('74', 81, 1, 3, 148393) What has been possible in these provinces is possible in Bengal, if the popular will is sufficiently expressed.
('74', 81, 1, 4, 148505) The third factor is the Bengal Government’s reference to the existence of the two well known parties connected with terrorist methods.
('74', 81, 1, 5, 148640) The reference seems to suggest that these parties function for their original purpose.
('74', 81, 1, 6, 148727) I know, and I had given the Khwaja Saheb the required assurance, that the organizations no longer functioned in the old way.
('74', 81, 1, 7, 148852) Comrades belonging to groups do not change names of their groups or loyalties because the methods which the labels origi nally stood for have become obsolete.
('74', 81, 1, 8, 149011) I would, however, advise amalgamation and the use of another name for the combination, if they must preserve their separate status.
('74', 81, 1, 9, 149143) Not only have the Bengal Government failed to take any or adequate notice of these three factors, they have failed to give due weight to the positive assurances of non violence given by the priso ners, which those who have been discharged seem to have carried out faithfully.
('74', 81, 1, 10, 149419) I therefore renew my appeal to the Bengal Government to respond to my proposal of 13th April, and release all the prisoners by 13th April, 1939. I do not mind what procedure they wish to adopt.
('74', 81, 1, 11, 149613) They can have the committee announced by them and through it regulate the dates of discharge of the prisoners.
('74', 81, 1, 12, 149724) One thing, so far as I am concerned, is undoubtedly common cause if there is to be a com plete clearance, viz., that the atmosphere of non violence is retained and that those who are discharged carry out the self imposed obli gation about non violence.
('74', 81, 1, 13, 149977) I would appeal to the Press and the public to restrain them selves in their criticism of the action of the Bengal Government in the matter and not embarrass them by bitter criticism.
('74', 81, 1, 14, 150160) It must be said to the credit of the Bengal Government that they have certainly not treated it as a party question.
('74', 81, 1, 15, 150276) Though the release is an integral part of the Congress programme only, it has more or less become an all parties’ question.
('74', 81, 1, 16, 150400) And I have no doubt that the quickest method of securing early release is never to allow the question to become a party question.
('74', 81, 1, 17, 150530) I would appeal to the prisoners not to be disturbed by the Bengal Government’s communique.
('74', 81, 1, 18, 150621) Having been myself a prisoner over half a dozen times under varying circumstances, I know how apart from the hardships of jail life, the uncertainty of his fate gnaws
('74', 82, 0, 1, 150788) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 83
('74', 82, 1, 2, 150836) into a prisoner’s whole being especially when he is fretting to go out and serve.
('74', 82, 1, 3, 150918) But I would ask them to treat 13th April or thereabouts as still the last date of their discharge.
('74', 82, 1, 4, 151017) It is contrary to my nature to import ‘thereabouts’ in fixing time tables, but the prisoner friends should extend to me the concession due to old age and its physical limitations.
('74', 82, 1, 5, 151197) I can give this assurance that ‘thereabouts’ does not mean years.
('74', 82, 1, 6, 151263) It can only refer to months.
('74', 82, 1, 7, 151292) They will please remember that they will hamper the effort of those who are trying to secure their release by resort to hunger strike.
('74', 82, 1, 8, 151427) I have given them myself as a hostage.
('74', 82, 1, 9, 151466) So long as there is life in me, I hope by God’s grace to stand by my promise not to relax the effort to secure their discharge.
('74', 82, 1, 10, 151594) There is no rest for me till every one of the prisoners is discharged.
('74', 82, 1, 11, 151665) They nobly responded to my call for an assurance of non violence.
('74', 82, 1, 12, 151731) I will keep my faith.
('74', 82, 1, 13, 151753) Some of my correspondents seem to think that I can work wonders.
('74', 82, 1, 14, 151818) Let me say as a devotee of truth that I have no such gift.
('74', 82, 1, 15, 151877) All the power I may have comes from God.
('74', 82, 1, 16, 151918) But He does not work directly.
('74', 82, 1, 17, 151949) He works through his numberless agencies.
('74', 82, 1, 18, 151991) In this case it is the Congress.
('74', 82, 1, 19, 152024) All the prestige that I have is derived from that of the Congress.
('74', 82, 1, 20, 152091) The latter derives it from its creed.
('74', 82, 1, 21, 152129) If Congressmen deny the creed of truth and non violence, the Congress loses prestige.
('74', 82, 1, 22, 152215) I assure them that my virtues, real or so called, will not count for anything, if I did not represent the Congress mind.
('74', 82, 1, 23, 152336) Friends of prisoners outside Bengal and sometimes the priso ners themselves write to me complaining that I confine my attention only to the Bengal prisoners.
('74', 82, 1, 24, 152494) In a way this is true.
('74', 82, 1, 25, 152517) I am bound to them by a written contract.
('74', 82, 1, 26, 152559) But in another way it is not true.
('74', 82, 1, 27, 152594) I do interest myself in their discharge also.
('74', 82, 1, 28, 152640) But the full suceess depends largely upon what happens in Bengal.
('74', 82, 1, 29, 152706) Let them, however, know that my efforts for their release continue, even apart from the Bengal priso ners.
('74', 82, 2, 30, 152813) Harijan, 8 10 1938

('74', 85, 10, 20, 157082) 139. THAT UNFORTUNATE WALK OUT
('74', 85, 11, 21, 157113) The walk out at the last A.I.C.C. meeting of the opponents of the Civil Liberties Resolution 2 was an unfortunate and hasty act.
('74', 85, 11, 22, 157242) What was their protest against?
('74', 85, 11, 23, 157274) I understand the President went out of his way to let them make as many and as long speeches as they liked.
('74', 85, 11, 24, 157382) Therefore the protest was against the majority refusing to accept amendments which cut at the root of the resolution which was re garded as vital to the existence of the Congress in its present form.
('74', 85, 12, 25, 157582) 1 The Prince of Aundh visited Gandhiji at Segaon on 29 11 1938 and 1 12 1938. 2 Vide “Draft of Resolution for A.I.C.C.”, Before 23 9 1938
('74', 86, 0, 1, 157720) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 87
('74', 86, 1, 2, 157768) The walk out has served one good purpose.
('74', 86, 1, 3, 157810) It has brought out in clear light the fact that the Congress is not today the homogeneous body it used to be.
('74', 86, 1, 4, 157920) It has members and parties who have no faith in its creed or its constructive programme, specially khadi and prohibition.
('74', 86, 1, 5, 158042) In these circumstances the Congress must cease to be a compact fighting organization engaged in a life and death struggle against the most experienced and organized corporation in the world.
('74', 86, 1, 6, 158233) It has been since 1920 like an army in action having one will, one policy, one aim and exact discipline.
('74', 86, 1, 7, 158338) All this must go if the protesters can have their own way.
('74', 86, 1, 8, 158397) In the first place there can be no amendment of or protest against accepted policies.
('74', 86, 1, 9, 158483) But even if such is permissible, there should be perfect and willing obedience after the rejection of amendments and protests.
('74', 86, 1, 10, 158610) Opposition in the Congress is not to be compared to the opposition, say, in the Central Assembly.
('74', 86, 1, 11, 158708) There the opposition has little in common with the Government.
('74', 86, 1, 12, 158771) In the Congress there can only be those who willingly and whole heartedly subscribe to its creed.
('74', 86, 1, 13, 158869) Those who do not want independence cannot become its memebrs nor can those who do not believe in truth and non violence, khadi or communal unity or total abolition of untouchability among Hindus or total prohibition of drink and intoxicating drugs.
('74', 86, 1, 14, 159118) It is up to those who do not believe in the fundamental policy of the Congress seriously to consider whether they would not serve the Congress and the country better by remaining outside the Congress and converting the people to their view of conducting the campaign rather than by remaining within and obstructing those who do not see eye to eye with them and yet are in the unfortunate position of having the majority on their side.
('74', 86, 1, 15, 159553) It is equally the duty of the majority to consider how best to deal with those who will resort to obstructive tactics.
('74', 86, 1, 16, 159672) My opinion based on experience is that if, after a friendly discussion with the obstructionists (if the use of that word is permissible to describe them), it is found that they believe it to be their duty to continue obstruction, it would conduce to the good of the country to hand over the reins to the minority and themselves follow the existing Congress programme without using the Congress name.
('74', 86, 1, 17, 160072) All this can succeed beyond expectations if it is done without huff, without malice, without bitterness, and merely to meet a situation that is becoming impossible.
('74', 86, 1, 18, 160237) If chaos is to be prevented, proper measures must be taken in time.
('74', 86, 1, 19, 160305) PESHAWAR, October 5, 1938
('74', 86, 2, 20, 160331) Harijan, 15 10 1938

('74', 88, 4, 14, 162118) 143. IF I WERE A CZECH
('74', 88, 5, 15, 162141) If I have called the arrangement with Herr Hitler “peace without honour”, it was not to cast any reflection on British or French statesmen.
('74', 88, 5, 16, 162281) I have no doubt that Mr. Chamberlain could not think of anything better.
('74', 88, 5, 17, 162354) He knew his nation’s limitations.
('74', 88, 5, 18, 162388) He wanted to avoid war, if it could be avoided at all.
('74', 88, 5, 19, 162443) Short of going to war, he pulled his full weight in favour of the Czechs.
('74', 88, 5, 20, 162517) That it could not save honour was no fault of his.
('74', 88, 5, 21, 162568) It would be so evey time there is a struggle with Herr Hitler or Signor Mussolini.
('74', 88, 5, 22, 162651) It cannot be otherwise.
('74', 88, 5, 23, 162675) Democracy dreads to spill blood.
('74', 88, 5, 24, 162708) The philosophy for which the two dictators stand calls it cowardice to shrink from carnage.
('74', 88, 5, 25, 162800) They exhaust the resources of poetic art in order to glorify organized murder.
('74', 88, 5, 26, 162879) There is no humbug about their word or deed.
('74', 88, 5, 27, 162924) They are ever ready for war.
('74', 88, 5, 28, 162953) There is nobody in Germany or Italy to cross their path.
('74', 88, 5, 29, 163010) Their word is law.
('74', 88, 5, 30, 163029) It is different with Mr. Chamberlain or M. Daladier 1. They have their Parliaments and Chambers to please.
('74', 88, 5, 31, 163136) They have parties to confer with.
('74', 88, 5, 32, 163170) They cannot maintain themselves on a perpetual war footing if their language is to have a democratic accent about it.
('74', 88, 5, 33, 163288) Science of war leads one to dictatorship pure and simple.
('74', 88, 5, 34, 163346) Science of non violence can alone lead one to pure democracy.
('74', 88, 5, 35, 163408) Eng land, France and America have to make their choice.
('74', 88, 5, 36, 163464) That is the challenge of the two dictators.
('74', 88, 6, 37, 163508) 1 Edouard Daladier, then Prime Minister of France
('74', 89, 0, 1, 163558) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 89, 1, 2, 163599) Russia is out of the picture just now.
('74', 89, 1, 3, 163638) Russia has a dictator who dreams of peace and thinks he will wade to it through a sea of blood.
('74', 89, 1, 4, 163734) No one can say what Russian dictatorship will mean to the world.
('74', 89, 1, 5, 163799) It was necessary to give this introduction to what I want to say to the Czechs and through them to all those nationalities which are called ‘small’ or ‘weak’.
('74', 89, 1, 6, 163958) I want to speak to the Czechs because their plight moved me to the point of physical and mental distress and I felt that it would be cowardice on my part not to share with them the thoughts that were welling up within me.
('74', 89, 1, 7, 164180) It is clear that the small nations must either come or be ready to come under the protection of the dictators or be a constant menace to the peace of Europe.
('74', 89, 1, 8, 164338) In spite of all the goodwill in the world England and France cannot save them.
('74', 89, 1, 9, 164417) Their intervention can only mean bloodshed and destruction such as has never been seen before.
('74', 89, 1, 10, 164512) If I were a Czech, therefore, I would free these two nations from the obligation to defend my country.
('74', 89, 1, 11, 164615) And yet I must live.
('74', 89, 1, 12, 164636) I would not be a vassal to any nation or body.
('74', 89, 1, 13, 164683) I must have absolute independence or perish.
('74', 89, 1, 14, 164728) To seek to win in a clash of arms would be pure bravado.
('74', 89, 1, 15, 164785) Not so, if in defying the might of one who would deprive me of my independence I refuse to obey his will and perish unarmed in the attempt.
('74', 89, 1, 16, 164925) In so doing, though I lose the body, I save my soul, i.e., my honour.
('74', 89, 1, 17, 164995) This inglorious peace should be my opportunity.
('74', 89, 1, 18, 165043) I must live down the humiliation and gain real independence.
('74', 89, 1, 19, 165104) But, says a comforter, ‘Hitler knows no pity.
('74', 89, 1, 20, 165150) Your spiritual effort will avail nothing before him.’ My answer is, ‘You may be right.
('74', 89, 1, 21, 165237) History has no record of a nation having adopted non violent resistance.
('74', 89, 1, 22, 165310) If Hitler is unaffected by my suffering, it does not matter.
('74', 89, 1, 23, 165371) For I shall have lost nothing worth [preserving].
('74', 89, 1, 24, 165421) My honour is the only thing worth preserving.
('74', 89, 1, 25, 165467) That is independent of Hitler’s pity.
('74', 89, 1, 26, 165505) But as a believer in non violence, I may not limit its possibilities.
('74', 89, 1, 27, 165575) Hitherto he and his likes have built upon their invariable experience that men yield to force.
('74', 89, 1, 28, 165670) Unarmed men, women and children offering non violent resistance without any bitterness in them will be a novel experience for them.
('74', 89, 1, 29, 165802) Who can dare say that it is not in their nature to respond to the higher and finer forces?
('74', 89, 1, 30, 165893) They have the same soul that I have.’ But says another comforter, ‘What you say is all right for you.
('74', 89, 1, 31, 165995) But how do you expect your people to respond to the novel call?
('74', 89, 1, 32, 166059) They are trained to fight.
('74', 89, 1, 33, 166086) In personal bravery they are second to none
('74', 90, 0, 1, 166130) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 91
('74', 90, 1, 2, 166178) in the world.
('74', 90, 1, 3, 166192) For you now to ask them to throw away their arms and be trained for non violent resistance, seems to me to be a vain attempt.’ ‘You may be right.
('74', 90, 1, 4, 166338) But I have a call I must answer.
('74', 90, 1, 5, 166371) I must deliver my message to my people.
('74', 90, 1, 6, 166411) This humiliation has sunk too deep in me to remain without an outlet.
('74', 90, 1, 7, 166481) I, at least, must act up to the light that has dawned on me.’ This is how I should, I believe, act if I was a Czech.
('74', 90, 1, 8, 166598) When I first launched out on satyagraha, I had no companion.
('74', 90, 1, 9, 166659) We were thirteen thousand men, women and children against a whole nation capable of crushing the existence out of us.
('74', 90, 1, 10, 166777) I did not know who would listen to me.
('74', 90, 1, 11, 166816) It all came as in a flash.
('74', 90, 1, 12, 166843) All the 13,000 did not fight.
('74', 90, 1, 13, 166873) Many fell back.
('74', 90, 1, 14, 166889) But the honour of the nation was saved.
('74', 90, 1, 15, 166929) New history was written by the South African Satyagraha.
('74', 90, 1, 16, 166986) A more apposite instance, perhaps, is that of Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the servant of God as he calls himself, the pride of Afghan as the Pathans delight to call him.
('74', 90, 1, 17, 167159) He is sitting in front of me as I pen these lines.
('74', 90, 1, 18, 167210) He has made several thousands of his people throw down their arms.
('74', 90, 1, 19, 167277) He thinks he has imbibed the lesson of non violence.
('74', 90, 1, 20, 167330) He is not sure of his people.
('74', 90, 1, 21, 167360) Elsewhere I reproduce the pledge that his soldiers of peace make.
('74', 90, 1, 22, 167426) I have come to the Frontier Province, or rather he has brought me, to see with my own eyes what his men here are doing.
('74', 90, 1, 23, 167546) I can say in advance and at once that these men know very little of non violence.
('74', 90, 1, 24, 167628) All the treasure they have on earth is their faith in their leader.
('74', 90, 1, 25, 167696) I do not cite these soldiers of peace as at all a finished illustration.
('74', 90, 1, 26, 167769) I cite them as an honest attempt being made by a soldier to convert fellow soldiers to the ways of peace.
('74', 90, 1, 27, 167875) I can testify that it is an honest attempt, and whether in the end it succeeds or fails, it will have its lessons for satyagrahis of the future.
('74', 90, 1, 28, 168020) My purpose will be fulfilled if I succeed in reaching these men’s hearts and making them see that if their non violence does not make them feel much braver than the possession of arms and the ability to use them they must give up their non violence which is another name for cowardice, and resume their arms which there is nothing but their own will to prevent them from taking back.
('74', 90, 1, 29, 168404) I present Dr. Benes 1 with a weapon not of the weak but of the brave.
('74', 90, 1, 30, 168474) There is no bravery greater than a resolute refusal to bend the knee to an earthly power, no matter how great, and that without
('74', 90, 2, 31, 168602) 1 Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia

('74', 91, 9, 15, 169200) 145. FILTH IN LITERATURE
('74', 91, 10, 16, 169225) A Travancore headmaster of a high school writes:
('74', 91, 11, 17, 169274) You know the political atmosphere of Travancore is very unhappy just at present.
('74', 91, 11, 18, 169355) Even high School pupils are going on strike and picketing others.
('74', 91, 11, 19, 169421) There is feeling among pupils that you are in favour of ‘students’ strikes’ and even ‘pupils’ strikes’.
('74', 91, 11, 20, 169525) I would like to get a communication addressed to pupils in general about your opinion on the matter.
('74', 91, 11, 21, 169626) It will clarify the situation.
('74', 91, 11, 22, 169657) I think I have written often enough against strikes by students and pupils except on the rarest of occasions.
('74', 91, 11, 23, 169767) I hold it to be quite wrong on the part of students and pupils to take part in political demonstrations and party politics.
('74', 91, 11, 24, 169891) Such ferment interferes with serious study and unfits students for solid work as future citizens.
('74', 91, 11, 25, 169989) There is one thing, however, for which it is the duty of students and pupils to strike.
('74', 91, 11, 26, 170077) I have received a letter from the Hon.
('74', 91, 11, 27, 170116) Secretary, Youths’Wel fare Association, Lahore, giving copious specimens of obscene and erotic passages from the text books prescribed by various universi ties.
('74', 91, 11, 28, 170277) They make sickening reading.
('74', 91, 11, 29, 170306) Though they are from prescribed
('74', 92, 0, 1, 170338) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 93
('74', 92, 1, 2, 170386) text books, I would not soil these columns with a reproduction of the extracts.
('74', 92, 1, 3, 170466) I have never come across such filth in all the literature that I have read.
('74', 92, 1, 4, 170542) The extracts are impartially given both [sic] from Sanskrit, Persian and Hindi poets.
('74', 92, 1, 5, 170628) My attention was first drawn to such writings by the girls of Mahila Ashram, Wardha, and recently by my daughter in law 1 who is studying in the Kanya Gurukul at Dehra Dun.
('74', 92, 1, 6, 170801) Though she is not illiterate, she had never come across such obscenity as she found in some of her text books.
('74', 92, 1, 7, 170912) She appealed to me for assistance.
('74', 92, 1, 8, 170947) I have been moving the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan authorities.
('74', 92, 1, 9, 171006) But big institutions move slowly.
('74', 92, 1, 10, 171040) Monopolies grow up.
('74', 92, 1, 11, 171060) Self interest of authors and publishers prevents reform.
('74', 92, 1, 12, 171117) The altar of literature claims incense.
('74', 92, 1, 13, 171157) My daughter in law suggested, and I at once fell in with her sugges tion, that she would risk failure at her examination and omit to learn the obscene or erotic passages.
('74', 92, 1, 14, 171328) This is a mild strike on her part, but a quite good and wholly effective one for herself.
('74', 92, 1, 15, 171418) But this is an occa sion which not only justifies a strrike on the part of students and pupils, it is in my opinion their duty to rise in revolt against such lite rature being forced on them.
('74', 92, 1, 16, 171610) It is one thing to defend the liberty to read what one likes.
('74', 92, 1, 17, 171672) But it is a wholly different thing to force on young minds acquaintance with literature that cannot but excite their animal passions and an un healthy curiosity about things which, in due course and to the extent necessary, they are bound to learn.
('74', 92, 1, 18, 171921) The evil becomes accentuated when it comes in the guise of innocent literature bearing the impri matur of great universities.
('74', 92, 1, 19, 172047) An orderly strike on the part of students is the quickest way of bringing about the much needed reform.
('74', 92, 1, 20, 172151) Such a strike would not be boisterous.
('74', 92, 1, 21, 172190) It would simply consist in the students notifying boycott of examinations which require a study of objectionable literature.
('74', 92, 1, 22, 172315) It is the duty of every pure minded student to rebel against obscenity.
('74', 92, 1, 23, 172387) The Association asks me to appeal to the Congress Ministers to take such steps as may be possible to remove text books or passages which are objectionable.
('74', 92, 1, 24, 172543) I gladly make the appeal hereby not only to them but [to] the Education Ministers in all the provinces.
('74', 92, 1, 25, 172647) Surely all are equally interested in the healthy growth of the student mind.
('74', 92, 2, 26, 172724) PESHAWAR, October 7, 1938
('74', 92, 3, 27, 172750) Harijan, 15 10 1938
('74', 92, 4, 28, 172770) 1 Nirmala Gandhi

('74', 93, 1, 2, 172828) 146. UNCERTIFIED KHADI
('74', 93, 2, 3, 172851) Reports have come to me showing that even responsible Con gressmen use khadi that is sold in uncertified bhandars.
('74', 93, 2, 4, 172966) No khadi is guaranteed pure that is sold in uncertified stores of which unfor tunately there is quite a number, and which has increased since the phenomenal rise given by the A.I.S.A. in the wages of spinners.
('74', 93, 2, 5, 173176) It is not often that workers get better wages without asking.
('74', 93, 2, 6, 173238) And when that happens enough unscrupulous persons will be found who will exploit the poverty or ignorance of the workers, pay them the old low wages, and sell their manufactures at prices lower than those charged under the raised rate of wages.
('74', 93, 2, 7, 173483) Then again, cloth is sold under the name of khadi which has its warp made of mill spun yarn.
('74', 93, 2, 8, 173576) Pure khadi is that khadi which is hand woven out of hand spun yarn and for which wages have been paid according to the A.I.S.A. scale.
('74', 93, 2, 9, 173711) Such khadi can be had only at certified stores.
('74', 93, 2, 10, 173759) Unfortunately Congressmen, out of ignorance or because they do not believe in khadi, buy cheap cloth for make believe at the uncertified stores and thus thwart the Congress policy about khadi and, to the extent of their purchase, defraud the spinners of the rise in the wages.
('74', 93, 2, 11, 174036) Let the public realize that every rise in the price of khadi means at least that much more paid to the spinner, I use ‘at least’ advisedly.
('74', 93, 2, 12, 174176) For the whole of the rise in wages in not charged to the buyers.
('74', 93, 2, 13, 174241) Those Congress leaders who open khadi stores without refe rence to the A.I.S.A. or without being asked by it, certainly harm their own institution, encourage fraud and violate the Congress policy; whereas it should be the duty and pride of every Congressman to help in every way the effort of the A.I.S.A. to better the lot of the most helpless of humanity.

('74', 93, 5, 16, 174645) 147. SEVEN COMPLAINTS
('74', 93, 6, 17, 174667) A Muslim friend writes:
('74', 93, 7, 18, 174691) You will be pained to hear that in my province the matters have gone from bad to worse.
('74', 93, 7, 19, 174779) The Muslims are extremely agitated and invite your immediate attention.
('74', 93, 7, 20, 174851) A Council of Action is formed and we desire to take a leaf from your own book of truth and non violence.
('74', 94, 0, 1, 174956) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 95
('74', 94, 1, 2, 175004) 1. The Government is persisting in the Vidya Mandir Scheme.
('74', 94, 2, 3, 175064) 2. Mother tongue is defined as mother tongue of the area—which is divided into Hindi and Marathi—thus excluding Urdu.
('74', 94, 3, 4, 175182) 3. Urdu schools used to be inspected by Urdu Inspectorate alone; the system is discontinued.
('74', 94, 4, 5, 175275) 4. My amendment to include Urdu or Hindustani in the recognized languages of the Assembly is turned down.
('74', 94, 5, 6, 175381) 5. My University Bill demanding representation for Muslims and Depressed Classes in the university is turned down.
('74', 94, 6, 7, 175496) 6. Hon’ble Biyani held a conference in Chandur in Berar where his procession was taken with music past a mosque during Juma prayers and the flag was worshipped.
('74', 94, 7, 8, 175657) 7. Your title as Mahatma is officially recognized by a Government circular, your birthday declared as a holiday, and consequently the Local Board in Amraoti has issued orders to take your image in a procession and to worship your image.
('74', 94, 7, 9, 175894) Gandhiji, you may permit me to say, we are not idolatrous and we do not recognize you as Mahatma or our religious and political leader.
('74', 94, 7, 10, 176030) Whatever the nature of the complaints, if the correspondent and his followers pursue the path of truth and non violence.
('74', 94, 7, 11, 176151) all will be well, and it will be found at the end of the contemplated action that both the parties have come closer together and that the cobwebs of misunderstanding have all been removed.
('74', 94, 7, 12, 176340) As to the complaints, I must warn the correspondent and others who expect the impossible from me that while I am ever ready to use whatever influence I may possess for the promotion of good and goodwill, I have grave limitations.
('74', 94, 7, 13, 176570) I could not live for two days if I shouldered the burden of investigating every complaint against every Congress Minister.
('74', 94, 7, 14, 176693) For that purpose there is the Parliamentary Sub Committee created by the Working Committee.
('74', 94, 7, 15, 176785) But I can say generally about the complaints as follows: 1. I see nothing wrong in the scheme as far as I know.
('74', 94, 7, 16, 176897) I know that the name ‘mandir’ has been objected to by some Muslims.
('74', 94, 7, 17, 176965) Shuklaji has made it plain that if Muslim boys or their parents object to attend the schools merely because they are called Vidya Mandirs, it would be open to them to attend schools which will bear an Arabic name.
('74', 94, 7, 18, 177179) But surely this is a matter for adjustment.
('74', 94, 7, 19, 177223) The word ‘mandir’ has no exclusive religious significance.
('74', 94, 7, 20, 177282) When it has and qualifying adjective it simply means a house.
('74', 94, 7, 21, 177344) Nor is such use rare.
('74', 94, 7, 22, 177366) 2. I do not know what actually has been done.
('74', 94, 7, 23, 177412) But the mother
('74', 95, 0, 1, 177427) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 95, 1, 2, 177468) tongue of an area is surely the tongue which the inhabitants generally speak.
('74', 95, 1, 3, 177546) 3. If Urdu inspectors have been discontinued because they know only Urdu, on the face of it, it seems to be wrong.
('74', 95, 1, 4, 177661) 4. As to the amendment about the recognition of Urdu or Hindustani, I do not know the merits.
('74', 95, 1, 5, 177755) 5. The same is true of the Bill.

('74', 97, 4, 16, 181336) 151. LOGICAL CONSEQUENCE
('74', 97, 5, 17, 181361) One must feel happy that the danger of war has been averted for the time being.
('74', 97, 5, 18, 181441) Is the price paid likely to be too great?
('74', 97, 5, 19, 181483) Is it likely that honour has been sold?
('74', 97, 5, 20, 181523) Is it a triumph of organized violence?
('74', 97, 5, 21, 181562) Has Herr Hitler discovered a new technique of organizing violence which enables him to gain his end without shedding blood?
('74', 97, 5, 22, 181686) I do not profess to known European politics.
('74', 97, 5, 23, 181731) But it does appear to me that small nationalities cannot exist in Europe with their heads erect.
('74', 97, 5, 24, 181828) They must be absorbed by their larger neighbours.
('74', 97, 5, 25, 181878) They must become vassals.
('74', 97, 5, 26, 181904) Europe has sold her soul for the sake of a seven days’ earthly existence.
('74', 97, 5, 27, 181978) The peace Europe gained at Munich is a triumph of vio lence; it is also its defeat.
('74', 97, 5, 28, 182062) If England and France were sure of victory, they would certainly have fulfilled their duty of saving Czecho slovakia or of dying with it.
('74', 97, 5, 29, 182200) But they quailed before the combined violence of Germany and Italy.
('74', 97, 5, 30, 182268) But what have Germany and Italy gained?
('74', 97, 5, 31, 182308) Have they added anything to the moral wealth of mankind?
('74', 97, 5, 32, 182365) In penning these lines my concern is not with the great powers.
('74', 97, 5, 33, 182429) Their height dazes me.
('74', 97, 5, 34, 182452) Czechoslovakia has a lesson for me and us in India.
('74', 97, 5, 35, 182504) The Czechs could not have done anything else when they found themselves deserted by their two powerful allies.
('74', 97, 5, 36, 182615) And yet I have the hardihood to say that if they had known the use of non violence as a weapon for the defence of national honour, they would have faced the whole might of Germany with that of Italy thrown
('74', 98, 0, 1, 182821) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 99
('74', 98, 1, 2, 182869) They would have spared England and France the humiliation of suing for a peace which was no peace; and to save their honour they would have died to a man without shedding the blood of the robber.
('74', 98, 1, 3, 183065) I must refuse to think that such heroism, or call it restraint, is beyond human nature.
('74', 98, 1, 4, 183153) Human nature will only find itself when it fully realizes that to be human it has to cease to be beastly or brutal.
('74', 98, 1, 5, 183269) Though we have the human form, without the attainment of the virtue of non violence we still share the qualities of our remote reputed ancestor, the orang outang.
('74', 98, 1, 6, 183432) These are not idle words I am writing.
('74', 98, 1, 7, 183471) Let the Czechs know that the Working Committee wrung itself with pain while their doom was being decided.
('74', 98, 1, 8, 183577) 1 The pain was quite selfish in a way.
('74', 98, 1, 9, 183616) But on that account it was the more real.
('74', 98, 1, 10, 183658) For though numerically we are a big nation, in terms of Europe, i.e., in terms of organized scientific violence, we are smaller than Czechoslovakia.
('74', 98, 1, 11, 183807) Our liberty is not merely threatened, we are fighting to regain it.
('74', 98, 1, 12, 183875) The Czechs are fully armed; we are wholly unarmed.
('74', 98, 1, 13, 183926) And so the Committee sat to deliberate what its duty was by the Czechs, what part the Congress was to play if the war cloud burst on us.
('74', 98, 1, 14, 184063) Were we to bargain with England for our liberty and appear to befriend Czechoslovakia, or were we to live up to the creed of non violence and say in the hour of trial for afflicted humanity that, consistently with our creed, we could not associate ourselves with war even though it might ostensibly be for the defence of Czechoslovakia whose very existence was threatened for no fault of hers, or for the only fault that she was too small to defend hereslf single handed?
('74', 98, 1, 15, 184535) The Working Committee had almost come to the conclusion that it would deny itself the opportunity of striking a bargain with England but would make its contribution to the world peace, to the defence of Czechoslovakia and to India’s freedom by declaring to the world by its action that the way to peace with honour did not lie through the mutual slaughter of the innocents, but that it
('74', 98, 2, 16, 184921) 1 The Congress Working Committee’s resolution on Czechoslovakia read: “The Working Committee has been following with great interest the events as they have been developing in Europe.
('74', 98, 2, 17, 185104) It views with great concern the unabashed attempt that is being made by Germany to deprive Czechoslovakia of its independence or reduce it to impotence.” “The Working Committee sends its profound sympathy to the brave people of Czechoslovakia in their struggle to preserve their freedom.
('74', 98, 2, 18, 185392) Being themselves engaged in a war—non violent but none the less grim and exacting—against the greatest Imperialist Power on earth, India cannot but be deeply interested in the protection of Czechoslovak freedom.
('74', 98, 2, 19, 185604) The committee hopes that the better part of humanity will still assert itself and save humanity from the impending catastrophe.”
('74', 99, 0, 1, 185733) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 99, 1, 2, 185775) lay only and truly through the practice of organized non violence even unto death.
('74', 99, 1, 3, 185858) And this was but the logical and natural step the Working Committee could have taken, if it was to prove true to its creed.
('74', 99, 1, 4, 185982) If India could gain her freedom through non violence, as Congressmen are to believe they can, she could also defend her freedom by the same means, and hence a fortiori could a smaller nation like Czecho slovakia.
('74', 99, 1, 5, 186195) I do not know what actually the Working Committe would have done if the war had come.
('74', 99, 1, 6, 186281) But the war is only postponed.
('74', 99, 1, 7, 186312) During the breathing time, I present the way of non violence for acceptance by the Czechs.
('74', 99, 1, 8, 186403) They do not yet know what is in store for them.
('74', 99, 1, 9, 186451) They can lose nothing by trying the way of non violence.
('74', 99, 1, 10, 186508) The fate of Republican Spain is hanging in the balance.
('74', 99, 1, 11, 186564) So is that of China.
('74', 99, 1, 12, 186585) If in the end they all lose, they will do so not because their cause is not just, but because they are less skilled in the science of destruction or because they are undermanned.
('74', 99, 1, 13, 186764) What would Republican Spain gain if it had Franco’s resources, or China if she had Japan’s skill in war, or the Czechs if they had the skill of Herr Hitler?
('74', 99, 1, 14, 186921) I suggest that if it is brave, as it is, to die to a man fighting against odds, it is braver still to refuse to fight and yet to refuse to yield to the usurper.
('74', 99, 1, 15, 187082) If death is a certainty in either case, is it not nobler to die with the breast bared to the enemy without malice against him within?

('74', 102, 4, 6, 190351) 155. TALK TO KHUDAI KHIDMATGARS–I
('74', 102, 5, 7, 190385) [On or before October 15, 1938] 2
('74', 102, 6, 8, 190419) Gandhiji told them that though it sounded to him as an overbold statement for them to make, still, as was his wont, he would take them at their word.
('74', 102, 6, 9, 190569) 3 He explained to them in detail what his conception of the nature and implications of non violence was.
('74', 102, 6, 10, 190674) It was comparatively easy to maintain a passive sort of non violence, when the opponent was powerful and fully armed.
('74', 102, 6, 11, 190792) But would they remain non violent in their dealings amongst themselves and with their own countrymen, when there was no extraneous force to restrain or check them?
('74', 102, 6, 12, 190956) Again, was theirs the non violence of the strong or that of the weak?
('74', 102, 6, 13, 191026) If theirs was the non violence of the strong, they should feel the stronger for their renunciation of the sword.
('74', 102, 6, 14, 191139) But if that was not the case with them, it was better for them to resume their weapons which they had of their own free will discarded.
('74', 102, 6, 15, 191275) For it was much better for them to be brave soldiers in arms than to be disarmed and emasculated.
('74', 102, 6, 16, 191373) He remarked: A charge has been levelled against me and Badshah Khan that we are rendering India and Islam a disservice by presenting the gospel of non violence to the brave and warlike people of the Frontier.
('74', 102, 6, 17, 191582) They say that I have come here to sap your strength.
('74', 102, 6, 18, 191635) The Frontier Province, they say, is the bastion of Islam in India, the Pathans are past masters in the use of the sword and the rifle and mine is an attempt to emasculate them by making them renounce their arms and thus undermine the citadel of the strength and security of Islam.
('74', 102, 6, 19, 191916) I wholly repudiate the charge.
('74', 102, 6, 20, 191947) My faith is that by adopting the doctrine of
('74', 102, 7, 21, 191992) 1 This was a letter addressed to Mahadev Desai from Pipodara.

('74', 119, 1, 2, 220778) 175. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('74', 119, 2, 3, 220806) MARDAN, October 17, 1938 I have two letters from schoolmasters, besides others from lay men, complaining of students’ rowdyism in Travancore.
('74', 119, 2, 4, 220948) The Principal of C.M.S. College, Kottayam, says that the students blocked the pass age of those who wanted to attend the classes.
('74', 119, 2, 5, 221078) They twice turned away girls who did not listen to them.
('74', 119, 2, 6, 221135) They rushed at the classes and made noises, making classes impossible.
('74', 119, 2, 7, 221206) This violent participation by students in a struggle which its authors claim to be absolutely non violent, makes progress difficult, if not impossible.
('74', 119, 2, 8, 221358) So far as I know, the leaders of the movement do not want the students, even if they wish to participate, to depart in any way from the non violent way.
('74', 119, 2, 9, 221511) Obstruction, rowdyism and the like are naked violence.
('74', 119, 2, 10, 221566) I am credited with influence over students.
('74', 119, 2, 11, 221610) If I have any, I would ask them to observe non violence in thought, word and deed.
('74', 119, 2, 12, 221693) If, however, the forces of violence cannot be controlled by those who are in charge of the movement, it may be a question for them whether in the interest of the movement itself it is not wise to suspend civil disobedience.
('74', 119, 2, 13, 221917) I must not presume to lay down the law from this distance, but I do feel from the evidence before me that the leaders would incur grave risk if they allowed students to think that their violence would help the movement or that it is secretly liked by the leaders.
('74', 119, 2, 14, 222181) Harijan, 22 10 1938

('74', 123, 7, 13, 227873) 183. HINDUSTANI, HINDI AND URDU
('74', 123, 8, 14, 227905) It is a great pity that bitter controversy has taken place and still
('74', 123, 9, 15, 227974) continues regarding the Hindi Urdu question.
('74', 123, 9, 16, 228019) So far as the Congress is concerned Hindustani is its recognized official language designed as an all India language for inter provincial contact.
('74', 123, 9, 17, 228166) It is not to supplant but to supplement the provincial languages.
('74', 123, 9, 18, 228232) The recent reso lution of the Working Committee should set all doubt at rest.
('74', 123, 9, 19, 228310) If the Congressmen who have to do all India work will only take the trouble of learning Hindustani in both the scripts, we shall have taken many strides in the direction of our common language goal.
('74', 123, 9, 20, 228509) The real competition is not between Hindi and Urdu but between Hindustani and English.
('74', 123, 9, 21, 228596) It is a tough fight.
('74', 123, 9, 22, 228617) I am certainly watching it with grave concern.
('74', 123, 10, 23, 228664) Hindi Urdu controversy has no bottom.
('74', 123, 10, 24, 228702) Hindustani of the Con 
('74', 123, 11, 25, 228725) gress conception has yet to be crystallized into shape.
('74', 123, 11, 26, 228781) It will not be so long as Congress proceedings are not conducted exclusively in Hin dustani.
('74', 123, 11, 27, 228874) The Congress will have to prescribe the dictionaries for use by Congressmen and a department will have to supply new words out side the dictionaries.
('74', 123, 11, 28, 229024) It is great work, it is work worth doing, if we are really to have a living, growing all India speech.
('74', 123, 11, 29, 229127) The department will have to determine which of the existing literature shall be con sidered as Hindustani, books, magazines, weeklies, dailies, whether written in Urdu script or Devanagari.
('74', 123, 11, 30, 229317) It is serious work needing a vast amount of plodding if it is to achieve success.
('74', 123, 12, 31, 229399) For the purpose of crystallizing Hindustani, Hindi and Urdu
('74', 123, 13, 32, 229459) may be regarded as feeders.
('74', 123, 13, 33, 229487) A Congressman must therefore wish well to both and keep in touch with both so far as he can.
('74', 124, 0, 1, 229580) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 125
('74', 124, 1, 2, 229629) This Hindustani will have many synonyms to supply the varied requirements of a growing nation rich in provincial languages.
('74', 124, 1, 3, 229753) Hindustani spoken to Bengali or Southern audiences will naturally have a large stock of words of Sanskrit origin.
('74', 124, 1, 4, 229867) The same speech deli vered in the Punjab will have a large admixture of words of Arabic or Persian origin.
('74', 124, 1, 5, 229974) Similar will be the case with audiences com posed predominantly of Muslims who cannot understand many words of Sanskrit origin.
('74', 124, 1, 6, 230102) All India speakers will have therefore to command a Hindustani vocabulary which will enable them to feel at home with audiences drawn from all parts of India.
('74', 124, 1, 7, 230261) Pandit Mala viyaji’s name comes uppermost in this connection.
('74', 124, 1, 8, 230323) I have known him handle Hindi speaking and Urdu speaking audiences with equal case.
('74', 124, 1, 9, 230407) I have never found him in want of the correct word.
('74', 124, 1, 10, 230459) The same is true of Babu Bhagwandas who uses synonymous words in the same speech, and he sees to it that it does not lose in grace.
('74', 124, 1, 11, 230591) Among the Muslims at the time of writing I can think of only Maulana Mahomed Ali whose vocabulary was varied enough to suit both audiences.
('74', 124, 1, 12, 230731) His knowledge of Gujarati acquired in Baroda service stood him in good stead.
('74', 124, 1, 13, 230809) Independently of the Congress, Hindi and Urdu will continue to flourish.
('74', 124, 1, 14, 230882) Hindi will be mostly confined to Hindus and Urdu to Mus lims.
('74', 124, 1, 15, 230944) As a matter of fact, comparatively speaking, there are very few Muslims who know Hindi well enough to be called scholars, though, I expect, in Hindi speaking parts, to Muslims born there, Hindi is the mother tongue.
('74', 124, 1, 16, 231160) There are thousands of Hindus whose mother tongue is Urdu and there are hundreds who can be aptly described as Urdu scholars.
('74', 124, 1, 17, 231286) Pandit Motilalji was one such.
('74', 124, 1, 18, 231317) Dr. Tej Bahadur Sapru is another.
('74', 124, 1, 19, 231351) Illustrations can be easily multiplied.
('74', 124, 1, 20, 231391) There is therefore no reason for any quarrel or unhealthy competition between the two sisters.
('74', 124, 1, 21, 231486) Healthy competition there always must be.
('74', 124, 1, 22, 231528) From all accounts I have received it seems that, under the able guidance of Moulvi Saheb Abdul Haq, the Osmania University is ren dering great service to the cause of Urdu.
('74', 124, 1, 23, 231701) The University has a big Urdu lexicon.
('74', 124, 1, 24, 231740) Scientific treatises have been and are being prepared in Urdu.
('74', 124, 1, 25, 231803) And as the teaching is being honestly imparted through Urdu in that University, it must grow.
('74', 124, 1, 26, 231897) And if, owing to unreasoning preju dice today, all Hindi speaking Hindus do not profit by the literature that is growing there, it is their fault.
('74', 124, 1, 27, 232044) But the prejudice has to die.
('74', 124, 1, 28, 232074) For, the present disunion between the communities is, like all diseases, only temporary.
('74', 124, 1, 29, 232163) For good or for ill, the two communities are wedded to
('74', 125, 0, 1, 232218) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 125, 1, 2, 232260) India, they are neighbours, sons of the soil.
('74', 125, 1, 3, 232306) They are destined to die here as they are born here.
('74', 125, 1, 4, 232359) Nature will force them to live in peace if they do not come together voluntarily.
('74', 125, 1, 5, 232441) And as with the Hindus so with the Muslims.
('74', 125, 1, 6, 232485) It is the latter’s loss, if they will not take advantage of the fruits of the humbler labours of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan and the Nagari Pracharini Sabha.
('74', 125, 1, 7, 232642) It is a pity they have not taken note with pride and pleasure of the big (for the Sammelan) step taken by it in defining Hindi as the language spoken in the north by Hindus and Mussalmans and written in Urdu or Devanagari script.
('74', 125, 1, 8, 232872) Thus, so far as the definition is concerned, it answers the Congress definition of Hindustani.
('74', 125, 1, 9, 232967) I know that there are some who dream that there shall be only Urdu or only Hindi.
('74', 125, 1, 10, 233049) I think it will always remain a dream and it is an unholy dream.

('74', 125, 3, 18, 233673) 184. FOREWORD TO “DADABHAI NAOROJI”
('74', 125, 4, 19, 233709) UTMANZAI, October 19, 1938
('74', 125, 5, 20, 233736) It was on 4th September, 1888, that I sailed from Bombay with three letters of introduction, the most precious being for the G. O. M. of India, Dadabhai Naoroji.
('74', 125, 5, 21, 233898) The letter was given by a Maharashtrian doctor, a friend of the family.
('74', 125, 5, 22, 233970) The worthy doctor told me the G. O. M. did not know him personally, in fact he had never even had the darshan of the G. O. M. “But,” said the doctor, “what does it matter?
('74', 125, 5, 23, 234142) Everyone knows him and adores him as India’s great son and champion.
('74', 125, 5, 24, 234211) He has exiled himself for us.
('74', 125, 5, 25, 234241) I claim to know him by his service of India.
('74', 125, 5, 26, 234286) You will see that my letter will serve you just as well as if I had known him personally.
('74', 125, 5, 27, 234376) The fact is, you need no
('74', 126, 0, 1, 234401) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 127
('74', 126, 1, 2, 234450) introduction to him.
('74', 126, 1, 3, 234471) Your being an Indian is sufficient introduction.
('74', 126, 1, 4, 234520) But you are a youngster, untravelled and timid.
('74', 126, 1, 5, 234568) This letter will give you courage enough to go to the G.O.M. and all will be smooth sailing for you.” And so it was.
('74', 126, 1, 6, 234685) When I reached London, I soon found that Indian students had free access to the G.O.M. at all hours of the day.
('74', 126, 1, 7, 234797) Indeed he was in the place of father to every one of them, no matter to which province or religion they belonged.
('74', 126, 1, 8, 234911) He was there to advise and guide them in their difficulties.
('74', 126, 1, 9, 234972) I have always been a hero worshipper.
('74', 126, 1, 10, 235010) And so Dadabhai became real Dada 1 to me.
('74', 126, 1, 11, 235052) The relationship took the deepest root in South Africa.
('74', 126, 1, 12, 235108) For, he was my constant adviser and inspiration.
('74', 126, 1, 13, 235157) Hardly a week passed without a letter from me to him describing the condition of Indians in South Africa.
('74', 126, 1, 14, 235263) And I well remember that whenever there was a reply to be expected, it came without fail in his own handwriting, in his inimitably simple style.
('74', 126, 1, 15, 235408) I never received a typed letter from him.
('74', 126, 1, 16, 235450) And during my visits to England from South Africa I found that he had for office a garret perhaps 8 feet by 6 feet.
('74', 126, 1, 17, 235566) There was hardly room in it for another chair.
('74', 126, 1, 18, 235613) His desk, his chair and the pile of papers filled the room.
('74', 126, 1, 19, 235673) I saw that he wrote his letters in copying ink and press copied them himself.
('74', 126, 1, 20, 235751) I have not read Shri Masani’s sketch.
('74', 126, 1, 21, 235789) But if he has at all done justice to the life so noble and yet so simple, his work needs no introduction from me or anybody else.
('74', 126, 1, 22, 235919) May it be an inspiration to the reader even as Dadabhai living was to me.
('74', 126, 1, 23, 235993) M. K. GANDHI
