('74', 127, 3, 7, 236521) 186. DISCUSSION WITH ABDUL GHAFFAR KHAN [October 19/20, 1938] 1
('74', 127, 4, 8, 236585) An important stage in Gandhiji’s Frontier mission was reached when in his quiet retreat at Utmanzai he devoted two days to confabulate and compare notes with Badshah Khan after his tour of the Khudai Khidmatgars in Peshawar and Mardan districts.
('74', 127, 4, 9, 236831) He asked Badshah Khan: What is your impression?
('74', 127, 4, 10, 236879) How do the Khudai Khidmatgars stand with regard to non violence?
('74', 127, 5, 11, 236944) [A. G. K.] My impression, Mahatmaji, is that as they themselves admitted before us, the other day, they are raw recruits and fall far short of the standard.
('74', 127, 5, 12, 237101) There is violence in their hearts which they have not been able altogether to cast out.
('74', 127, 5, 13, 237189) They have their defects of temper.
('74', 127, 5, 14, 237224) But there is no doubt as to their sincerity.
('74', 127, 5, 15, 237269) Given a chance they can be hammered into shape and I think the attempt is worth while.
('74', 127, 5, 16, 237356) If we could assimilate and put into practice the whole of the doctrine of non violence as you have explained it to us, how much stronger and better off we should be.
('74', 127, 6, 17, 237522) Gandhiji suggested to Badshah Khan that if non violence was to receive a fair trial, the Khudai Khidmatgars must be prepared to go through a rigorous course of training in constructive non violence which he had in mind for them.
('74', 127, 7, 18, 237751) [A. G. K.] My idea, Mahatmaji, is to make Utmanzai into a model village.
('74', 127, 7, 19, 237824) The spinning and weaving centre will serve as a sort of permanent exhibition for the education of the villagers.
('74', 127, 7, 20, 237937) At the home for Khudai Khidmatgars we shall set before us the self sufficiency ideal.
('74', 127, 7, 21, 238023) We shall wear only the clothes that we ourselves pro duced, eat only such fruits and vegetables as we raise there and have a small dairy to provide us with milk.
('74', 127, 7, 22, 238185) We shall deny ourselves what we cannot ourselves produce.
('74', 127, 7, 23, 238243) [G.] Good.
('74', 127, 7, 24, 238254) May I further suggest that the Khudai Khidmatgars should take their due share in the building of the huts too that are to house them?
('74', 127, 8, 25, 238388) 1 From Pyarelal’s report “In the Frontier Province IV” published in Harijan, 12 11 1938
('74', 128, 0, 1, 238476) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 129
('74', 128, 1, 2, 238525) [A. G. K.] That is our idea.
('74', 128, 1, 3, 238554) To train the first batch of workers, Gandhiji suggested that some Khudai Khidmatgars whom Badshah Khan might select might be sent to Wardha, where, besides becoming adepts in the science of khadi, they would also get a grounding in first aid and hygiene, sanitation and village uplift work and in Hindustani.
('74', 128, 1, 4, 238863) They would also be initiated there into the Wardha Scheme of education so that on their return they would be able to take up the work of mass education.
('74', 128, 1, 5, 239016) Gandhiji then said: But your work will not make headway unless you take the lead and yourself become an adept in all these things.
('74', 128, 1, 6, 239147) Lastly, your work will come to nought unless you enforce the rule of punctuality in your retreat.
('74', 128, 1, 7, 239245) There must be a fixed routine and fixed hours for rising and going to bed, for taking meals and for work and rest, and they must be rigorously enforced.
('74', 128, 1, 8, 239398) I attach the greatest importance to punctuality; it is a corollary to non violence.
('74', 128, 2, 9, 239482) They next proceeded to discuss the modus operandi by which the Khudai Khidmatgars, when they had become sure of their non violence, would fulfil their mission of coping with the trans border raids.
('74', 128, 2, 10, 239680) Badshah Khan was of the opinion that the task was rendered infinitely difficult by the presence of the police and the military who were not fully under popular control and whose presence there brought in all the evils of double rule.
('74', 128, 2, 11, 239914) “Either the authorities should whole heartedly co operate with us or they should withdraw the police and the military from one district to begin with, and we shall then undertake to maintain the peace of that district through our Khudai Khidmatgars.” But Gandhiji held a different view.
('74', 128, 2, 12, 240201) He remarked: I frankly confess that I do not expect the authorities whole heartedly to co operate with us.
('74', 128, 2, 13, 240308) They would distrust our ability, if not our motive.
('74', 128, 2, 14, 240360) It is too much to expect them to withdraw the police on trust.
('74', 128, 2, 15, 240423) Non violence is a universal principle and its operation is not limited by a hostile environment.
('74', 128, 2, 16, 240520) Indeed its efficacy can be tested only when it acts in the midst of and in spite of opposition.
('74', 128, 2, 17, 240616) Our non violence would be a hollow thing and nothing worth if it depen ded for its success on the goodwill of the authorities.
('74', 128, 2, 18, 240743) If we can esta blish full control over the people, we shall render the police and the military innocuous.
('74', 128, 3, 19, 240849) And he described to Badshah Khan how during the Bombay riots on the occasion of the Prince of Wales’s visit, the police and the military found their job gone because the Congress immediately regained control and peace was restored.
('74', 128, 4, 20, 241081) [A. G. K.] But the difficulty is that the raiders are mostly bad characters, who have absconded from British India.
('74', 128, 4, 21, 241197) We cannot make contact with them because the authorities won’t permit us or our workers to go into the tribal territory.
('74', 129, 0, 1, 241318) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 129, 1, 2, 241360) [G.] They must, and I tell you they will when we are fully ready.
('74', 129, 1, 3, 241426) But for that we shall need to have a body of Khudai Khidmatgars who are really and truly servants of God, with whom non violence is a living faith.
('74', 129, 1, 4, 241574) Non violence is an active principle of the highest order.
('74', 129, 1, 5, 241632) It is soul force or the power of the godhead within us.
('74', 129, 1, 6, 241688) Imperfect man cannot grasp the whole of that Essence—he would not be able to bear its full blaze—but even an infinitesimal fraction of it, when it becomes active within us, can work wonders.
('74', 129, 1, 7, 241879) The sun in the heavens fills the whole universe with its life giving warmth.
('74', 129, 1, 8, 241956) But if one went too near it, it would consume him to ashes.
('74', 129, 1, 9, 242016) Even so is it with godhead.
('74', 129, 1, 10, 242044) We become godlike to the extent we realize non violence; but we can never become wholly God.
('74', 129, 1, 11, 242137) Non violence is like radium in its action.
('74', 129, 1, 12, 242180) An infinitesimal quantity of it imbedded in a malignant growth, acts continuously, silently, and ceaselessly till it has transformed the whole mass of the diseased tissue into a healthy one.
('74', 129, 1, 13, 242371) Similarly, even a tiny grain of true non violence acts in a silent, subtle, unseen way and leavens the whole society.
('74', 129, 1, 14, 242489) It is self acting.
('74', 129, 1, 15, 242508) The soul persists even after death, its existence does not depend on the physical body.
('74', 129, 1, 16, 242596) Similarly, non violence or soul force too, does not need physical aids for its propagation or effect.
('74', 129, 1, 17, 242698) It acts independently of them.
('74', 129, 1, 18, 242729) It transcends time and space.
('74', 129, 1, 19, 242759) It follows, therefore, that if non violence becomes successfully established in one place, its influence will spread everywhere.
('74', 129, 1, 20, 242888) So long as a single dacoity takes place in Utmanzai, I will say that our non violence is not genuine.
('74', 129, 1, 21, 242990) The basic principle on which the practice of non violence rests is that what holds good in respect of yourself holds good equally in respect of the whole universe.
('74', 129, 1, 22, 243154) All mankind in essence are alike.
('74', 129, 1, 23, 243188) What is, therefore, possible for me is possible for everybody.
('74', 129, 1, 24, 243251) Pursuing further this line of reasoning, I came to the conclusion that if I could find a non violent solution of the various problems that arise in one particular village, the lesson learnt from it would enable me to tackle in a non violent manner all similar problems in India.
('74', 129, 1, 25, 243530) And so I decided to settle down in Sevagram.
('74', 129, 1, 26, 243575) My sojourn in Sevagram has been an education for me.
('74', 129, 1, 27, 243628) My experience with the Harijans has provided me with what I regard as an ideal solution for the Hindu Muslim problem, which does away with all pacts.
('74', 129, 1, 28, 243778) So if you can set things right in Utmanzai your whole problem would be solved.
('74', 129, 1, 29, 243857) Even our relations with the English will be transformed and
('74', 130, 0, 1, 243917) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 131
('74', 130, 1, 2, 243966) purified if we can show to them that we really do not stand in need of the protection for which their police and the army are ostensibly kept.
('74', 130, 2, 3, 244109) But Badshah Khan had a doubt.
('74', 130, 2, 4, 244139) In every village there is an element of self seekers and exploiters who are ready to go to any length in order to serve their selfish ends.
('74', 130, 2, 5, 244279) Would it not be better, Khan Saheb asked, to ignore them altogether or should an attempt be made to cultivate them too.
('74', 130, 2, 6, 244399) [G.] We may ultimately have to leave some of them out, but we may not regard anybody as irreclaimable.
('74', 130, 2, 7, 244502) We should try to understand the psychology of the evil doer.
('74', 130, 2, 8, 244563) He is very often victim of his circumstances.
('74', 130, 2, 9, 244609) By patience and sympathy, we shall be able to win over at least some of them to the side of justice.
('74', 130, 2, 10, 244710) Moreover, we should not forget that even evil is sustained through the co operation, either willing or forced, of good.
('74', 130, 2, 11, 244830) Truth alone is self sustained.
('74', 130, 2, 12, 244861) In the last resort we can curb power of the evil doers to do mischief by with drawing all co operation from them and completely isolating them.
('74', 130, 2, 13, 245005) This in essence is the principle of non violent non co opera tion.
('74', 130, 2, 14, 245072) It follows, therefore, that it must have its roots in love.
('74', 130, 2, 15, 245132) Its object should not be to punish the opponent or to inflict injury upon him.
('74', 130, 2, 16, 245211) Even while non co operating with him, we must make him feel that in us he has a friend and we should try to reach his heart by rendering him humanitarian service whenever possible.
('74', 130, 2, 17, 245392) In fact it is the acid test of non violence that in a non violent conflict there is no rancour left behind, and in the end the enemies are converted into friends.
('74', 130, 2, 18, 245555) That was my experience in South Africa with General Smuts.
('74', 130, 2, 19, 245614) He started by being my bitterest opponent and critic.
('74', 130, 2, 20, 245668) Today he is my warmest friend.
('74', 130, 2, 21, 245699) For eight years we were ranged on opposite sides.
('74', 130, 2, 22, 245749) But during the Second Round Table Conference it was he who stood by me and, in public as well as in private, gave me his full support.
('74', 130, 2, 23, 245884) This is only one instance out of many that I can quote.
('74', 130, 2, 24, 245940) Times change and systems decay.
('74', 130, 2, 25, 245972) But it is my faith that in the result, it is only non violence and things that are based on non vio lence that will endure.
('74', 130, 2, 26, 246096) Nineteen hundred years ago Christianity was born.
('74', 130, 2, 27, 246146) The ministry of Jesus lasted only for three brief years.
('74', 130, 2, 28, 246203) His teaching was misunderstood even during his own time, and today’s Christianity is a denial of his central teaching— “Love your enemy”.
('74', 130, 2, 29, 246341) But what are nineteen hundred years for the spread of the central doctrine of a man’s teaching?
('74', 130, 2, 30, 246437) Six centuries rolled by and Islam appeared on the scene.
('74', 130, 2, 31, 246494) Many Mussalmans will not even allow me to say that Islam, as the word im 
('74', 131, 0, 1, 246568) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 131, 1, 2, 246610) plies, is unadulterated peace.
('74', 131, 1, 3, 246641) My reading of the Koran has convinced me that the basis of Islam is not violence.
('74', 131, 1, 4, 246723) But here again thirteen hundred years are but a speck in the cycle of Time.
('74', 131, 1, 5, 246799) I am convinced that both these great faiths will live only to the extent that their followers imbibe the central teaching of non violence.
('74', 131, 1, 6, 246938) But it is not a thing to be grasped through mere intellect, it must sink into our hearts.
('74', 131, 2, 7, 247028) A Pilgrimage for Peace, pp.
('74', 131, 3, 8, 247056) 187. NOTES
('74', 131, 4, 9, 247067) MR. AND ESQUIRE V. SHRI, MOULVI, MAULANA, JANAB AND THE LIKE
('74', 131, 5, 10, 247128) Some friends told me on my putting ‘Shri’ before ‘Jinnah’ instead of ‘Mr.’ in my statement made before I visited him in Bombay that it must have offended him.
('74', 131, 5, 11, 247287) I demurred and said that if he was offended he would have given me a gentle hint, I would have apologized and used an adjective he liked best.
('74', 131, 5, 12, 247430) The readers will remember, in the heyday of non co operation the terms ‘Mr.’ and ‘Esq.’ were dropped by Congressmen and the nationalist Press, and ‘Shri’ was the title largely used for all irrespective of religion.
('74', 131, 5, 13, 247645) Though the practice has largely fallen into desuetude, I have never given it up.
('74', 131, 5, 14, 247726) But for our bad habit, I was going to say slavish mentality, we would never have used ‘Mr.’ and ‘Esquire’ before or after Indian names.
('74', 131, 5, 15, 247862) In Europe an Englishman never addresses foreigners as ‘Mr.’or ‘Esquire’ but uses the adjectives current in the respective countries.
('74', 131, 5, 16, 247995) Thus Hitler is never called ‘Mr.’, he is ‘Herr’ Hitler.
('74', 131, 5, 17, 248051) Similarly Musso lini is neither ‘Mr.’ nor ‘Herr’, he is ‘Signor’.
('74', 131, 5, 18, 248117) Why we should have dropped our own nomenclature I do not know.
('74', 131, 5, 19, 248180) But a moment’s detachment from the prevailing habit should show us that the use of ‘Mr.’ and ‘Esquire’ before or after Indian names sounds ludicrous.
('74', 131, 5, 20, 248330) I must, however, admit that the use of ‘Shri’ before Muslim names, in these days of mutual suspicion, may not please Muslim friends.
('74', 131, 5, 21, 248463) I have discussed the matter with some Muslim friends.
('74', 131, 5, 22, 248517) They told me the word ‘Moulvi’ was the usual adjective.
('74', 131, 5, 23, 248573) ‘Janab’ I have heard often in the South.
('74', 131, 5, 24, 248614) Anyway I can say that in using ‘Shri’ for Muslim Indian names, I have had no idea except the friendliest.
('74', 131, 5, 25, 248720) When anybody calls me ‘Mr.’ the use of the word jars on me.
('74', 131, 5, 26, 248780) The happiest Hindu usage is ‘ji’ at the end of the name.
('74', 131, 5, 27, 248837) ‘Saheb’ is synonymous
('74', 132, 0, 1, 248859) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 133
('74', 132, 1, 2, 248908) with ‘ji’.
('74', 132, 1, 3, 248919) I remember I always used to address the late Hakim Ajmal khan as Hakimji.
('74', 132, 1, 4, 248993) Some Muslim friend told me that Hakim ‘Saheb’ would be preferred by Muslims.
('74', 132, 1, 5, 249070) I had not known before of any such preference.
('74', 132, 1, 6, 249117) But since the correction, except for inadvertent use of ‘ji’, I always addressed the deceased patriot as Hakim Saheb.
('74', 132, 1, 7, 249235) I could not address him as ‘Mr.’ Ajmalkhan even if somebody deposited five salted canes on the naked back.
('74', 132, 1, 8, 249342) It seems that we become ‘Misters’ and ‘Esquires’ after we receive English education!!!
('74', 132, 1, 9, 249429) Will readers learned in this kind of lore help me and persons like me by giving the uncontaminated usages in vogue in India?
('74', 132, 1, 10, 249554) UTMANZAI, October 20, 1938 Harijan, 29 10 1938

('74', 136, 1, 2, 255550) 193. THE CONFISCATED LANDS
('74', 136, 2, 3, 255577) It would be wrong on my part if I allowed it to be said that the Bill to provide for the restoration of lands forfeited during the Civil Disobedience Movement just passed by the Bombay Legislature, miscalled expropriatory law, would not have been passed if I had my will.
('74', 136, 2, 4, 255849) I must make the confession that I had some hand in the Minis ters’ bringing in the Bill.
('74', 136, 2, 5, 255938) Indeed I felt that any other course would be less than correct.
('74', 136, 2, 6, 256002) Any parley with those who had bought the lands would be either coercion on behalf of the Government or blackmail by the so called owners.
('74', 136, 2, 7, 256140) If it was right to restore the lands to the true owners, it should be done by law.
('74', 136, 2, 8, 256223) If the Government had not the power under the Government of India Act even to pass such an innocent and necessary relief measure, it was worse than the critics had described it to be.
('74', 136, 2, 9, 256407) I hold that the Bombay Bill is more than just.
('74', 136, 2, 10, 256454) The clause providing for compensation to the so called owners to the extent of their outlay plus interest makes it more than just.
('74', 136, 2, 11, 256585) The provable facts about these lands are that they were bought in collusion with the authorities.
('74', 136, 2, 12, 256683) Indeed it was difficult for them to find pur chasers.
('74', 136, 2, 13, 256737) The lands were sold to terrorize the people.
('74', 136, 2, 14, 256782) It was part of the repressive policy, and they were sold in some cases for a song.
('74', 136, 2, 15, 256865) When the Government that resorted to such terrorism gave place to those who were its victims, surely they must be credited with magnanimity when, instead of confiscating the lands purchased collusively and in the teeth of strong and overwhelming popular opposition, they offered compensation.
('74', 136, 2, 16, 257158) Had the fight between the Government and the people been violent instead of non violent, the victorious party coming into power would certainly have restored without compensation all property to the legal possessors forcibly taken away from the rightful owners.
('74', 136, 2, 17, 257420) Surely, the situation could not be altered because the fight was non violent and there was a semblance of legal procedure about the transfers.
('74', 136, 2, 18, 257563) The public should know that the lands were first confiscated by the then Government and when the confiscation did not seem to break the spirit of the fighters, the unworthy means of selling the lands was resorted to.
('74', 136, 2, 19, 257780) But they seemed to be terrified of their own enormity and they desisted from selling further lands.
('74', 136, 2, 20, 257880) I would far rather draw the curtain over the painful past.
('74', 136, 2, 21, 257939) I have raised it just to let
('74', 137, 0, 1, 257968) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 137, 1, 2, 258010) the reader know that the Bombay Government have not been guilty of injustice.
('74', 137, 2, 3, 258088) KOHAT, October 22, 1938 Harijan, 29 10 1938

('74', 139, 7, 15, 261632) 198. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KOHAT 2
('74', 139, 8, 16, 261671) October 22, 1938
('74', 139, 9, 17, 261688) I have given over one hour today to acquaint myself with your difficulties and woes.
('74', 139, 9, 18, 261773) But I confess to you that I am no longer fit to tackle such matters.
('74', 139, 9, 19, 261842) While, on the one hand, old age is slowly creeping over me, on the other my responsibilities are becoming more and more multifarious and there is danger that if I have too many irons in the fire, I may not be able to do justice to the more important of my responsibilities.
('74', 139, 9, 20, 262116) And among these, the responsibility that I have under taken in respect of the Khudai Khidmatgars is the more important, and if I can carry it out to my satisfaction, in collaboration with Khan Saheb, I will feel that my closing years have not been wasted.

('74', 140, 1, 2, 262963) of the soul.

('74', 141, 3, 4, 264447) In the course of his talk before the Khudai Khidmatgar officers at Kohat, he impressed upon them the tremendous nature of the step which they had taken.
('74', 141, 3, 5, 264600) He had often said before that if the Pathan, famed in the world for the prowess of his arms, really took to non violence, renouncing arms, it would be a red letter day in the history of India and the world.
('74', 141, 3, 6, 264807) For good or for ill, the Pathan today has come to be regarded as a bogey man by the average person in India.
('74', 141, 3, 7, 264916) In Gujarat and Kathia war children turn pale at the very mention of the Pathan.
('74', 141, 3, 8, 264996) At Sabarmati Ashram, we try to inculcate fearlessness among the children.

('74', 141, 3, 10, 265221) I have not been able to impress upon our ashram girls that they have no need to fear a Pathan.
('74', 141, 3, 11, 265316) They try to make a show of bravery.
('74', 141, 3, 12, 265352) But it is only a make believe.
('74', 141, 3, 13, 265383) During a communal disturbance they dare not stir out of their homes if there is a report of even a casual Pathan being about.
('74', 141, 3, 14, 265509) They are afraid they would be kidnapped .
('74', 141, 3, 15, 265551) I tell them that even if they are kidnapped they must not be frightened.
('74', 141, 3, 16, 265624) They should appeal to the kidnapper’s sense of honour to behave chivalrously towards one who should be as a sister to him.

('74', 141, 3, 21, 266143) When, therefore, I hear that a body of Khidmatgars has arisen among the Pathans, who have completely renounced violence, I do not know whether to believe it or not.
('74', 141, 3, 22, 266308) What are the implications of renouncing violence and what is the mark of a person who has renounced violence?
('74', 141, 4, 23, 266418) One did not become a Khudai Khidmatgar by adopting that name or by putting on the Khudai Khidmatgar’s uniform, he told them.

('74', 144, 8, 15, 272125) HUNGOO, [October 23, 1938] 1
('74', 144, 9, 16, 272154) Gandhiji referred to an address of welcome that had been presented to him at Nasarat Khel on the way, at the foundation laying ceremony of the Khudai Khidmatgars’ office.
('74', 144, 9, 17, 272325) In it there was a reference to “our last struggle”.
('74', 144, 9, 18, 272377) He remarked: Let me tell you that civil disobedience may come and go, but our non violent struggle for freedom goes on and will continue till Independence is attained.
('74', 144, 9, 19, 272545) Only the form has changed.
('74', 144, 9, 20, 272572) I know that to 90 per cent Indians, non violence means that and nothing else.
('74', 144, 9, 21, 272650) 2 It is good so far.
('74', 144, 9, 22, 272671) There is bravery in it.
('74', 144, 9, 23, 272695) But you and particularly the Khudai Khidmatgar officers must clearly understand that this is not the whole of non violence.
('74', 144, 9, 24, 272819) If you have really understood the meaning of non violence, it should be clear to you that non violence is not a principle or a virtue to be brought into play on a particular occasion or to be practised with reference to a parti cular party or section.
('74', 144, 9, 25, 273071) It has to become a part and parcel of our being.
('74', 144, 9, 26, 273120) Anger should disappear from our hearts altogether, otherwise what is the difference between ourselves and our oppressors?
('74', 144, 9, 27, 273242) Anger may lead
('74', 144, 10, 28, 273257) 1 According to Pyarelal’s report in the Frontier Province III published in Harijan, 5 11 1938, Gandhiji visited Hungoo on October 23, 1938. 2 The address had mentioned that the Khudai Khidmatgars had not been and would never be cowed down by repression.
('74', 145, 0, 1, 273511) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 145, 1, 2, 273553) one person to issue an order to open fire, another to use abusive language, a third one to use the lathi.
('74', 145, 1, 3, 273659) At root it is all the same.
('74', 145, 1, 4, 273687) It is only when you have become incapable of feeling or harbouring anger in your hearts that you can claim to have shed violence or can expect to remain non violent to the end.
('74', 145, 2, 5, 273864) He then proceeded to explain the difference between civil disobedience and satyagraha.
('74', 145, 2, 6, 273951) Our civil disobedience or non co operation, by its very nature, was not meant to be practised for all time.
('74', 145, 2, 7, 274059) But the fight which we are today putting up through our constructive non violence has a validity for all time; it is the real thing.
('74', 145, 2, 8, 274192) Supposing the Government were to cease to arrest civil resisters, our jail going would then stop but that would not mean that our fight is over.
('74', 145, 2, 9, 274337) A civil resister does not go to jail to embarrass the jail authorities by indulging in the breach of jail rules.
('74', 145, 2, 10, 274450) Of course, there can be civil disobedience in jail too.
('74', 145, 2, 11, 274506) But there are definite rules for it.
('74', 145, 2, 12, 274543) The point is that the civil resister’s fight does not end with his imprisonment.
('74', 145, 2, 13, 274624) Once we are inside the prison we become civilly dead so far as the outside world is concerned.
('74', 145, 2, 14, 274719) But inside the prison our fight to convert the hearts of the Government’s bond slaves, i.
('74', 145, 2, 15, 274809) e., the jail officials, just begins.
('74', 145, 2, 16, 274846) It gives us a chance of demonstrating to them that we are not like thieves or dacoits, that we wish them no ill, nor do we want to destroy the opponent but want only to make him our friend, not by servilely obeying all orders, just or unjust— that is not the way to win true friendship—but by showing them that there is no evil in us, that we sincerely wish them well and in our hearts pray that God’s goodness may be upon them.
('74', 145, 2, 17, 275275) My fight continued even when I was lodged behind prison bars.
('74', 145, 2, 18, 275337) I have been several times in prison and every time I have left only friends behind in the jail officials and others with whom I have come in contact.
('74', 145, 2, 19, 275487) It is a speciality of non violence that its action never stops.
('74', 145, 2, 20, 275551) That cannot be said of the sword or the bullet.
('74', 145, 2, 21, 275599) The bullet can destroy the enemy; non violence converts the enemy into a friend and thus enables the civil resister to assimilate to himself the latter’s strength.
('74', 145, 3, 22, 275763) By their civil disobedience struggle, he continued, they had demonstrated to the world their determination no longer to be ruled by the British.
('74', 145, 3, 23, 275908) But they had now to give proof of valour of another and higher type.
('74', 145, 3, 24, 275977) During the Khilafat days tall, hefty Pathan soldiers used to come and meet the Ali Brothers and himself secretly.
('74', 145, 3, 25, 276091) They used to tremble at the thought of their visit being discovered by their superior officers and resulting in their dismissal from service.
('74', 145, 3, 26, 276233) In spite of their tall stature and
('74', 146, 0, 1, 276268) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 147
('74', 146, 1, 2, 276317) physical strength they used to cower and become servile when confronted by a person physically stronger than they.
('74', 146, 1, 3, 276432) I want strength which will enable me to submit to none but God, my sole Lord and Master.
('74', 146, 1, 4, 276521) It is only when I can do that, that I can claim to have realized non violence.
('74', 146, 2, 5, 276600) He then proceeded to expatiate on another speciality of non violence, viz., one need not go to a school or a pir or a guru to learn its use.
('74', 146, 2, 6, 276741) Its virtue lay in its simplicity.
('74', 146, 2, 7, 276775) If they realized that it was the most active principle that worked all the twenty four hours without rest or remission, they would look for opportunities for its application in their homes, in the streets, in relation to their foes no less than friends.
('74', 146, 2, 8, 277029) They could begin to practise it in their homes from that very day.
('74', 146, 2, 9, 277096) He had disciplined himself sufficiently never to feel angry with the enemy, but he confessed that he sometimes lost temper with friends.
('74', 146, 2, 10, 277233) Such discipline in non violence as he had, he told them, he had at home from his wife.
('74', 146, 2, 11, 277320) And with that he unfolded in poignant detail, a chapter of his domestic life.
('74', 146, 2, 12, 277398) He used to be a tyrant at home, he said.
('74', 146, 2, 13, 277439) His tyranny was the tyranny of love.
('74', 146, 2, 14, 277476) I used to let loose my anger upon her.
('74', 146, 2, 15, 277515) But she bore it all meekly and uncomplainingly.
('74', 146, 2, 16, 277563) I had a notion that it was her duty to obey me, her lord and master, in everything.
('74', 146, 2, 17, 277647) But her unresisting meekness opened my eyes and slowly it began to dawn upon me that I had no such prescriptive right over her.
('74', 146, 2, 18, 277775) If I wanted her obedience, I had first to persuade her by patient argument.
('74', 146, 2, 19, 277851) She thus became my teacher in non violence.
('74', 146, 2, 20, 277895) And I dare say, I have not had a more loyal and faithful comrade in life.
('74', 146, 2, 21, 277969) I literally used to make life a hell for her.
('74', 146, 2, 22, 278015) Every other day I would change my residence, prescribe what dress she was to wear.
('74', 146, 2, 23, 278098) She had been brought up in an orthodox family where untou chability was observed.
('74', 146, 2, 24, 278180) Muslims and untouchables used to frequent our house.
('74', 146, 2, 25, 278233) I made her serve them all regardless of her innate reluc tance.
('74', 146, 2, 26, 278297) But she never said ‘no’.
('74', 146, 2, 27, 278322) She was not educated in the usual sense of the term and was simple and unsophisticated.
('74', 146, 2, 28, 278410) Her guileless simplicity conquered me completely.
('74', 146, 2, 29, 278460) You have all wives, mothers and sisters at home.
('74', 146, 2, 30, 278509) You can take the lesson of non violence from them.
('74', 146, 2, 31, 278560) You must, besides, take the vow of truth, ask yourselves how dear truth is to you and how far you observe it in thought, word and deed.
('74', 146, 2, 32, 278696) A person who is not truthful is far away from non violence.
('74', 146, 2, 33, 278756) Untruth itself is violence.
('74', 146, 3, 34, 278784) Referring to the month of Ramzan that had just set in, he told them how it could be used to make a start in non violence.
('74', 146, 3, 35, 278906) We seem to think that the observance of Ramzan begins and ends with abstention from food and drink.
('74', 146, 3, 36, 279006) We think nothing of losing
('74', 147, 0, 1, 279033) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('74', 147, 1, 3, 279152) If there is the slightest delay in serving the repast at the time of the breaking of the fast, the poor wife is hauled over live coals.
('74', 147, 1, 4, 279288) I do not call it observing the Ramzan, but its travesty.
('74', 147, 1, 5, 279345) If you really want to cultivate non violence, you should take a pledge that come what may, you will not give way to anger or order about members of your household or lord it over them.
('74', 147, 1, 6, 279530) You can thus utilize trifling little occa sions in everyday life to cultivate non violence in your own person and teach it to your children.
('74', 147, 2, 7, 279671) He took another instance.
('74', 147, 2, 8, 279697) Suppose somebody hit their child with a stone.
('74', 147, 2, 9, 279744) Usually the Pathan tells his child not to return home to whine but to answer back with a bigger stone.
('74', 147, 2, 10, 279847) But a votary of non violence, said Gandhiji, would tell his child not to meet a stone by a stone but by embracing the boy who threw the stone and making friends with him.
('74', 147, 2, 11, 280018) The same formula, i.
('74', 147, 2, 12, 280039) e., to banish anger completely from the heart and to make everybody into one’s friend, is indeed enough to win India her independence.
('74', 147, 2, 13, 280174) It is the surest and the quickest way, too, and it is my claim that for winning Independence for the poor masses of India, it is the only way.

('74', 147, 4, 15, 280345) 204. THE NATIONAL FLAG
('74', 147, 5, 16, 280368) Here is a letter from a correspondent:
('74', 147, 6, 17, 280407) It has become a far too common occurrence and therefore deserving of notice at your hands to set up the national tri coloured flag in such a manner as to indicate rivalry with or predominance over the religious flags and other symbols exhibited on occasions of religious worship and festivities.
('74', 147, 6, 18, 280703) While we all desire that the national flag should be a symbol of unity and determination to achieve uninterrupted progress in all directions, we should be undoing this very purpose by trying to make rivalry between the national flag and other flags and symbols connected with religion which should predominate on occasions of religious ceremony.
('74', 147, 6, 19, 281049) The enthusiasm of some of our workers leads them to error in this respect and in fact to develop an opposition in some quarters to the national flag which did not exist before.
('74', 147, 7, 20, 281226) Sometimes, again, private interests and factions seek to make use of the national feeling in respect of the flag and exploit it for their own purposes by mixing up a quarrel with the national flag and confusing the issues in regard to incidents.
('74', 147, 8, 21, 281472) It seems as if ever so many of the movements for which you were
('74', 148, 0, 1, 281536) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 149
('74', 148, 1, 2, 281585) responsible are liable to be misconstrued and misdirected, unless you are always ready to re explain, re interpret and prevent misdirection.
('74', 148, 1, 3, 281726) I particularly fear the consequences of doing anything to create a rivalry between the national flag and the religious symbols of either Hindus or Mussalmans or of others.
('74', 148, 1, 4, 281898) The tendency of setting up the national flag on temple cars and temple towers offends my sense of the universality of religion and the incongruity of trying to nationalize God.
('74', 148, 1, 5, 282075) As the author of the idea of a national flag and its make up which in essence the present flag represents, I have felt grieved how the flag has been often abused and how it has even been used to cover violence.
('74', 148, 1, 6, 282286) The flag has been designed to represent non violence ex pressed through real communal unity and non violent labour which the lowliest and highest can easily undertake with the certain prospect of making substantial and yet imperceptible addition to the wealth of the country.
('74', 148, 1, 7, 282562) But today it must be confessed that from that standpoint it is merely a piece of tricolour cloth not always khadi and is not proud of [sic] and a living emblem of communal unity and equalizing labour in which all participate.
('74', 148, 1, 8, 282788) The spinning wheel does hum in thousands of village huts.
('74', 148, 1, 9, 282846) But compared to what should be, the result is poor.
('74', 148, 2, 10, 282898) Moreover the national flag, if it is a symbol of non violence must also mean humility.
('74', 148, 2, 11, 282985) If I had my way I would not exhibit it at any meeting which is not a purely Congress meeting if a single person objects to it.
('74', 148, 2, 12, 283112) The dignity of the flag cannot be lowered by yielding even to a single objector at a non Congress meeting.
('74', 148, 2, 13, 283219) Its dignity will be lowered when it is hauled down for fear of the power we want to oust.
('74', 148, 2, 14, 283309) The dignity will be still more lowered when we exhibit it at meetings or on Congress offices though we have no living faith in communal unity and the spinning wheel with all its implications.
('74', 148, 2, 15, 283501) Since the flag is not a religious symbol and represents and reconciles all religions, in religious processions, or temples or religious gatherings it has no place.
('74', 148, 2, 16, 283665) Everything has its value when it is in its place.
('74', 148, 2, 17, 283715) It has none when it is out of its place.
('74', 148, 2, 18, 283756) Bullion and banknotes have no value whatsoever in the desert of Sahara.
('74', 148, 2, 19, 283828) Indeed in the present state of tension, I would not hoist it on Government buildings or municipal offices unless it is accepted not merely by an overwhelming vote but unanimously.
('74', 148, 2, 20, 284008) I have no hesitation in saying that even one vote cast against it, maybe mischievously, should have its weight, if the flag is a symbol of non violence and humility.

('74', 151, 6, 14, 288374) 208. WOMAN’S SPECIAL MISSION
('74', 151, 7, 15, 288403) THE EDITOR, Harijan Sir, I have read your articles on the recent European crisis with great joy.
('74', 151, 7, 16, 288500) It was only natural that you should speak to Europe now.
('74', 151, 7, 17, 288557) How could you restrain yourself when humanity was on the very verge of destruction?
('74', 151, 8, 18, 288641) Will the world listen?
('74', 151, 8, 19, 288664) That is the question.
('74', 151, 9, 20, 288686) There is no doubt—judging from letters from friends in England—that people there went through absolute agony during that ghastly week.
('74', 151, 9, 21, 288821) I am sure the same applies to the whole world.
('74', 151, 9, 22, 288868) The mere thought of war—modern warfare—with its devilish ingenuity and consequent pitiless butchery and bestiality—definitely made people think as they had never thought before.
('74', 151, 9, 23, 289046) “The sigh of relief that was breathed and the gratitude to God that went up from every heart when the news came through that war had been averted are something that I can never forget as long as I live,” writes an English friend.
('74', 151, 9, 24, 289276) And yet is it just the fear of unspeakable suffering, the dread of losing one’s nearest and dearest, of seeing one’s country humiliated, that cause one to detest war?
('74', 151, 9, 25, 289443) Are we glad war has been averted even at the humiliation of another nation?
('74', 151, 9, 26, 289519) Would we have felt differently if the sacrifice of honour had been demanded of us?
('74', 151, 9, 27, 289602) Do we hate war because we realize it is the wrong way to settle disputes or is our hatred of it part and parcel of our fear?
('74', 151, 9, 28, 289727) These are questions
('74', 151, 10, 29, 289747) 1 Addressee’s mother
('74', 152, 0, 1, 289768) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 153
('74', 152, 1, 2, 289817) that must be answered in the right way if war is really to vanish from the earth.
('74', 152, 1, 3, 289899) The crisis over, however, what do we see?
('74', 152, 1, 4, 289941) A more strenuous race than before for armaments, a more comprehensive and intensive organization than ever of all the resources available—of men, women, money, skill and talent— in the event of war !
('74', 152, 1, 5, 290141) No avowed declaration that “War shall not be” from anywhere!
('74', 152, 1, 6, 290202) Is this not a recognition that war —however averted today—is still hanging over our heads as the proverbial sword of Damocles?
('74', 152, 1, 7, 290329) To me, as a woman, it is painful to realize that my sex has not contributed to world peace the quota that should be ours by instinct and prerogative to contribute.
('74', 152, 1, 8, 290493) It pains me to read and hear of women’s auxiliary corps being organized, of women being commandeered and volunteering to take their full share in the actual field as well as behind the lines.
('74', 152, 1, 9, 290685) And yet, when war comes, it is the women’s hearts that are wrung in agony—it is their souls that are scarred beyond repair.
('74', 152, 1, 10, 290809) It is all so inexplicable.
('74', 152, 1, 11, 290836) Why is it that we have not chosen the better part through all the ages?
('74', 152, 1, 12, 290908) Why have we, without murmur, bowed the knee to hideous, soulless, brute force?
('74', 152, 1, 13, 290987) It is a sad commentary on our spiritual development.
('74', 152, 1, 14, 291040) We have failed to understand our high calling.
('74', 152, 1, 15, 291087) I am quite convinced that if women could only have a heart understanding of the power and glory of non violence all would be well with the world.
('74', 152, 1, 16, 291233) Why cannot you inspire and organize us, women of India?
('74', 152, 1, 17, 291289) Why will you not concentrate on having us as your “sword arm”?
('74', 152, 1, 18, 291352) How often have I longed for you to undertake an all India tour just for this purpose?
('74', 152, 1, 19, 291438) I believe that you would have a wonderful response, for the heart of Indian womanhood is sound and no women, perhaps in the world, have finer traditions of sacrifice and self effacement behind them as we.
('74', 152, 1, 20, 291643) Perhaps if you would make something of us we may, in however humble a manner, beable to show the way of peace to a sorrowing and stricken world.
('74', 152, 1, 21, 291788) Who knows?
('74', 152, 1, 22, 291799) 22 10 1938 A WOMAN I publish this letter not without hesitation.
('74', 152, 1, 23, 291864) The correspondent’s faith in my ability to stir the woman heart flatters me.
('74', 152, 1, 24, 291941) But I am humble enough to recognize my limitations.
('74', 152, 1, 25, 291993) It seems to me that the days of my touring are over.

('74', 154, 12, 21, 294822) 212. SPEECH AT BANNU 1
('74', 154, 13, 22, 294845) October 25, 1938
('74', 154, 14, 23, 294862) Perhaps you know that for over two months I have been observing complete silence.
('74', 154, 14, 24, 294944) I have benefited by it, and I believe it has benefited the country too.
('74', 154, 14, 25, 295016) The silence was originally taken in answer to an acute mental distress, but subsequently I decided to prolong it
('74', 154, 15, 26, 295129) 1At the meeting, which was largely attended, addresses of welcome to Gandhiji were presented by the Bannu District Congress Committee and the Seva Samiti, Chandni Chowk.
('74', 154, 15, 27, 295299) The report of the speech was also published in The Hindustan Times and The Bombay Chronicle.
('74', 155, 0, 1, 295392) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 155, 1, 2, 295434) indefinitely on its own merits.
('74', 155, 1, 3, 295466) It has served me as a wall of protection and enabled me to cope with my work better than before.
('74', 155, 1, 4, 295563) When I came to this province, I had resolved to relax my silence only for the purpose of having talks with the Khudai Khidmatgars, but I had to yield to Khan Saheb’s pressure.
('74', 155, 1, 5, 295739) Your addresses have eulogized me and thanked me for having come here.
('74', 155, 1, 6, 295809) I do not think I deserve any praise or thanks.
('74', 155, 1, 7, 295856) I know that I can do very little to satisfy your expectations.
('74', 155, 1, 8, 295919) My visit to the Frontier Province is purely to meet the Khudai Khidmatgars and know for myself their understanding of non violence.
('74', 155, 1, 9, 296051) Visit to your town is a by product.
('74', 155, 1, 10, 296087) I gave many hours today seeing deputations and studying papers presented to me.
('74', 155, 1, 11, 296167) The recent raid of Bannu and the happenings during the raid have touched me deeply.
('74', 155, 1, 12, 296251) This province is peculiarly placed, and is different from the other provinces inasmuch as on one side it is surrounded by a number of border tribes containing men whose profession is raiding.
('74', 155, 1, 13, 296443) So far as I have been able to know they are not actuated by communal considerations.
('74', 155, 1, 14, 296528) The raiders’ motive seems to be satisfaction of primary needs.
('74', 155, 1, 15, 296591) That the Hindus are more often their victims is probably due to the fact that they generally possess more money.
('74', 155, 1, 16, 296704) The kidnappings too appear to have the same motive.
('74', 155, 1, 17, 296756) Continuation of the raids is in my opinion a proof of British failure in this part of India.
('74', 155, 1, 18, 296849) Their Frontier policy has cost the country crores of rupees and thousands of lives have been sacrificed.
('74', 155, 1, 19, 296954) The brave tribesmen still remain unsubdued.
('74', 155, 1, 20, 296998) If all the accounts I have heard today are substantially correct, and I believe they are, life and property are not secure in most parts of the province.
('74', 155, 1, 21, 297152) A number of people whose relations or dear ones have either been killed or kidnapped and held to ransom by the raiders, saw me today.
('74', 155, 1, 22, 297286) As I listened to the harrowing tales of distress my heart went out to them in sympathy.
('74', 155, 1, 23, 297374) But I must confess to you that with all the will in the world, I possess no magic spell by which I could restore them to their families.
('74', 155, 1, 24, 297511) Nor should you expect much from the Govern ment or the Congress ministry.
('74', 155, 1, 25, 297585) No Government can afford, and the present British Government lacks even the will, to mobilize its military resources every time one of its subjects is kidnapped, unless the person kidnapped happens to belong to the ruling race.
('74', 155, 1, 26, 297813) After studying all the facts I have gained the impression that the situation in respect of border raids has grown worse since the
('74', 156, 0, 1, 297943) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 157
('74', 156, 1, 2, 297992) inauguration of Congress Government.
('74', 156, 1, 3, 298029) The Congress Ministers have no effective control over the police, none over the military.
('74', 156, 1, 4, 298119) The Con gress ministry in this province has less than the others.
('74', 156, 1, 5, 298185) I therefore feel that unless Dr. Khan Saheb can cope with the question of the raids it might be better for him to tender his resignation.
('74', 156, 1, 6, 298323) There is danger of the Congress losing all prestige in this province if the raids continue to increase.
('74', 156, 1, 7, 298427) Apart from my opinion, you have to say for yourselves whether in spite of the handicaps I have mentioned, you would rather have the Congress ministry or some other.
('74', 156, 1, 8, 298592) After all, the Prime Minister is your servant.
('74', 156, 1, 9, 298639) He holds office under the triple sufferance of his electorate, the Provincial Congress Committee and the Working Committee.
('74', 156, 1, 10, 298763) Some of those who met me today asked me if they could seek safety by migrating from the Frontier Province.
('74', 156, 1, 11, 298870) I have told them that migration is a perfectly legitimate course to adopt when there is no other way of living with safety and honour.
('74', 156, 1, 12, 299005) A complaint has further been brought to me that the Muslim populations in the affected places no longer give help against the raiders which they used to formerly, before certain sections of Frontier Crime Regulation Act were repea led, and that has encouraged the raiders.
('74', 156, 1, 13, 299278) While that may be true, let me warn you that if you depend for your protection on the armed assistance of others you must be prepared sooner or later to accept the domination of these defenders.
('74', 156, 1, 14, 299473) Of course you are entitled to learn the art of defending yourselves with arms.
('74', 156, 1, 15, 299552) You must develop a sense of co operation.
('74', 156, 1, 16, 299594) In no case should you be guilty of cowardice Self defence is everybody’s birthright.
('74', 156, 1, 17, 299679) I do not want to see a single coward in India.
('74', 156, 1, 18, 299726) The fourth alternative is that of non violent approach which I am here before you to suggest.
('74', 156, 1, 19, 299820) It is the surest and infallible method of self defence.
('74', 156, 1, 20, 299876) If I had my way, I would go and mix with tribes, and argue it out with them and I am sure they would not be impervious to the argument of love and reason.
('74', 156, 1, 21, 300031) But I know today that door is shut to me.
('74', 156, 1, 22, 300073) The Government won’t permit me to enter the tribal territory.
('74', 156, 1, 23, 300135) The tribesman cannot be the bogey man that he is represented to be.
('74', 156, 1, 24, 300203) He is a human just like you and me and capable of responding to the human touch which has hitherto been conspicuous by its absence in dealing with him.
('74', 156, 1, 25, 300355) A number of Waziris came and saw me today at noon.
('74', 156, 1, 26, 300406) I did not find that their nature was essentially different from human nature elsewhere.
('74', 157, 0, 1, 300494) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 157, 1, 2, 300536) Man’s nature is not essentially evil.
('74', 157, 1, 3, 300574) Brute nature has been known to yield to the influence of love.
('74', 157, 1, 4, 300637) You must never despair of human nature.
('74', 157, 1, 5, 300677) You are a community of traders.
('74', 157, 1, 6, 300709) Do not leave out of your traffic that noblest and most precious of merchandise, viz., love.
('74', 157, 1, 7, 300801) Give to the tribesmen all the love that you are capable of, and you will have theirs in return.
('74', 157, 1, 8, 300897) To seek safety by offering blackmail or ransom to the raiders would be a direct invitation to them to repeat their depredations and will be demoralizing alike to the giver and the tribesmen.
('74', 157, 1, 9, 301088) Instead of offering them money, the rational course would be to raise them above penury by teaching them industry and thereby removing the principal motive that leads them into the raiding habit.
('74', 157, 1, 10, 301284) I am having talks with Khudai Khidmatgars in this connection and evolving a plan in collaboration with Khan Saheb.
('74', 157, 1, 11, 301399) If the plan bears fruit, and the Khudai Khidmatgars truly become what their name signifies, the influence of their example like the sweet fragrance of the rose will spread to the tribes and might provide a permanent solution of the Frontier question.

('74', 157, 2, 13, 301669) 213. TALK TO KHUDAI KHIDMATGARS
('74', 157, 3, 14, 301701) BANNU, [On or before October 26, 1938] 1
('74', 157, 4, 15, 301742) Gandhiji explained the difference between non violence of the strong and non violence of the weak and the difference between constructive work, taken up as a philanthropic activity or as a political expedient, and constructive work linked to non violence, when it becomes an emancipative force with tremendous potency.
('74', 157, 4, 16, 302061) He recalled how the movement of non violence was launched in India.
('74', 157, 4, 17, 302129) Millions at that time felt that they would not be able to fight the British Government with the sword as the latter was infinitely better armed.
('74', 157, 4, 18, 302274) He told them that even if they went forth to fight, sword in hand, they had to be ready to face death.
('74', 157, 4, 19, 302377) If the sword broke in their hand, death would be a certainty.
('74', 157, 4, 20, 302439) Why should not they then learn the art of dying without killing and pit against the enemy the strength of their spirit?
('74', 157, 4, 21, 302559) The Government might imprison them or confiscate their property or even kill them.
('74', 157, 4, 22, 302642) What did it matter?
('74', 157, 4, 23, 302662) The argument went home.
('74', 157, 4, 24, 302686) But in their heart of hearts, said Gandhiji, many had the feeling that if only they had sufficient armed strength they would resort to fighting.
('74', 157, 4, 25, 302831) They accepted non violence because there was nothing else.
('74', 157, 4, 26, 302890) In other words, there was violence in the heart.
('74', 157, 4, 27, 302939) Only it was given up in action.
('74', 157, 4, 28, 302971) It was non violence of the weak, not of the brave.
('74', 157, 4, 29, 303022) Even so it had made them stronger.
('74', 157, 5, 30, 303057) 1 Gandhiji left Bannu on October 26.
('74', 158, 0, 1, 303094) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 159
('74', 158, 1, 2, 303143) was there to tell them that it was a big mistake to regard non violence as a weapon of the weak or to adopt it as such.
('74', 158, 1, 3, 303263) If the Khudai Khidmatgars fell into that mistake, it would be a tragedy.
('74', 158, 1, 4, 303336) If you give up the sword at Badshah Khan’s word, but retain it in your hearts, your non violence will be a short lived thing—not even a nine days’ wonder.
('74', 158, 1, 5, 303491) After a few years you will want to revert to it but, maybe, you will then find that you have got out of the habit and are lost to both the ideals.
('74', 158, 1, 6, 303638) Nothing will, in that event, remain to you but vain regret.
('74', 158, 1, 7, 303698) What I want of you is a unique thing, i.
('74', 158, 1, 8, 303739) e., that you will disdain to use the sword although you have got the capacity and there is no doubt as to victory.
('74', 158, 1, 9, 303854) Even if the opponent is armed with a broken sword, you will oppose your neck to it.
('74', 158, 1, 10, 303938) And this, not with anger or retaliation in your hearts but only love.
('74', 158, 1, 11, 304008) If you have really understood non violence in this sense, you will never want to use the sword because you will have got something infinitely superior in its place.
('74', 158, 1, 12, 304173) You will ask, ‘How will all this have any effect on the British Government?’ My reply is that by uniting all the people of India in a common bond of love through our selfless service, we can transform the atmosphere in the country so that the Britisher will not be able to resist it.
('74', 158, 1, 13, 304457) You will say that the Britisher is impervious to love.
('74', 158, 1, 14, 304512) My thirty years’ unbroken experience is to the contrary.
('74', 158, 1, 15, 304569) Today 17,000 English men can rule over three hundred millions of Indians because we are under a spell of fear.
('74', 158, 1, 16, 304680) If we learn to love one another, if the gulf between Hindu and Muslim, caste and outcaste, and rich and poor, is obliterated, a handful of English would not dare to continue their rule over us.
('74', 158, 1, 17, 304874) Just as there are laws of armed warfare, there are laws of non violent warfare too.
('74', 158, 1, 18, 304958) They have not been fully discovered.
('74', 158, 1, 19, 304995) Under violence you punish the evil doer, in non violence you pity him, and regard him as a patient to be cured by your love.
('74', 158, 1, 20, 305120) What must you do then to drive out the British by the non vio lent method?
('74', 158, 1, 21, 305195) If you want to adopt the method of violence, you have to learn to drill and to become adept in the use of arms.
('74', 158, 1, 22, 305307) In Europe and America even women and children are given that training.
('74', 158, 1, 23, 305378) Simi larly those who have adopted the weapon of non vio lence have to put themselves through a vigorous discipline in non violence.
('74', 158, 2, 24, 305510) And with that he came to the constructive programme and its place in the scheme of non violence as a dynamic force.
('74', 158, 2, 25, 305626) He had placed the programme of non violence before the country in 1920, he explained.
('74', 158, 2, 26, 305712) It was divided into two parts, non co operation and constructive programme.
('74', 158, 2, 27, 305788) The latter included establishment of
('74', 159, 0, 1, 305825) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 159, 1, 2, 305867) communal unity, abolition of untouchability, prohibition, complete eradication of the drink and drug evil and propagation of khadi, hand spin ning, hand weaving and other cottage industries.
('74', 159, 1, 3, 306058) But all these things had to be taken up not as a political expediency but as an integral part of the programme of non violence.
('74', 159, 1, 4, 306186) This last made all the difference.
('74', 159, 1, 5, 306221) For instance, Hindu Muslim unity regarded as an expedient was one thing and quite another when adopted as an integral part of non violence.
('74', 159, 1, 6, 306361) The former, by its very nature, cannot be lasting.
('74', 159, 1, 7, 306412) It will be discarded as soon as the political exigency that suggested it is over.

('74', 159, 1, 9, 306532) When it is taken up as a part of the programme of non violence it will have nothing but love at its root and will be sealed with one’s heart’s blood.
('74', 159, 1, 10, 306682) In the same way the charkha or the spinning wheel had to be linked to non violence.
('74', 159, 1, 11, 306766) Today there are millions of unemployed destitute in India.
('74', 159, 1, 12, 306825) One way to deal with them is to allow them to die off so that, as in South Africa, there might be more per capita land for the survivors.
('74', 159, 1, 13, 306963) That would be the way of violence.
('74', 159, 1, 14, 306998) The other way, the way of non violence, is based on the principle of ‘even unto this last’.
('74', 159, 1, 15, 307090) It requires us to have equal regard for the least of God’s creation.
('74', 159, 1, 16, 307159) A votary of this path will deny to himself what cannot be shared with the least.
('74', 159, 1, 17, 307240) That applies even to those who labour with their hands—the relatively better off among the labouring class must seek to align themselves with the less fortunate.
('74', 159, 2, 18, 307402) It was this line of thinking, said Gandhiji, which had led to the discovery of the charkha on his part.
('74', 159, 2, 19, 307506) I had not even seen a charkha when I first advocated its use.
('74', 159, 2, 20, 307568) In fact I called it a handloom in Hind Swaraj, not knowing a spin ning wheel from a handloom.
('74', 159, 2, 21, 307662) I had before my mind’s eye the poor, landless labourer without employment or means of subsistence, crus hed under the weight of poverty.
('74', 159, 2, 22, 307799) How could I save him—that was my problem.
('74', 159, 2, 23, 307841) Even now while I am sitting with you in these comfortable surroundings, my heart is with the poor and the oppressed in their humble cottages.
('74', 159, 2, 24, 307983) I would feel more at home in their midst.
('74', 159, 2, 25, 308025) If I allowed myself to succumb to the love of ease and comfort, it would be my undoing as a votary of ahimsa.

('74', 159, 2, 29, 308390) For instance, if I am a doctor, while I draw the sacrificial thread it will make me think how I can assuage the suffering of the destitute

('74', 160, 1, 2, 308578) instead of the royalty in rich palaces with the prospect of fat fees.

('74', 161, 2, 3, 310685) October 26, 1938
('74', 161, 3, 4, 310702) I am here to tell you, with fifty years’ experience of non vio lence at my back, that it is an infinitely superior power as compared to brute force.
('74', 161, 3, 5, 310851) An armed soldier relies on his weapons for his strength.
('74', 161, 3, 6, 310908) Take away from him his weapons—his gun or his sword, and he generally becomes helpless.
('74', 161, 3, 7, 310996) But a person who has truly realized the principle of non violence has the God given strength for his weapon and the world has not known anything that can match it.
('74', 161, 3, 8, 311160) Man may, in a moment of unawareness forget God, but He keeps watch over him and protects him always.
('74', 161, 3, 9, 311261) If the Khudai Khidmatgars have understood this secret, if they have realized that non violence is the greatest power on earth, well and good; otherwise it would be better for Khan Saheb to restore to them their weapons which they have discarded at his instance.
('74', 161, 3, 10, 311523) They will then be at least brave after the manner of the world that has today made the worship of brute force its cult.
('74', 161, 3, 11, 311643) But if they discard their old weapons and at the same time remain strangers to the power of non violence, it would be a tragedy for which I for one am not and, so far as I know, Khan Saheb too is not prepared.
('74', 161, 3, 12, 311853) Harijan, 19 11 1938

('74', 162, 8, 15, 313503) LAKKI, [October 27, 1938] 4
('74', 162, 9, 16, 313531) The principles on which a non violent organization is based are different from and the reverse of what obtains in a violent organi zation.
('74', 162, 9, 17, 313670) For instance, in the orthodox army, there is a clear distinction made between an officer and a private.
('74', 162, 9, 18, 313774) The latter is subordinate and inferior to the former.
('74', 162, 9, 19, 313828) In a non violent army the general is just the chief servant—first among equals.
('74', 162, 9, 20, 313908) He claims no privilege over or superiority to the rank and file.
('74', 162, 9, 21, 313973) You have fondly given the title
('74', 162, 10, 22, 314005) 1 Dewan of Junagadh; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 27 10 1938 2 Narandas 3 Extracted from Pyarelal’s report “In the Frontier Province V” 4Vide the preceding item.
('74', 163, 0, 1, 314172) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 163, 1, 2, 314214) ‘Badshah Khan’ to Khan Saheb.
('74', 163, 1, 3, 314244) But if in his heart of hearts he actually began to believe that he could behave like an ordinary general, it would spell his downfall and bring his power to an end.
('74', 163, 1, 4, 314409) He is Badshah in the sense only that he is the truest and foremost Khudai Khidmatgar and excels all other Khudai Khidmatgars in the quality and quantity of service.
('74', 163, 1, 5, 314574) The second difference between a military organization and a peace organization is that in the former the rank and file have no part in the choice of their general and other officers.
('74', 163, 1, 6, 314757) These are imposed upon them and enjoy unrestricted power over them.
('74', 163, 1, 7, 314825) In a non violent army, the general and the officers are elected or are as if elected when their authority is moral and rests solely on the willing obedience of the rank and file.
('74', 163, 1, 8, 315004) So much for internal relations between the general of a non violent army and his soldiers.
('74', 163, 1, 9, 315095) Coming to their relations with the outside world, the same sort of difference is visible between these two kinds of organizations.
('74', 163, 1, 10, 315226) Just now we had to deal with an enormous crowd that had gathered outside this room.
('74', 163, 1, 11, 315310) You tried to disperse it by persuasion and loving argument, not by using force and, when in the end we failed in our attempt, we withdrew and sought relief from it by getting behind closed doors in this room.
('74', 163, 1, 12, 315519) Military discipline knows nothing of moral pressure.
('74', 163, 1, 13, 315572) Let me proceed a step further.
('74', 163, 1, 14, 315603) The people who are crowding outside here are all our friends though they are not Khudai Khid matgars.
('74', 163, 1, 15, 315705) They are eager to listen to what we may tell them.
('74', 163, 1, 16, 315756) Even their indiscipline is a manifestation of their love.
('74', 163, 1, 17, 315814) But there may be others besides them elsewhere who may not be well disposed towards us, who may even be hostile to us.
('74', 163, 1, 18, 315933) In armed organizations, the only recog nized way of dealing with such persons is to drive them out.
('74', 163, 1, 19, 316033) Here, to consider the opponent, or, for the matter of that, anybody, even in thought, as your enemy would, in the parlance of non violence or love, be called a sin.
('74', 163, 1, 20, 316198) Far from seeking revenge, a votary of non vio lence would pray to God that He might bring about a change of heart of his opponent, and if that does not happen he would be prepared to bear any injury that his opponent might inflict upon him, not in a spirit of cowardice or helplessness, but bravely with a smile upon his face.
('74', 163, 1, 21, 316525) I believe implicitly in the ancient saying that “non violence real and complete will melt the stoniest hearts.”
('74', 163, 2, 22, 316637) He illustrated his remarks by describing how Mir Alam Khan, his Pathan
('74', 164, 0, 1, 316708) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 165
('74', 164, 1, 2, 316757) assailant in South Africa, had ultimately repented and become friendly.
('74', 164, 2, 3, 316829) This could not have happened if I had retaliated.
('74', 164, 2, 4, 316879) My action can be fitly described as a process of conversion.
('74', 164, 2, 5, 316940) Unless you have felt within you this urge to convert your enemy by your love, you had better retrace your steps; this business of non violence is not for you.
('74', 164, 2, 6, 317099) ‘What about thieves, dacoits and spoilers of defenceless women ?’ you will ask.
('74', 164, 2, 7, 317179) Must a Khudai Khidmatgar maintain his non violence in regard to them too?
('74', 164, 2, 8, 317253) My reply is, most decidedly ‘Yes’.
('74', 164, 2, 9, 317288) Punishment is God’s, Who alone is the infallible Judge.
('74', 164, 2, 10, 317344) It does not belong to man “with judgment weak”.
('74', 164, 2, 11, 317392) Renunciation of violence must not mean apathy or helplessness in the face of wrongdoing.
('74', 164, 2, 12, 317481) If our non violence is genuine and rooted in love, it ought to provide a more effective remedy against wrongdoing than the use of brute force.
('74', 164, 2, 13, 317624) I certainly expect you to trace out the dacoits, show them the error of their ways and, in so doing, brave even death.

('74', 166, 7, 26, 322128) Your beginning is almost hair raising, but as one proceeds further one feels that this must be one of those incidents which are all too frequent in the world.

('74', 167, 1, 2, 322523) 223. LETTER TO M. R. MASANI
('74', 167, 2, 3, 322551) DERA ISMAIL KHAN, October 27, 1938
('74', 167, 3, 4, 322586) BHAI MASANI, I was pained to read your reply to my article.
('74', 167, 3, 5, 322646) You seem to say that socialists believe in khadi, in prohibition and in non violence and that the Committee has no evidence of speeches inciting to violence having been made.

('74', 167, 6, 15, 323320) 224. MONSTROUS IF TRUE
('74', 167, 7, 16, 323343) A correspondent writes:
('74', 167, 8, 17, 323367) Here in Nasik there is a Police Training School.
('74', 167, 8, 18, 323416) Police officers are made in this school.
('74', 167, 8, 19, 323457) They are expected to have their meals in a common mess and they are obliged to partake of fleshmeat and wines.
('74', 167, 8, 20, 323568) Let alone meat eating, how far is it consistent with the prohibition policy of the Government to train its police officers in wine drinking?
('74', 167, 8, 21, 323709) These officers may well be required to take part in the prohibition drive.
('74', 167, 8, 22, 323784) Perhaps you do not even know that meat eating and wine drinking is compulsory in this school.
('74', 167, 8, 23, 323878) I must confess my ignorance of the compulsion.
('74', 167, 8, 24, 323925) It is only the assurance with which my correspondent writes that has induced me to publish the letter.
('74', 167, 8, 25, 324028) If the information is true, it is surely monstrous that meat eating and wine drinking should be considered a necessary part of a police officer’s training.
('74', 167, 8, 26, 324184) This rule excludes vegetarians and non drinkers from training as police officers.
('74', 167, 8, 27, 324266) The rule is a grave injustice in a country in which tens of thousands are vegetarians by religion.
('74', 167, 9, 28, 324365) 1 Not clear in the source 2 Vide “Forword to “Dadabhai Naoroji”, 19 10 1938
('74', 168, 0, 1, 324441) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 169
('74', 168, 1, 2, 324490) can only hope that the information is incorrect and that if it is true, the glaring wrong will be redressed without delay.

('74', 172, 5, 5, 331034) 231. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DERA ISMAIL KHAN 1
('74', 172, 6, 6, 331084) October 28, 1938
('74', 172, 7, 7, 331101) I thank you for the purse which you have presented but you should know that Daridranarayana, whose representative I claim to be, is not so easily satisfied.
('74', 172, 7, 8, 331258) My business is with the crores of semi starved masses, who need relief sorely.
('74', 172, 7, 9, 331337) We have to tackle through khadi the question of a huge annual drain from India for cotton pur chase.
('74', 172, 7, 10, 331438) Through khadi the A. I. S. A. has already distributed over four crores of rupees as wages among the needy, poor, Hindu and Mussal man spinners and weavers.
('74', 172, 7, 11, 331594) Then there is the question of Harijan uplift—an equally Herculean task.
('74', 172, 7, 12, 331666) Your donation ought to be com mensurate with the magnitude of the task for which it is intended.
('74', 172, 7, 13, 331763) Yours is not a poor city.
('74', 172, 7, 14, 331789) The donors are mostly merchants.
('74', 172, 7, 15, 331822) Surely, you could have done better.
('74', 172, 8, 16, 331858) Referring next to the Khudai Khidmatgars and to the strained relations between them and the local volunteers which he had noticed, he proceeded: These differences are unfortunate.
('74', 172, 8, 17, 332038) If, however, Khudai Khid matgars live up to their creed as they have now understood it, the differences and quarrels will be things of the past.
('74', 172, 8, 18, 332183) They are on their trial.
('74', 172, 8, 19, 332208) If they come out victorious they will be instrumental in bringing about communal unity and establishing swaraj.
('74', 172, 8, 20, 332320) I know, to banish anger altogether from one’s breast is a difficult task.
('74', 172, 8, 21, 332394) It cannot be achieved through pure, personal effort.
('74', 172, 8, 22, 332447) It can be done only by God’s grace.
('74', 172, 8, 23, 332483) I ask you all to join me in the prayer that God might enable the Khudai Khidmatgars to conquer the last traces of anger and violence that might still be lurking in their breasts.

('74', 175, 7, 25, 336732) 238. INTERPRETATION OF MEMBER’S PLEDGE
('74', 175, 8, 26, 336771) [October 30, 1938] 3
('74', 175, 9, 27, 336792) The pledge was purposely drawn as it is of a general character.
('74', 175, 9, 28, 336856) It is a gentleman’s pledge, each member being put upon his or her honour as to the interpretation of the expression ‘the best part of my
('74', 175, 10, 29, 336993) 1 Vide the following item.
('74', 175, 10, 30, 337020) 2 Vide the preceding item.
('74', 176, 0, 1, 337047) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 177
('74', 176, 1, 2, 337096) energy and talents to the furtherance of its object which is the all round welfare of the villagers of India’.
('74', 176, 1, 3, 337207) Members are also pledged not only to work for the furtherance of the object but also ‘to strive to live up to the ideals’ and ‘prefer the use of village manufactures to any other’.
('74', 176, 1, 4, 337388) Recommending members of the Board will therefore see to it that the candidate for membership has, in everything he does, the welfare of the villagers at heart.
('74', 176, 1, 5, 337548) It follows that such a person will give to village work at least some time every day not necessarily in villages but may be for villages.
('74', 176, 1, 6, 337686) Thus a member living in a city, who on a particular day sells to or induces a person to buy village manufactures, has done some village work for that day.
('74', 176, 1, 7, 337841) The member recommending will also see to it that the candidate wherever possible uses articles of village manufacture, e.g., khadi in the place of mill cloth, village earthen pots instead of factory made china, reed pen instead of steel pen, handmade paper instead of ordinary paper, wholesome babul or neem or such other tooth brush instead of the very insanitary and injurious tooth brush, leather goods made in villages out of village flayed cattle instead [of] tanned hide, the ordinary village gur instead of factory sugar, hand pounded whole rice instead of mill polished rice, etc.
('74', 176, 2, 8, 338430) The Board would draw the attention of agents, workers and the public to the importance of dead cattle hide as an article of trade and village manufacture.
('74', 176, 2, 9, 338585) Workers are advised to study in their own areas the method of disposal of the dead cattle and its preparation from flaying to tanning and report to the Board their observations.
('74', 176, 2, 10, 338763) Public are invited to prefer the use of only such leather goods as are pre pared in the villages.
('74', 176, 2, 11, 338861) Things to Remember
('74', 176, 3, 12, 338880) Agent’s appointment of Hardhyansingh, Delhi.
('74', 176, 3, 13, 338925) Accurate descri ption of the areas of work of members of Board and agents.
('74', 176, 4, 14, 339000) From a photostat: G.N. 10137 and 10138
('74', 177, 0, 1, 339039) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('74', 179, 5, 12, 342635) 243. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TANK 1
('74', 179, 6, 13, 342673) October 31, 1938
('74', 179, 7, 14, 342690) They 2 feel that the existence of a microscopic Hindu minority in the midst of the predominantly Mussalman population in this area can be rendered possible only if the latter will be as true hamsayas— neighbours—to them and they have asked me to appeal to Khudai Khidmatgars to fulfil their natural role in respect of them.
('74', 179, 7, 15, 343014) I entirely endorse their feeling and their appeal and I am convinced that it is within your power to set them at their ease if you will but fulfil the expectations you have raised in me.
('74', 179, 7, 16, 343201) As I observed on a previous occasion, the Hindus, the Mussalmans and the Englishmen in this pro vince are being weighed in the balance.
('74', 179, 7, 17, 343337) History will record its verdict about the Englishmen’s deeds.
('74', 179, 7, 18, 343399) But Hindus and Mussalmans can write their own history by being correct in their mutual dealings.
('74', 179, 7, 19, 343496) For the Khudai Khidmatgars their course of action has been determined.
('74', 179, 7, 20, 343567) They have to become a living wall of protection to their neighbours.
('74', 179, 7, 21, 343636) A small body of determined spirits fired by an unquenchable faith in their mission can alter the course of history.
('74', 179, 7, 22, 343752) It has happened before and it may again happen if the non violence of Khudai Khid matgars is unalloyed gold, not mere glittering tinsel.

('74', 180, 0, 1, 344101) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 181
('74', 180, 1, 2, 344150) 244. TALE TO KHUDAI KHIDMATGARS 1
('74', 180, 2, 3, 344184) TANK, October 31, 1938
('74', 180, 3, 4, 344207) If in your heart of hearts there is the slightest inclination to regard your non violence as a mere cloak or a stepping stone to greater violence as suggested by this friend 2, nay, unless you are prepared to carry your non violence to its ultimate logical conclusion and to pray for forgiveness even for a baby killer and a child mur derer, you cannot sign your Khudai Khidmatgar’s pledge of non violence.
('74', 180, 3, 5, 344614) To sign that pledge with mental reservations would only bring disgrace upon you, your organization and hurt him whom you delight to call the Pride of Afghans.
('74', 180, 3, 6, 344773) But what about the classical instance of the defenceless sister or mother who is threatened with molestation by an evil minded ruffian, you will ask.
('74', 180, 3, 7, 344923) Is the ruffian in question to be allowed to work his will?
('74', 180, 3, 8, 344982) Would not the use of violence be permissible even in such a case?
('74', 180, 3, 9, 345048) My reply is ‘no’.
('74', 180, 3, 10, 345066) You will entreat the ruffian.
('74', 180, 3, 11, 345096) The odds are that in his intoxication he will not listen.
('74', 180, 3, 12, 345154) But then you will interpose yourself between the intended victim and him.
('74', 180, 3, 13, 345228) Very probably you will be killed but you will have done your duty.
('74', 180, 3, 14, 345295) Ten to one, killing you unarmed and unresisting will assuage the assailant’s passion and he will leave his victim unmolested.
('74', 180, 3, 15, 345421) But it has been said to me that tyrants do not act as we want or expect them to.
('74', 180, 3, 16, 345502) Finding you unresisting he may tie you to a post and make you watch his rape of the victim.
('74', 180, 3, 17, 345594) If you have the will you will so exert yourself that you will break yourself in the attempt or break the bonds.
('74', 180, 3, 18, 345706) In either case, you will open the eyes of the wrongdoer.
('74', 180, 3, 19, 345763) Your armed resistance could do no more, while if you were worsted, the position would likely be much worse than if you died unresisting.
('74', 180, 3, 20, 345900) There is also the chance of the intended victim copying your calm courage and immolating herself rather than allowing herself to be dishonoured.
('74', 180, 3, 21, 346045) Harijan, 19 11 1938
('74', 180, 4, 22, 346065) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s report “In the Frontier Province V” 2 The reference is to a Pathan’s question quoted by Gandhiji in his article “Khudai Khidmatgars and Badshah Khan”; vide “Khudai Khidmatgars and Badshah Khan”, 19 11 1938
