('74', 250, 7, 10, 477178) 337. NON CO OPERATORS
('74', 250, 8, 11, 477200) Several letters have been lying on my file from Congressmen who non co operated during the non co operation days.
('74', 250, 8, 12, 477314) Among these were those also who resigned Government services.
('74', 250, 8, 13, 477376) Some of these are now agitating for reinstatement.
('74', 250, 8, 14, 477427) They quote in support my appeal to the public including Government servants tonon co operate.
('74', 250, 8, 15, 477521) Among the sufferers who have, to my knowledge, not agitated for restoration are the resisters who were fined, the relatives who lost their bread winners, the lawyers who gave up their practice and were reduced to penury, and the students who gave up their studies and consequent prospects.
('74', 250, 8, 16, 477811) They think the suffering voluntarily undergone was its own reward and demands no further compensation.
('74', 250, 8, 17, 477914) If all these were to claim restoration from the Congress Minis ters, the latter’s lot would be truly unenviable and they would have little work to do save that of adjudging claims.
('74', 250, 8, 18, 478095) They would also have to raise money for discharging claims that must amount to seve ral crores.
('74', 250, 8, 19, 478191) Moreover, it would be difficult for the discharged Govern ment servants who gave up their jobs whether compulsorily or volunt arily to show that the cases of other sufferers were less hard thantheirs.
('74', 250, 8, 20, 478392) In my opinion these ex Government servants as a class were the least sufferers.
('74', 250, 8, 21, 478472) And if they have been without work all these years, they can hardly become efficient servants of the State.
('74', 250, 8, 22, 478580) Government service for Congressmen is not an avenue to material advancement; it should be an avenue to service.
('74', 250, 8, 23, 478692) Therefore only those Congressmen may enter Government service whose market value is higher than that they can get from the Government.
('74', 250, 8, 24, 478827) They can be employed only when
('74', 251, 0, 1, 478858) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 251, 1, 2, 478900) they are wanted.
('74', 251, 1, 3, 478917) There should be no such thing as Congress patro nage.
('74', 251, 1, 4, 478971) A war, whether violent or non violent, loses its thrill and its gran deur if the warriors are insured against all loss.
('74', 251, 1, 5, 479091) A satyagrahi to be worthy of the name stands to lose all without expectation of any compensation in the future.
('74', 251, 1, 6, 479203) His merit lies in his undergoing the uttermost sacrifice.
('74', 251, 1, 7, 479261) Indeed the Congress machinery will fall to pieces if men come to it to better their prospects in life.
('74', 251, 1, 8, 479364) And if the Congress Ministers are expected to satisfy personal ambition they will be them selves discredited and bring down the prestige of the Congress in the end.
('74', 251, 1, 9, 479529) I hope the reader will not fail to note the difference between this and the restoration of lands which were vindictively sold for a song by the preceding Government administration.
('74', 251, 1, 10, 479710) There the restoration was easily possible and was a duty.
('74', 251, 1, 11, 479768) It was like restoring a bit of country taken away by the victor.
('74', 251, 1, 12, 479833) If another civil disobedience campaign becomes necessary, the Government will think fifty times before selling people’s land and unpatriotic persons will not dare to profit at the expense of patriots.
('74', 251, 2, 13, 480034) SEGAON, November 27, 1938 Harijan, 3 12 1938

('74', 253, 0, 1, 481624) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 254
('74', 253, 1, 2, 481666) 340. STATES AND THE PEOPLE
('74', 253, 2, 3, 481693) The almost simultaneous awakening in the various States is a very significant event in the national struggle for independence.
('74', 253, 2, 4, 481820) It will be wrong to think that such awakening can be due to the instigation of one person or a body of persons or any organization.
('74', 253, 2, 5, 481952) It is just possible that the Haripura resolution of the Congress put the people of the States on their mettle and they realized as never before that their salvation depended upon their own labours.
('74', 253, 2, 6, 482150) But above all it is the time spirit that has brought about the awakening.
('74', 253, 2, 7, 482224) It is to be hoped that the Princes and their advisers will recognize it and meet the legitimate aspirations of the people.
('74', 253, 2, 8, 482347) There is no half way house between total extinction of the States and the Princes making their people respon sible for the administration of their States and themselves becoming trustees for the people, taking an earned commission for their labours.
('74', 253, 2, 9, 482597) I hope, therefore, the rumour is not true that the British Govern ment are likely, at the instance of some Princes or their Dewans, to announce a change in the policy recently enunciated by Earl Winter ton, about the ability of the Princes to grant responsible government to their people.
('74', 253, 2, 10, 482886) If any of them have asked the British Government to reverse the policy, they have undoubtedly done a disservice to themselves.
('74', 253, 2, 11, 483013) And if the British Government respond to the unworthy wish, they will precipitate a first class crisis whose magnitude it is difficult to foretell.
('74', 253, 2, 12, 483161) I must refuse to believe that the British Govern ment can commit such a blunder.
('74', 253, 2, 13, 483242) Earl Winterton’s announcement was but an endorsement of past practice.
('74', 253, 2, 14, 483313) They are not known to have ever interfered with the States giving powers to their people, however wide they might be.
('74', 253, 2, 15, 483431) I go a step further.
('74', 253, 2, 16, 483452) Even as the British Government, as the Para mount Power, are bound to protect the Princes against harm from out side or within, they are equally or a fortiori bound to ensure just rule on the part of the Princes.
('74', 253, 2, 17, 483665) Hence it is their bounden duty, when they supply the police or the military to any State, to see that there is a pro per emergency justifying the request and that the military or the police will be used with becoming restraint.
('74', 253, 2, 18, 483893) From Dhenkanal have come to me stories of fiendish cruelty exercised by the State myr midons under the shadow of the police supplied by the Paramount Power.
('74', 253, 2, 19, 484050) I asked for evidence in support of some of the unnamable
('74', 254, 0, 1, 484107) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 255
('74', 254, 1, 2, 484155) cruelties.
('74', 254, 1, 3, 484166) And I have enough to inspire belief.
('74', 254, 1, 4, 484203) Indeed, it is a question whether responsible Ministers in the pro vinces have not a moral responsibility in respect of the people of the States in their respective provinces.
('74', 254, 1, 5, 484378) Under the Constitution, the Minis ters have no power over them.
('74', 254, 1, 6, 484442) The Governor is the agent of the Vice roy who is the representative of the Paramount Power.
('74', 254, 1, 7, 484534) But the Minis ters in autonomous provinces have surely a moral responsibility regar ding what happens in the States.
('74', 254, 1, 8, 484651) So long as the States and the people are satisfied, Ministers have no worry.
('74', 254, 1, 9, 484728) But have they none if there is, say, a virulent epidemic in the States which, if neglected, may easily overtake the province in which they are situated?
('74', 254, 1, 10, 484881) Have they none when there is a moral epidemic which seems to be raging in Dhen kanal?
('74', 254, 1, 11, 484967) I understand that the persecuted people are taking refuge in British Orissa.
('74', 254, 1, 12, 485044) Can the Ministers refuse them shelter?
('74', 254, 1, 13, 485083) How many can they take charge of?
('74', 254, 1, 14, 485117) Whatever happens in these States affects for better or for worse the province as a whole.
('74', 254, 1, 15, 485207) I do believe, therefore, that the Ministers by reason of the heavy responsibility resting on their shoulders have the moral right, within strict limits, to assert themselves for the sake of internal peace and decency.
('74', 254, 1, 16, 485425) They cannot look on with unconcern while the people of the States—an arbitrary creation of the Paramount Power—are being ground to dust as they in Dhenkanal are reported to be.
('74', 254, 1, 17, 485602) One reads in the papers that some concessions have been given to the people of Dhenkanal.
('74', 254, 1, 18, 485692) I do not know whether the report is true and whether the relief answers the purpose for which the people of Dhenkanal are fighting and suffering.
('74', 254, 1, 19, 485838) It is, however, irrelevant to the issue raised by me.
('74', 254, 1, 20, 485892) I feel that the Ministers in the provinces are morally bound to take notice of gross misrule in the States within their borders and to tender advice to the Paramount Power as to what, in their opinion, should be done.
('74', 254, 1, 21, 486110) The Paramount Power, if it is to enjoy friendly relations with the provincial Ministers, is bound to give sym pathetic ear to their advice.
('74', 254, 1, 22, 486250) There is one other matter which demands the urgent attention of the States and their advisers.
('74', 254, 1, 23, 486345) They fight shy of the very name Con gress.
('74', 254, 1, 24, 486388) They regard Congressmen as outsiders, foreigners and what not.
('74', 254, 1, 25, 486451) They may be all that in law.
('74', 254, 1, 26, 486480) But man made law, if it is in conflict with the natural law, becomes a dead letter when the latter operates in full force.
('74', 254, 1, 27, 486603) The people of the States look up to the Congress in all matters
('74', 255, 0, 1, 486667) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 256
('74', 255, 1, 2, 486709) affecting their interest.
('74', 255, 1, 3, 486735) Many of them are members of the Congress.
('74', 255, 1, 4, 486777) Some like Shri Jamnalalji hold high offices in the Congress organi zation.
('74', 255, 1, 5, 486852) In the eyes of the Congress there is no distinction between members from the States and from India called British.
('74', 255, 1, 6, 486967) It is surely detrimental to the interests of the States to ignore the Congress or Congressmen, especially when it or they seek to render friendly assistance.
('74', 255, 1, 7, 487125) They must recognize the fact that the people in the States are in many cases guided by the Congress.
('74', 255, 1, 8, 487226) They know that I am responsible for the policy of non interference hitherto followed by the Congress.
('74', 255, 1, 9, 487328) But with the growing influence of the Congress it is impossible for me to defend it in the face of injustice perpetrated in the States.
('74', 255, 1, 10, 487464) If the Congress feels that it has the power to offer effective interference, it will be bound to do so when the call comes.
('74', 255, 1, 11, 487588) And if the Princes believe that the good of the people is also their good, they would gratefully seek and accept the Congress assistance.
('74', 255, 1, 12, 487726) It is surely in their interest to cultivate friendly relations with an organization which bids fair in the future, not very distant, to replace the Paramount Power, let me hope, by friendly arrangement.
('74', 255, 1, 13, 487929) Will they not read the handwriting on the wall?
('74', 255, 1, 14, 487977) SEGAON, November 28, 1938

('74', 267, 4, 12, 503845) 364. A CAUTION
('74', 267, 5, 13, 503860) Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel’s and Shri Damodardas’s requests res pectively to non Rajkot people and non Hyderabad people not to take part in satyagraha are timely and deserve to receive hearty response.
('74', 267, 5, 14, 504060) It is the essence of satyagraha that those who are suffering should alone offer it.
('74', 267, 5, 15, 504144) Cases can be conceived when what may be termed sym pathetic satyagraha may be legitimately applied.
('74', 267, 5, 16, 504244) But so far as I see there is nothing in the Rajkot or Hyderabad satyagraha to warrant outside participation.
('74', 267, 5, 17, 504353) Indeed it is likely to acerbate the authorities.
('74', 267, 5, 18, 504402) The idea underlying satyagraha is to convert the wrongdoer, to awaken the sense of justice in him, to show him also that without the co operation, direct or indirect, of the wronged, the wrongdoer cannot do the wrong intended by him.
('74', 267, 5, 19, 504636) If the people in either case are not ready to suffer for their causes, no outside help in the shape of satya graha can possibly bring true deliverance.
('74', 267, 6, 20, 504788) SEGAON, December 3, 1938
('74', 267, 7, 21, 504813) Harijan, 10 12 1938

('74', 269, 6, 10, 506345) wondered if the world, including the world of missionaries, had advanced since they had last met.
('74', 269, 6, 11, 506443) 3 He was going to preside over the deliberations of the International Missionary Council meeting in Madras during the month, and he wanted to share with Gandhiji the plans of the meeting, and wanted Gandhiji’s “intuition and judgment on things to be discussed at the Convention.”

('74', 276, 10, 27, 524466) 369. HOW TO POPULARIZE KHADI
('74', 276, 11, 28, 524495) A valued khadi worker writes a letter in Hindi which freely translated means: Compared to mill cloth khadi is not an economic pro position in terms of prices.
('74', 276, 11, 29, 524654) To compete with mill cloth you have to drop the cost of hand ginning, carding and spinning.
('74', 276, 11, 30, 524746) Even for self spinners, therefore, it is not a paying proposition.
('74', 276, 11, 31, 524813) No doubt you have evolved new economics of khadi.
('74', 276, 11, 32, 524863) But till the people at large appreciate them, khadi cannot be universal.
('74', 277, 0, 1, 524936) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 278
('74', 277, 1, 2, 524978) the Congress Ministers do not understand or appreciate your new economics.
('74', 277, 1, 3, 525053) In the circumstances, will you not guide khadi workers and even the Ministers and Congressmen in general?
('74', 277, 1, 4, 525159) Your faith seems to be so strong that you would straightway give eight annas per day to spinners for eight hours’ honest and skilled work if we, your co workers, will let you.
('74', 277, 1, 5, 525335) Frankly we do not possess your faith.
('74', 277, 1, 6, 525373) There is no doubt that khadi cannot compete with mill cloth, it was never meant to.
('74', 277, 1, 7, 525457) If the people will not understand or appreciate the law governing khadi, it will never be universal.
('74', 277, 1, 8, 525558) It must then remain the fad of monied people and cranks.
('74', 277, 1, 9, 525615) And if it is to be merely that, the labours of a huge organization like the A.I.S.A must mean a waste of effort, if not something much worse.
('74', 277, 1, 10, 525757) But khadi has a big mission.
('74', 277, 1, 11, 525786) Khadi provides dignified labour to the millions who are otherwise idle for nearly four months in the year.
('74', 277, 1, 12, 525893) Even apart from the remuneration the work brings, it is its own reward.
('74', 277, 1, 13, 525965) For if millions live in compulsory idleness, they must die spiritually, mentally and physically.
('74', 277, 1, 14, 526062) The spinning wheel autoatically raises the status of millions of poor women.
('74', 277, 1, 15, 526139) Even though, therefore, mill cloth were to be given gratis to the people, their true welfare demands that they should refuse to have it in preference to khadi, the product of their labours.
('74', 277, 1, 16, 526329) Life is more than money.
('74', 277, 1, 17, 526354) It is cheaper to kill our aged parents who can do no work and who are a drag on our slender resources.
('74', 277, 1, 18, 526457) It is also cheaper to kill our children whom we do not need for our mate rial comfort and whom we have to maintain without getting anything in return.
('74', 277, 1, 19, 526608) But we kill neither our parents nor our children, but consi der it a privilege to maintain them no matter what their mainte nance costs us.
('74', 277, 1, 20, 526748) Even so must we maintain khadi to the exclusion of all other cloth.
('74', 277, 1, 21, 526816) It is the force of habit which makes us think of khadi in terms of prices.
('74', 277, 1, 22, 526891) We must revise our notion of khadi economics.
('74', 277, 1, 23, 526937) And when we have studied them from the point of view of the national wellbeing, we shall find that khadi is never dear.
('74', 277, 1, 24, 527057) We must suffer dislocation of domestic economy during the transition stage.
('74', 277, 1, 25, 527133) At present we are labouring under a heavy handicap.
('74', 277, 1, 26, 527185) Cotton production has been cen tralized for the sake of Lancashire and, if you will, for the sake of Indian mills.
('74', 277, 1, 27, 527300) Prices of cotton are determined by the prices in foreign lands.
('74', 277, 1, 28, 527364) When the production of cotton is distributed in accordance with the demands of khadi economics, cotton prices would not fluctuate
('74', 278, 0, 1, 527494) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 279
('74', 278, 1, 2, 527542) and, in any case, will be, in effect, lower than today.
('74', 278, 1, 3, 527598) When the people, either through State protection or through voluntary effort, have cultivated the habit of using only khadi, they will never think of it in terms of money, even as millions of vegetarians do not compare the prices of flesh foods with those of non flesh foods.
('74', 278, 1, 4, 527874) They will starve rather than take flesh foods even though they may be offered free.
('74', 278, 1, 5, 527958) But I recognize that very few Congressmen have this living faith in khadi.
('74', 278, 1, 6, 528033) The Ministers are Congressmen.
('74', 278, 1, 7, 528064) They derive their inspi ration from their surroundings.
('74', 278, 1, 8, 528120) If they had a living faith in khadi, they could do a great deal to popularize it.
('74', 278, 1, 9, 528202) Khadi was an integral part of the original swaraj programme of 1920. In 1921 22 thousands of Congressmen repeated from hundreds of platforms that swaraj for the millions depended upon the spin ning wheel humming in every village.
('74', 278, 1, 10, 528432) The late Ali Brothers used to say, at the numerous meetings they addressed, that without the char kha in every cottage and the loom in every village there was no freedom.
('74', 278, 1, 11, 528603) Maulana Mahomed Ali used to say in his picturesque lan guage that our charkhas were our instruments of war and the cones of yarn turned out by them were our ammunition.
('74', 278, 1, 12, 528772) He said this with a conviction that went home to his audiences.
('74', 278, 1, 13, 528836) But the faith of those early days was not sustained.
('74', 278, 1, 14, 528889) Congressmen in general have ceased to connect khadi with swaraj.
('74', 278, 1, 15, 528954) Shri Jawaharlal Nehru has called khadi the livery of our freedom.
('74', 278, 1, 16, 529020) For how many does it bear that meaning?
('74', 278, 1, 17, 529060) If Congressmen could have that belief, khadi itself would be current coin.
('74', 278, 1, 18, 529135) Freedom is never dear at any price.
('74', 278, 1, 19, 529171) It is the breath of life.
('74', 278, 1, 20, 529197) What would a man not pay for living?
('74', 278, 1, 21, 529234) The Congress flag was designed to represent not civil disobedience which is but a phase, but it was designed to represent the essentials of freedom.
('74', 278, 1, 22, 529383) Its background is khadi.
('74', 278, 1, 23, 529408) The spinning wheel covers and sustains it.
('74', 278, 1, 24, 529451) Its colours show how necessary communal unity is for the attainment of freedom.
('74', 278, 1, 25, 529531) Given the fulfilment of these conditions, civil disobedi ence and the suffering it implies may not be at all necessary.
('74', 278, 1, 26, 529651) To wear khadi is for me to wear freedom.
('74', 278, 1, 27, 529692) Given a full hearted acceptance of this meaning of khadi, I am able to say what the Congress Ministers and, for that matter, all the Ministers, khadi workers and Congressmen can and should do.
('74', 278, 1, 28, 529885) There may be a Minister whose sole business would be to look after khadi and village industries.
('74', 278, 1, 29, 529982) There should, therefore, be a depart ment for this purpose.
('74', 278, 1, 30, 530042) The other departments will co operate.
('74', 279, 0, 1, 530081) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 280
('74', 279, 1, 2, 530123) the Agricultural Department will frame a scheme of decentralization of cotton production, survey the land suitable for cotton production for village use and find out how much cotton will be required for its province.
('74', 279, 1, 3, 530340) It will even stock cotton at suitable centres for distribution.
('74', 279, 1, 4, 530404) The Stores Department will make purchases of khadi available in the province and give orders for its cloth requirements.

('74', 288, 6, 15, 543154) SHARMA,
('74', 288, 7, 16, 543162) I have your very candid letter.

('74', 288, 7, 18, 543245) I shall provide the money.
('74', 288, 7, 19, 543272) As regards earning a living I do not believe that you can make a success of this venture.
('74', 288, 7, 20, 543362) I fear that in one way or another your ex penses will go up.

('74', 288, 7, 22, 543499) Carrying on a business and doing good to others cannot go together.
('74', 288, 7, 23, 543567) You should sit down with Draupadi and work out a limit to your expenses and you should make up your mind that you will not go beyond it.
('74', 288, 7, 24, 543704) If you do that your monthly expenses can be drawn from some institution.
('74', 288, 7, 25, 543777) What can I say about the debt of Rs. 850?
('74', 288, 7, 26, 543819) The mistake was made at the outset in incurring the debt.
('74', 288, 7, 27, 543877) I can only say that so long as you have not repaid the debt you should forget all about helping others and take up a job so that you can meet your expenses and repay the debt.
('74', 288, 7, 28, 544053) If you have jewellery or other property in the family you can even dispose of it to clear the debt.
('74', 288, 7, 29, 544153) This is a drastic cure but I am sure it is also the most effective cure.
('74', 288, 7, 30, 544226) You should resolve also not

('74', 293, 1, 2, 549114) 395. DISCUSSION WITH D. TAKAOKA 1
('74', 293, 2, 3, 549148) [December 7, 1938] 2
('74', 293, 3, 4, 549169) It can be possible if Japan ceases to throw its greedy eyes on India.
('74', 293, 3, 5, 549239) No doubt you do not bring your army to India, but you em ploy your matchless skill, and your ability to hide the truth and your knowledge of the weaknesses of Indians, in order to flood India with your goods which are often flimsy.
('74', 293, 3, 6, 549471) You have copied the rulers of India in their methods of exploitation and gone even one better.
('74', 293, 3, 7, 549566) Now, from the Japanese standpoint you cannot afford to lose the millions of rupees that you get from India.
('74', 293, 3, 8, 549674) And if you cannot get them volun tarily, you will be quite capable of doing so by force of arms.
('74', 293, 3, 9, 549771) But that would not be the way of bringing Japan and India together.
('74', 293, 3, 10, 549839) What can bring them together is a moral bond based on mutual friendship.
('74', 293, 3, 11, 549912) But there is no basis for that friendship today.
('74', 293, 3, 12, 549961) Take your art.
('74', 293, 3, 13, 549976) I like it.
('74', 293, 3, 14, 549987) I read a fascinating account of Japan and Japanese life by Edwin Arnold many years ago.
('74', 293, 3, 15, 550075) That picture has remained with me.
('74', 293, 3, 16, 550110) I want to assimilate all your good points, but unfortunately no one comes here to give us the good things of Japan.
('74', 293, 3, 17, 550226) You believe only in dumping your goods on us.
('74', 293, 3, 18, 550272) How can I take a single yard of Japanese cloth, however fine and artistic it may be?
('74', 293, 3, 19, 550357) It is as poison to us, for it means starvation for the poor people of India.
('74', 293, 3, 20, 550434) You have left the West far behind in diplomacy, in skill, in cheap manufactures, in armed warfare, in exploitation.
('74', 293, 3, 21, 550550) How then can there be friendship between you and us, so long as you see nothing wrong in exploitation?
('74', 293, 4, 22, 550653) Mr. Takaoka wondered if Gandhiji could give a message to the new party in Japan which stands for Asia for the Asiatics.
('74', 293, 4, 23, 550773) Gandhiji said: I do not subscribe to the doctrine of Asia for the Asiatics, if it is meant as an anti European combination.
('74', 293, 4, 24, 550897) How can we have Asia for the Asiatics unless we are content to let Asia remain a frog in the well?
('74', 293, 4, 25, 550996) But Asia cannot afford to remain a frog in the well.
('74', 293, 4, 26, 551049) It has a message for the whole world, if it will only live up to it.
('74', 293, 4, 27, 551118) There is the imprint of Buddhistic influence on the whole of Asia, which includes India, China, Japan, Burma, Ceylon and the Malay States.
('74', 293, 4, 28, 551257) I said to the Bur

('74', 294, 1, 3, 551630) I would say the same thing to China and Japan.
('74', 294, 1, 4, 551677) But, for Asia to be not for Asia but the whole world, it has to relearn the message of Buddha and deliver it to the world.

('74', 294, 3, 14, 552336) 396. REPLY TO GERMAN CRITICS
('74', 294, 4, 15, 552365) I was not unprepared for the exhibition of wrath from Germany over my article 1 about the German treatment of the Jews.
('74', 294, 4, 16, 552485) I have my self admitted my ignorance of European politics.
('74', 294, 4, 17, 552544) But in order to com mend my prescription to the Jews for the removal of their many ills, I did not need to have an accurate knowledge of European politics.
('74', 294, 4, 18, 552700) The main facts about the atrocities are beyond dispute.
('74', 294, 4, 19, 552756) When the anger over my writing has subsided and comparative calmness has returned, the most wrathful German will find that underlying my writing there was friendliness towards Germany, never any ill will.
('74', 294, 4, 20, 552961) Have I not repeatedly said that active non violence is unadul terated love—fellow feeling?
('74', 294, 4, 21, 553052) And if the Jews, instead of being help lessly and of necessity non violent, adopt active non violence, i.e., fellow feeling for the gentile Germans deliberately, they cannot do any harm to the Germans and I am as certain as I am dictating these lines that the stoniest German heart will melt.
('74', 294, 4, 22, 553345) Great as have been the Jewish contributions to the world’s progress, this supreme act of theirs will be their greatest contribution and war will be a thing of the past.
('74', 294, 4, 23, 553514) It passes comprehension why any German should be angry over my utterly innocuous writing.
('74', 294, 4, 24, 553604) Of course, German critics, as others, might have ridiculed it by saying that it was a visionary’s effort
('74', 294, 5, 25, 553709) 1 Vide “The Jews”
('74', 295, 0, 1, 553727) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 296
('74', 295, 1, 2, 553769) doomed to fail.
('74', 295, 1, 3, 553785) I therefore welcome this wrath, though wholly un merited, against my writing.
('74', 295, 1, 4, 553863) Has my writing gone home?
('74', 295, 1, 5, 553889) Has the writer felt that my remedy was after all not so ludicrous as it may appear, but that it was eminently practical if only the beauty of suffer ing without retaliation was realized?
('74', 295, 1, 6, 554076) To say that my writing has rendered neither myself, my move ment, nor German Indian relations any service, is surely irrelevant, if not also unworthy, implying as it does a threat; and I should rank my self a coward if, for fear of my country or myself or Indo German relations being harmed, I hesitated to give what I felt in the innermost recesses of my heart to be cent per cent sound advice.
('74', 295, 1, 7, 554472) The Berlin writer has surely enunciated a novel doctrine that people outside Germany may not criticize German action even from friendliest motives.
('74', 295, 1, 8, 554620) For my part I would certainly welcome the inte resting things that Germans or other outsiders may unearth about Indians.
('74', 295, 1, 9, 554741) I do not need to speak for the British.
('74', 295, 1, 10, 554781) But if I know the Bri tish people at all, they, too, welcome outside criticism, when it is well informed and free from malice.
('74', 295, 1, 11, 554908) In this age, when distances have been obliterated, no nation can afford to imitate the fabled frog in the well.
('74', 295, 1, 12, 555020) Sometimes it is refreshing to see ourselves as others see us.
('74', 295, 1, 13, 555082) If, therefore, the German critics happen to see this reply, I hope that they will not only revise their opinion about my writing but will also realize the value of outside criticism.
('74', 295, 2, 14, 555265) SEGAON, December 8, 1938
('74', 295, 3, 15, 555290) Harijan, 17 12 1938

('74', 296, 9, 14, 556355) 399. SOME QUESTIONS ANSWERED
('74', 296, 10, 15, 556384) Friends have sent me two newspaper cuttings criticizing my appeal to the Jews.
('74', 296, 10, 16, 556463) The two critics suggest that in presenting non vio lence to the Jews as a remedy against the wrong done to them I have suggested nothing new, and that they have been practising non vio lence for the past two thousand years.
('74', 296, 10, 17, 556687) Obviously, so far as these critics are concerned, I did not make my meaning clear.
('74', 296, 10, 18, 556770) The Jews, so far as I know, have never practised non violence as an article of faith or even as a deliberate policy.
('74', 296, 10, 19, 556887) Indeed, it is a stigma against them that their ancestors crucified Jesus.
('74', 296, 10, 20, 556961) Are they not supposed to believe in eye for an eye and tooth for a tooth?
('74', 296, 10, 21, 557035) Have they no violence in their hearts for their oppressors?
('74', 296, 10, 22, 557095) Do they not want the so called democratic powers to punish Germany for her persecution and to deliver them from
('74', 296, 11, 23, 557207) 1 The addressee was Home Minister in the Congress Ministry of Bombay Province.
('74', 296, 11, 24, 557286) 2 The letter was written on the reverse of a letter from the addressee with which he had enclosed a letter received from Padmaja Naidu and his reply to it as well as one from Jamnalal Bajaj.
('74', 296, 11, 25, 557477) 3 Jamnalal Bajaj’s secretary
('74', 297, 0, 1, 557506) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 298
('74', 297, 1, 2, 557548) oppression?
('74', 297, 1, 3, 557560) If they do, there is no non violence in their hearts.
('74', 297, 1, 4, 557614) Their non violence, if it may be so called, is of the helpless and the weak.
('74', 297, 1, 5, 557691) What I have pleaded for is renunciation of violence of the heart and consequent active exercise of the force generated by the great renunciation.
('74', 297, 1, 6, 557837) One of the critics says that favourable public opinion is necessary for the working of non violence.
('74', 297, 1, 7, 557938) The writer is evidently thinking of passive resistance conceived as a weapon of the weak.
('74', 297, 1, 8, 558028) I have drawn a distinction between passive resistance of the weak and active non violent resistance of the strong.
('74', 297, 1, 9, 558143) The latter can and does work in the teeth of the fiercest opposition.
('74', 297, 1, 10, 558213) But it ends in evoking the widest public sympathy.
('74', 297, 1, 11, 558264) Sufferings of the non violent have been known to melt the stoniest hearts.
('74', 297, 1, 12, 558339) I make bold to say that if the Jews can summon to their aid the soul power that comes only from non violence, Herr Hitler will bow before the courage which he has never yet experienced in any large measure in his dealings with men, and which, when it is exhibited, he will own is infinitely superior to that shown by his best storm troopers.
('74', 297, 1, 13, 558681) The exhibition of such courage is only possible for those who have a living faith in the God of Truth and Non violence, i.
('74', 297, 1, 14, 558804) e., Love.
('74', 297, 1, 15, 558814) Of course, the critics can reasonably argue that the nonviolence pictured by me is not possible for masses of mankind, it is possible only for the very few highly developed persons.
('74', 297, 1, 16, 558996) I have combated that view and suggested that, given proper training and proper generalship, non violence can be practised by masses of mankind.
('74', 297, 1, 17, 559140) I see, however, that my remarks are being misunderstood to mean that because I advise non violent resistance by the persecuted Jews, by inference I expect or would advise non interference by the democratic powers on behalf of the Jews.
('74', 297, 1, 18, 559376) I hardly need to answer this fear.
('74', 297, 1, 19, 559411) Surely there is no danger of the great powers refraining from action because of anything I have said.
('74', 297, 1, 20, 559513) They will, they are bound to, do all they can to free the Jews from the inhuman persecution.
('74', 297, 1, 21, 559606) My appeal has force in the face of the fact that the great powers feel unable to help the Jews in an effective manner.
('74', 297, 1, 22, 559725) Therefore it is that I have offered the prescription which I know to be infallible when taken in the right manner.
('74', 297, 1, 23, 559840) The most relevant criticism, however, which I have received is this: How do I expect the Jews to accept my prescription when I know that India, where I am myself working, where I call myself the self appointed general, has not accepted it in toto.
('74', 297, 1, 24, 560088) My answer is: ‘Blessed
('74', 298, 0, 1, 560111) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 299
('74', 298, 1, 2, 560159) are they that expect nothing.’ I belong to the category of the blessed, in this case at least.
('74', 298, 1, 3, 560254) Having got the prescription and being sure of its efficacy, I felt that I would be wrong if I did not draw attention to it when I saw cases where it could be effectively applied.
('74', 298, 1, 4, 560433) Hitherto I have refused to deal with European politics.
('74', 298, 1, 5, 560489) My gen eral position still remains the same.
('74', 298, 1, 6, 560534) I presented my remedy almost in suppressed tones in the case of Abyssinia.
('74', 298, 1, 7, 560609) The cases of the Czechs and the Jews became more vivid to me than the case of the Abyssinians.
('74', 298, 1, 8, 560704) And I could not restrain myself from writing.
('74', 298, 1, 9, 560750) Perhaps Dr. Mott was right when he said to me the other day that I must write more and more articles like those on the Czechs and the Jews, if only because they must aid me in the Indian struggle.
('74', 298, 1, 10, 560947) He said that the West was never more prepared than now to listen to the message of non vio lence.
('74', 298, 1, 11, 561045) SEGAON, December 9, 1938
('74', 298, 2, 12, 561070) Harijan, 17 1 2 1938
('74', 298, 3, 13, 561091) 400. RED TAPE
('74', 298, 4, 14, 561105) A distinguished Indian, who had been watching Ministers Kher and Munshi working at breakneck speed, told me the other day how they seemed to have aged, and warned me that the nation would lose them before their time if I did not prevent them from overworking themselves.
('74', 298, 4, 15, 561376) I wish I had the influence over them which the friend credited me with.
('74', 298, 4, 16, 561448) If I had, I would certainly prevent them from com mitting suicide by inches.
('74', 298, 4, 17, 561525) What applies to these two Ministers applies to the others.
('74', 298, 4, 18, 561584) A few days after the visitor, came a high official who has been specially entrusted with responsible work by Shri Kher.
('74', 298, 4, 19, 561704) He said, “I want to fulfil Shri (of course he used ‘Mr.’) Kher’s expectations.
('74', 298, 4, 20, 561783) But I do not know how I am to give him satisfaction.
('74', 298, 4, 21, 561836) I believe I have always been a conscientious worker and kept myself busy.
('74', 298, 4, 22, 561910) But now since the advent of the Congress Ministry our work has increased.
('74', 298, 4, 23, 561984) For they give themselves no rest and give us none.
('74', 298, 4, 24, 562035) The result is an ever increasing pile of files.
('74', 298, 4, 25, 562083) It is almost impossible to clear the desk from day to day.
('74', 298, 4, 26, 562142) And now I have been given work which demands thinking out and planning.
('74', 298, 4, 27, 562214) I must study.
('74', 298, 4, 28, 562228) And I do not know what to do with these files.” I promptly answered, “Burn them.” I meant it too.
('74', 298, 4, 29, 562326) The third visitor, who followed quickly after the second, was a
('74', 299, 0, 1, 562390) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 300
('74', 299, 1, 2, 562432) socialist friend.
('74', 299, 1, 3, 562450) He said: “We are much misunderstood.
('74', 299, 1, 4, 562487) Your article on the walk out 1 has added to the misunderstanding.
('74', 299, 1, 5, 562553) I assure you we want to help, not to hinder, the Congress work and the Ministers, reserving to ourselves the right of constructive criticism.
('74', 299, 1, 6, 562695) But look at our difficulty.
('74', 299, 1, 7, 562723) There is the Karachi resolution and the Congress manifesto 2. We honestly feel that the promises made in them about economic relief are not being fully carried out.
('74', 299, 1, 8, 562888) I do not want to underrate the Congress Ministers’ difficulties.
('74', 299, 1, 9, 562953) But mere tinkering with the problem won’t do.
('74', 299, 1, 10, 562999) There are forces at work which no one can stop.
('74', 299, 1, 11, 563047) Advantage is being taken of the situation to put up the masses against the Congress.
('74', 299, 1, 12, 563132) The masses have the vote.
('74', 299, 1, 13, 563158) They are becoming otherwise conscious of their power.
('74', 299, 1, 14, 563212) And if we do not take care, the Congress may one fine morning discover that it has lost its hold (at least temporarily) on the masses.” I agreed in general with the friend and I said, “The reason for dissatisfaction is plain to me.
('74', 299, 1, 15, 563444) You have a philosophy of your own.
('74', 299, 1, 16, 563479) The Congress Ministries today are not of the socialist hue.
('74', 299, 1, 17, 563539) They are supposed to be of the ‘Gandhian’ hue, whatever it may mean.
('74', 299, 1, 18, 563608) Now, yours is a clear cut programme.
('74', 299, 1, 19, 563645) You have textbooks to go by.
('74', 299, 1, 20, 563674) But I myself do not know what is the Gandhian hue.
('74', 299, 1, 21, 563725) I am sailing on an uncharted sea.
('74', 299, 1, 22, 563759) I have to take frequent soundings.
('74', 299, 1, 23, 563794) If such is my pitiable condition, the Ministers’ is much worse.
('74', 299, 1, 24, 563858) They are so tied down to red tape that they have no time to think.
('74', 299, 1, 25, 563925) They have no time to see me or discuss things with me and, what is more or worse, know ing their condition, I have no heart to inflict even letters on them.
('74', 299, 1, 26, 564082) And I must not speak at them through the columns of Harijan.” I have touched on many topics in the foregoing paragraph.
('74', 299, 1, 27, 564202) But my main purpose in this article is to deal with red tape.
('74', 299, 1, 28, 564264) If the Ministers are to cope with their new responsibility, they must discover the art of burning red tape.
('74', 299, 1, 29, 564372) The old order could only live by and on red tape.
('74', 299, 1, 30, 564422) It will strangle the new order.
('74', 299, 1, 31, 564454) The Ministers must see people on whose goodwill alone they can exist.
('74', 299, 1, 32, 564524) They must listen to petty and serious complaints.
('74', 299, 1, 33, 564574) But they need not keep a record of all these or the letters they receive nor even of all the decisions they give.
('74', 299, 1, 34, 564688) They have only to keep sufficient record to refresh their memory and to preserve continuity of practice.
('74', 299, 1, 35, 564793) Much of the departmental correspondence
('74', 299, 2, 36, 564833) 1 Vide “That Unfortunate Walk Out” 2 Vide “Extracts from the congress election Menifesto”, 22 4 1936
('74', 300, 0, 1, 564934) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 301
('74', 300, 1, 2, 564982) must cease.
('74', 300, 1, 3, 564994) The Ministers are not responsible to the India Office several thousand miles away.
('74', 300, 1, 4, 565077) They are responsible to the millions of their masters who do not know what red tape is and care little.
('74', 300, 1, 5, 565181) Many of them can’t read and write.
('74', 300, 1, 6, 565216) But they have primary wants to be ful filled.
('74', 300, 1, 7, 565262) They have been accustomed by Congressmen to think that immediately the Congress comes into power there won’t be a hungry mouth in all India nor a naked person who wants to cover himself.
('74', 300, 1, 8, 565449) The Ministers have to give their time and thought to such problems, if they are to do justice to the trust they have undertaken.
('74', 300, 1, 9, 565578) If they are of the so called Gandhian hue, they must find out what it is, not from me but from within by searching inward.
('74', 300, 1, 10, 565701) I may not always know what it is.
('74', 300, 1, 11, 565735) But I do know that if it is properly investigated and followed, it is radical and revolutionary enough to satisfy all the real wants of India.
('74', 300, 1, 12, 565878) The Congress is a revolutionary body.
('74', 300, 1, 13, 565916) Only its revolution is to be distinguished from all the other political revolutions known to history.
('74', 300, 1, 14, 566018) Whereas the previous ones have been based on violence, this one is deliberately non violent.
('74', 300, 1, 15, 566111) If it was violent, probably much of the old form and practice would have been retained.
('74', 300, 1, 16, 566199) But, for the Congress most of the old forms and practices are taboo.
('74', 300, 1, 17, 566268) The most potent is the police and the military.
('74', 300, 1, 18, 566316) I have admitted that so long as Congressmen are in office and they cannot discover peaceful ways and means of preserving order they are bound to make use of both.
('74', 300, 1, 19, 566479) But the question ever present before the Ministers must be: is such use indispensable, and if it is, why is it so?
('74', 300, 1, 20, 566594) If, as a result of their inquiry— not after the old style, costly and more often than not useless, but an inquiry costless but thorough and effective—they find that they cannot run the State without the use of the police and the military, it is the clearest possible sign, in terms of non violence, that the Congress should give up office and again wander in the wilderness in search of the Holy Grail.

('74', 302, 1, 2, 568146) 404. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR
('74', 302, 2, 3, 568175) December 9, 1938
('74', 302, 3, 4, 568192) LILA, I was very much pained by today’s incident.
('74', 302, 3, 5, 568242) But how could you help your nature?
('74', 302, 3, 6, 568278) However, my purpose in writing this is different.
('74', 302, 3, 7, 568328) I have noticed that you and Amtul Salaam cannot tolerate S. 1 sleeping with me.
('74', 302, 3, 8, 568408) Whatever may be the cause, I do not want to carry on my experiment by displeasing you two.
('74', 302, 3, 9, 568499) I, therefore, want to tell both of you that I have discontinued my experiment for the present.
('74', 302, 3, 10, 568594) The fault is not yours.
('74', 302, 3, 11, 568618) I believe it is entirely mine.
('74', 302, 3, 12, 568649) But I do not wish to discuss the matter with you, nor do I want you to reply.
('74', 302, 3, 13, 568727) I have simply informed you.
('74', 302, 3, 14, 568755) Show this letter to Amtul Salaam.

('74', 305, 6, 15, 573400) 411. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('74', 305, 7, 16, 573428) December 10, 1938
('74', 305, 8, 17, 573446) Having obtained the permission of the President of the Travan core State Congress, I am now able to tell the public what advice I gave the deputation that saw me on November 13 and 14. 1 I told them that their cause would be damaged by persistence in the charges against the Dewan and that the question was not one of the truth or otherwise of the charges.
('74', 305, 8, 18, 573803) 2 It was one of political insight.
('74', 305, 8, 19, 573838) Allegations were made that the struggle was personal.
('74', 305, 8, 20, 573892) The demand for responsible government made it impersonal and raised it to a higher level.
('74', 305, 8, 21, 573982) I could not be a party to the conduct of a struggle which must engage and exhaust time and energy in pursuit of a personal matter to the ex clusion of the most important one of swaraj.
('74', 305, 8, 22, 574167) If they concentrated on the allegations, responsible government was bound to recede into the background.
('74', 305, 9, 23, 574272) 1 The deputation actually saw Gandhiji on the 15th; vide “Talk to Travancore State Congress Deputation”, 15 11 1938 2 Vide also “Statement to the Press”, 3 10 1938
('74', 306, 0, 1, 574436) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 307
('74', 306, 1, 2, 574484) Though my conviction about the correctness of my advice was unshaken, the members were to be guided by their own, if it conflicted with mine, for the burden of conducting the struggle rested on them.
('74', 306, 1, 3, 574684) I also told them that if violence continued, no matter how it occurred, they were bound to suspend civil disobedience; for violence on the part of the public, even though instigated, showed that the State Con gress influence was not adequate.
('74', 306, 1, 4, 574927) This in no way meant suspension of the struggle.
('74', 306, 1, 5, 574976) It meant merely a change of the emphasis on the instru ments.
('74', 306, 1, 6, 575038) An instrument of permanent value was a constructive pro gramme.
('74', 306, 1, 7, 575102) The employment of civil disobedience had well defined limitations and required suspension as the occasion demanded.
('74', 306, 2, 8, 575218) Harijan, 17 12 1938
('74', 306, 3, 9, 575238) 412. DISCUSSION WITH CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES 1
('74', 306, 4, 10, 575284) [Before December 12, 1938] 2
('74', 306, 5, 11, 575313) One of the questioners asked Gandhiji what his motive in life was, “the thing that leads us to do what we do”, whether it was religious, or social or political.
('74', 306, 6, 12, 575474) GANDHIJI: Purely religious.
('74', 306, 6, 13, 575502) This was the question asked me by the late Mr. Montagu when I accompanied a deputation which was purely political.
('74', 306, 6, 14, 575617) “How you, a social reformer,” he exclaimed, have “found your way into this crowd ?” My reply was that it was only an extension of my social activity.
('74', 306, 6, 15, 575767) I could not be leading a religious life unless I identified myself with the whole of mankind, and that I could not do unless I took part in politics.
('74', 306, 6, 16, 575917) The whole gamut of man’s activi ties today constitutes an indivisible whole.
('74', 306, 6, 17, 575994) You cannot divide social, economic, political and purely religious work into watertight compart ments.
('74', 306, 6, 18, 576097) I do not know any religion apart from human activity.
('74', 306, 6, 19, 576151) It pro vides a moral basis to all other activities which they would otherwise lack, reducing life to a maze of sound and fury signifying nothing!
('74', 306, 7, 20, 576297) QUESTION: Seeing the influence you wield over the people, may we inquire whether it is the love of the cause or the love of the people that moves you?
('74', 306, 8, 21, 576448) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Non violence and World Crisis”.
('74', 306, 8, 22, 576509) The missionaries included William Paton, Secretary of the International Missionary Council, Leslie B. Moss, Secretary of the Conference of Missionary Societies in North America, Dr. Smith of the British and Foreign Bible Society and John Mott.
('74', 306, 8, 23, 576753) They were in India to attend the International Missionary Conference which opened at Tambaram on December 12, 1938. 2 ibid
('74', 307, 0, 1, 576876) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 308
('74', 307, 1, 2, 576918) ANSWER: Love of the people.
('74', 307, 1, 3, 576946) Cause without the people is a dead thing.
('74', 307, 1, 4, 576988) Love of the people brought the problem of untouchability early into my life.
('74', 307, 1, 5, 577065) My mother said, ‘You must not touch this boy, he is an untouchable.’ ‘Why not?’ I questioned back, and from that day my revolt began.
('74', 307, 2, 6, 577199) Q. You would expect us Christians to copy your example.
('74', 307, 2, 7, 577255) Should we allow our religious motive to plunge us into politics?
('74', 307, 3, 8, 577320) A. Those who come from different parts of the world into this country cannot say: ‘We shall have nothing to do with the politics of the country.’ They would not be true to their faith if they bargained with the Government in order to supersede their fellow feeling with the people.
('74', 307, 3, 9, 577602) Supposing the Government does a grievous wrong to the people of the soil and the missionaries are told that they must not lift a finger to prevent it, surely, the least they can do is to leave the country by way of signifying their displeasure at the perpetration of the wrong.
('74', 307, 3, 10, 577880) If a missionary puts himself out for service, opportunities will come: today it may be in the economic sphere, tomorrow in the social, next time it may be in the political field.
('74', 307, 3, 11, 578059) You cannot then say, ‘I shall confine myself to this or that work and do nothing else.’ When I went to South Africa I knew nothing about that country.
('74', 307, 3, 12, 578210) I was bound to my client only.
('74', 307, 3, 13, 578241) Yet, within seven days of my reaching there, I found that I had to deal with a situation too terrible for words.
('74', 307, 4, 14, 578354) Gandhiji was next asked in what relation his non violence stood to the Pacifist attitude, “which we Westerners are trying to adopt without much success.”
('74', 307, 5, 15, 578508) GANDHIJI: In my opinion non violence is not passivity in any shape or form.
('74', 307, 5, 16, 578584) Non violence, as I understand it, is the activest force in the world.
('74', 307, 5, 17, 578654) Therefore, whether it is materialism or anything else, if non violence does not provide an effective antidote it is not the active force of my conception.
('74', 307, 5, 18, 578809) Or, to put it conversely, if you bring me some conundrums that I cannot answer I would say my non violence is still defective.
('74', 307, 5, 19, 578936) Non violence is the supreme law.
('74', 307, 5, 20, 578969) During my half a century of experience I have not yet come across a situation when I had to say that I was helpless, that I had no remedy in terms of non violence.
('74', 307, 5, 21, 579133) Take the question of the Jews on which I have written.
('74', 307, 5, 22, 579188) 1 No Jew need feel helpless if he takes to the non violent way.
('74', 307, 5, 23, 579252) A friend has written me a letter objecting that in that article I have assumed that the
('74', 307, 6, 24, 579340) 1 Vide “The Jews”
('74', 308, 0, 1, 579358) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 309
('74', 308, 1, 2, 579406) Jews have been violent.
('74', 308, 1, 3, 579430) It is true that the Jews have not been actively violent in their own persons.
('74', 308, 1, 4, 579508) But they called down upon the Germans the curses of mankind, and they wanted America and England to fight Germany on their behalf.
('74', 308, 1, 5, 579639) If I hit my adversary, that is of course violence, but to be truly non violent, I must love him and pray for him even when he hits me.
('74', 308, 1, 6, 579774) The Jews have not been actively non violent or, in spite of the misdeeds of the dictators, they would say, ‘We shall suffer at their hands; they knew no better.
('74', 308, 1, 7, 579935) But we shall suffer not in the manner in which they want us to suffer.’ If even one Jew acted thus, he would salve his self respect and leave an example which, if it became infectious, would save the whole of Jewry and leave a rich heritage to mankind besides.
('74', 308, 1, 8, 580196) What about China, you will ask.
('74', 308, 1, 9, 580228) The Chinese have no designs upon other people.
('74', 308, 1, 10, 580275) They have no desire for territory.
('74', 308, 1, 11, 580310) True, perhaps, China is not ready for such aggression; perhaps, what looks like her pacifism is only indolence.
('74', 308, 1, 12, 580422) In any case China’s is not active non violence.
('74', 308, 1, 13, 580470) Her putting up a valiant defence against Japan is proof enough that China was never intentionally non violent.
('74', 308, 1, 14, 580581) That she is on the defensive is no answer in terms of non violence.
('74', 308, 1, 15, 580649) Therefore, when the time for testing her active non violence came, she failed in the test.
('74', 308, 1, 16, 580740) This is no criticism of China.
('74', 308, 1, 17, 580771) I wish the Chinese success.
('74', 308, 1, 18, 580799) According to the accepted standards her behaviour is strictly correct.
('74', 308, 1, 19, 580870) But when the position is examined in terms of non violence, I must say it is un becoming for a nation of 400 millions, a nation as cultured as Japan [sic], to repel Japanese aggression by resorting to Japan’s own methods.
('74', 308, 1, 20, 581092) If the Chinese had non violence of my conception, there would be no use left for the latest machinery for destruction which Japan possesses.
('74', 308, 1, 21, 581233) The Chinese would say to Japan, ‘Bring all your machinery, we present half of our population to you.
('74', 308, 1, 22, 581334) But the remain ing two hundred millions won’t bend their knee to you.’ If the Chi nese did that, Japan would become China’s slave.
('74', 308, 2, 23, 581465) And in support of this argument he referred to Shelley’s celebrated lines from The Mask of Anarchy, “Ye are many, they are few”:
('74', 308, 3, 24, 581594) Stand ye calm and resolute,
('74', 308, 4, 25, 581622) Like a forest close and mute,
('74', 308, 5, 26, 581652) With folded arms and looks which are
('74', 308, 6, 27, 581689) Weapons of unvanquished war.
('74', 308, 7, 28, 581718) And if then the tyrants dare
('74', 308, 8, 29, 581747) Let them ride among you there,
('74', 309, 0, 1, 581778) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 310
('74', 309, 1, 2, 581820) Slash, and stab, and maim and hew—
('74', 309, 2, 3, 581855) What they like, that let them do.
('74', 309, 3, 4, 581889) With folded arms and steady eyes,
('74', 309, 4, 5, 581923) And little fear, and less surprise,
('74', 309, 5, 6, 581959) Look upon them as they slay
('74', 309, 6, 7, 581987) Till their rage has died away.
('74', 309, 7, 8, 582018) Then they will return with shame
('74', 309, 8, 9, 582051) To the place from which they came,
('74', 309, 9, 10, 582086) And the blood thus shed will speak
('74', 309, 10, 11, 582121) In hot blushes on their cheek.
('74', 309, 11, 12, 582152) Rise like Lions after slumber
('74', 309, 12, 13, 582182) In unvanquishable number,
('74', 309, 13, 14, 582208) Shake your chains to earth like dew
('74', 309, 14, 15, 582244) Which in sleep had fallen on you—
('74', 309, 15, 16, 582278) Ye are many—they are few.
('74', 309, 15, 17, 582304) It has been objected, however, that non violence is all right in the case of the Jews because there is personal contact between the individual and his persecutors, but in China, Japan comes with its long range guns and aeroplanes.
('74', 309, 15, 18, 582535) The person who rains death from above has never any chance of even knowing who and how many he has killed.
('74', 309, 15, 19, 582642) How can non violence combat aerial warfare, seeing that there are no personal contacts?
('74', 309, 15, 20, 582730) The reply to this is that behind the death dealing bomb there is the human hand that releases it, and behind that still, is the human heart that sets the hand in motion.
('74', 309, 15, 21, 582900) And at the back of the policy of terrorism is the assumption that terrorism if applied in a sufficient measure will produce the desired result, namely, bend the adversary to the tyrant’s will.
('74', 309, 15, 22, 583093) But supposing a people make up their mind that they will never do the tyrant’s will, nor retaliate with the tyrant’s own methods, the tyrant will not find it worth his while to go on with his terrorism.
('74', 309, 15, 23, 583296) If sufficient food is given to the tyrant, a time will come when he will have had more than surfeit.
('74', 309, 15, 24, 583397) If all the mice in the world held conference together and resolved that they would no more fear the cat but all run into her mouth, the mice would live.
('74', 309, 15, 25, 583550) I have actually seen a cat play with a mouse.
('74', 309, 15, 26, 583596) She did not kill it outright but held it between her jaws, then released it, and again pouched upon it as soon as it made an effort to escape.
('74', 309, 15, 27, 583739) In the end the mouse died out of sheer fright.
('74', 309, 15, 28, 583786) The cat would have derived no sport if the mouse had not tried to run away.
('74', 309, 15, 29, 583862) I learnt
('74', 310, 0, 1, 583871) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 311
('74', 310, 1, 2, 583919) the lesson of non violence from my wife, when I tried to bend her to my will.
('74', 310, 1, 3, 583997) Her determined resistance to my will on the one hand, and her quiet submission to the suffering my stupidity involved on the other, ultimately made me ashamed of myself and cured me of my stupidity in thinking that I was born to rule over her, and in the end she became my teacher in non violence.
('74', 310, 1, 4, 584295) And what I did in South Africa was but an extension of the rule of satyagraha which she unwillingly practised in her own person.
('74', 310, 2, 5, 584424) But one of the visitors objected: You do not know Hitler and Mussolini.
('74', 310, 2, 6, 584496) They are incapable of any kind of moral response.
('74', 310, 2, 7, 584546) They have no conscience and they have made themselves impervious to world opinion.
('74', 310, 2, 8, 584629) Would it not be playing into the hands of these dictators if, for instance, the Czechs following your advice confronted them with non violence?
('74', 310, 2, 9, 584773) Seeing that dictatorships are unmoral by definition, would the law of moral conversion hold good in their case?
('74', 310, 3, 10, 584885) GANDHIJI: Your argument presupposes that the dictators like Mussolini or Hitler are beyond redemption.
('74', 310, 3, 11, 584988) But belief in non violence is based on the assumption that human nature in its essence is one and therefore unfailingly responds to the advances of love.
('74', 310, 3, 12, 585142) It should be remembered that they have up to now always found ready response to the violence that they have used.
('74', 310, 3, 13, 585256) Within their experience, they have not come across organized non violent resistance on an appreciable scale, if at all.
('74', 310, 3, 14, 585376) Therefore, it is not only highly likely, but I hold it to be inevitable, that they would recognize the superiority of non violent resistance over any display of violence that they may be capable of putting forth.
('74', 310, 3, 15, 585589) Moreover the non violent technique that I have pre sented to the Czechs does not depend for its success on the goodwill of the dictators, for, a non violent resister depends upon the unfailing assistance of God which sustains him throughout difficulties which would otherwise be considered insurmountable.
('74', 310, 3, 16, 585895) His faith makes him indomitable.
('74', 310, 4, 17, 585928) The visitor retorted that these dictators wisely refrain from using force, but simply take possession of what they want.
('74', 310, 4, 18, 586049) In the circumstances what can non violent resisters do?
('74', 310, 5, 19, 586105) GANDHIJI: Suppose they come and occupy mines, factories and all sources of natural wealth belonging to the Czechs, then the follow ing results can take place: (1) The Czechs may be annihilated for disobedience to orders.
('74', 310, 5, 20, 586326) That would be a glorious victory for the Czechs and the beginning of the fall of Germany.
('74', 310, 5, 21, 586416) (2) The Czechs might become demoralized in the presence of overwhelming force.
('74', 310, 5, 22, 586495) This is a result common in all struggles, but if demoralization does
('74', 311, 0, 1, 586564) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 312
('74', 311, 1, 2, 586606) take place, it would not be on account of non violence, but it would be due to absence or inadequacy of non violence (3) The third thing that can take place is that Germany might use her new possessions for occupation by her surplus population.
('74', 311, 1, 3, 586851) This, again, could not be avoided by offering violent resistance, for we have assumed that violent resistance is out of the question.
('74', 311, 1, 4, 586985) Thus non violent resistance is the best method under all conceivable circumstances.
('74', 311, 1, 5, 587069) I do not think that Hitler and Mussolini are after all so very indifferent to the appeal of world opinion.
('74', 311, 1, 6, 587176) But today these dictators feel satisfaction in defying world opinion because none of the so called Great Powers can come to them with clean hands, and they have a rankling sense of injustice done to their people by the Great Powers in the past.
('74', 311, 1, 7, 587421) Only the other day an esteemed English friend owned to me that Nazi Germany was England’s sin and that it was the Treaty of Versailles that made Hitler.
('74', 311, 2, 8, 587574) QUESTION: What can I as a Christian do to contribute to international peace?
('74', 311, 2, 9, 587651) How can international anarchy be broken down and non violence made effective for establishing peace?
('74', 311, 2, 10, 587752) Subject nations apart, how can nations at the top be made to disarm themselves?
('74', 311, 3, 11, 587832) ANSWER: You as a Christian can make an effective contribution by non violent action even though it may cost you your all.
('74', 311, 3, 12, 587954) Peace will never come until the Great Powers courageously decide to disarm themselves.
('74', 311, 3, 13, 588041) It seems to me that recent events must force that belief on the Great Powers.
('74', 311, 3, 14, 588119) I have an implicit faith— faith that today burns brighter than ever, after half a century’s experience of unbroken practice of non violence—that mankind can only be saved through non violence which is the central teaching of the Bible as I have understood the Bible.
('74', 311, 4, 15, 588386) Q. You have said that so far as India is concerned you are hopeful that it will stick to non violence.
('74', 311, 4, 16, 588489) What are the omens of that hope?
('74', 311, 5, 17, 588522) A. If you ask for outward proofs, I cannot give any.
('74', 311, 5, 18, 588575) But I have an instinctive feeling that the country is not going to take to anything else.
('74', 311, 5, 19, 588665) You must remember that just now I am filled with what I saw in the North West Frontier Province.
('74', 311, 5, 20, 588762) I was not prepared for what I saw.
('74', 311, 5, 21, 588797) They are in dead earnest about the thing, and there is a deep rooted sincerity in their hearts.
('74', 311, 5, 22, 588893) They themselves see light and hope in non violence.
('74', 311, 5, 23, 588945) Khan Saheb told me that before that it was all darkness.
('74', 311, 5, 24, 589002) There was not a family but had its blood feuds.
('74', 311, 5, 25, 589050) They lived like tigers in a den.
('74', 311, 5, 26, 589083) Though the Pathans used to be always armed with knives,
('74', 312, 0, 1, 589139) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 313
('74', 312, 1, 2, 589187) daggers and rifles, they used to be terrified of their superior officers, lest they should lose their jobs.
('74', 312, 1, 3, 589295) All that has changed now with thousands.
('74', 312, 1, 4, 589336) Blood feuds are becoming a thing of the past among those Pathans who have come under the influence of Khan Saheb’s non violence movement and, instead of depending for their livelihood on paltry jobs, they have turned to the soil for cultivation, and soon they will turn to industry if their promise is kept.
('74', 312, 2, 5, 589644) Q. What is your method of worship?
('74', 312, 3, 6, 589679) A. We have joint worship morning and evening at 4.20 a.
('74', 312, 3, 7, 589735) and 7 p.
('74', 312, 3, 8, 589744) This has gone on for years.
('74', 312, 3, 9, 589772) We have a recitation of verses from the Gita and other accepted religious books, also hymns of saints with or without music.
('74', 312, 3, 10, 589897) Individual worship cannot be described in words.
('74', 312, 3, 11, 589946) It goes on continuously and even uncon sciously.
('74', 312, 3, 12, 589995) There is not a moment when I do not feel the presence of a witness whose eye misses nothing and with whom I strive to keep in tune.
('74', 312, 3, 13, 590127) I do not pray as Christian friends do.
('74', 312, 3, 14, 590166) Not because I think there is anything wrong in it, but because words won’t come to me.
('74', 312, 3, 15, 590253) I suppose it is a matter of habit.
('74', 312, 4, 16, 590288) Q. Is there any place for supplication in your prayer?
('74', 312, 5, 17, 590343) A. There is and there is not.
('74', 312, 5, 18, 590373) God knows and anticipates our wants.
('74', 312, 5, 19, 590410) The Deity does not need my supplication, but I, a very im perfect human being, do need His protection as a child that of its father.
('74', 312, 5, 20, 590543) And yet I know that nothing that I do is going to change His plans.
('74', 312, 5, 21, 590611) You may call me a fatalist, if you like.
('74', 312, 6, 22, 590652) Q. Do you find any response to your prayer?
('74', 312, 7, 23, 590696) A. I consider myself a happy man in that respect.
('74', 312, 7, 24, 590746) I have never found Him lacking in response.
('74', 312, 7, 25, 590790) I have found Him nearest at hand when the horizon seemed darkest—in my ordeals in jails when it was not all smooth sailing for me.
('74', 312, 7, 26, 590921) I cannot recall a moment in my life when I had a sense of desertion by God.
('74', 312, 8, 27, 590997) Harijan, 24 12 1938
('74', 313, 0, 1, 591017) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 314
('74', 313, 1, 2, 591059) 413. MESSAGE TO C. K. GIBBON 1

('74', 313, 4, 5, 591252) The Bombay Chronicle, 13 12 1938
('74', 313, 5, 6, 591285) 414. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY
('74', 313, 6, 7, 591309) I read suggestions about a memorial to the late Maulana Shau kat Ali.
('74', 313, 6, 8, 591379) 3 As soon as I learnt about the wholly unexpected death, I wrote to some Muslim friends sharing with them my innermost thoughts.
('74', 313, 6, 9, 591508) One of them writes thus:
('74', 313, 7, 10, 591533) There can be no two opinions about the extreme urgency and essential necessity of a sincere and lasting Hindu Muslim unity.
('74', 313, 7, 11, 591657) And the sooner it is brought about the better it will be for all concerned.
('74', 313, 7, 12, 591733) Delay in this matter can only be fraught with consequences which nobody can contemplate without serious concern.
('74', 313, 7, 13, 591846) The present drift may lead to most tragic developments which must, if at all possible, be avoided.
('74', 313, 7, 14, 591945) I know that Shaukat was in his own way genuinely anxious to bring about real Hindu Muslim understanding, and nothing will please his spirit more than to know in its rest in heaven that one of the objects after which he strove in this world was at last achieved.
('74', 313, 7, 15, 592207) There may be people who may doubt this, but knowing him and the working of his mind most intimately as I do, I can assert it with confidence.
('74', 313, 7, 16, 592349) I entirely endorse the opinion that, in spite of his outbursts at times to the contrary, deep down in the Maulana was the same longing for peace for which he used to speak and work eloquently during the Khilafat days.
('74', 313, 7, 17, 592567) I have no doubt whatsoever that the truest memorial to his memory will be a joint determination on the part of both the com munities to bring about not a paper unity but a heart unity, based not on suspicion and distrust but on mutual trust.
('74', 313, 7, 18, 592809) No other unity is worth having.
('74', 313, 7, 19, 592841) And without that unity there is no real freedom for India.
('74', 313, 7, 20, 592900) SEGAON, December 12, 1938
('74', 313, 8, 21, 592926) Harijan, 17 12 1938
('74', 313, 9, 22, 592946) 1 General Secretary of the Anglo Indian Civil Liberties Association 2 The news item carrying the message is dated December 12, 1938. 3 Shaukat Ali died on November 27.

('74', 317, 1, 2, 596375) 421. A NOTE
('74', 317, 2, 3, 596387) [Before December 13, 1938] 1
('74', 317, 3, 4, 596416) In my view, we should not interfere with whatever the Princes are doing.
('74', 317, 3, 5, 596489) But why should not all the obnoxious portions of the Criminal Law Amendment Act be removed?
('74', 317, 3, 6, 596581) Let only the absolute minimum be retained.
('74', 317, 5, 7, 596624) Such a protest should be considered thoughtless.
('74', 317, 5, 8, 596673) We want to do away with all that is bad in the [Criminal Law Amendment] Act.
('74', 317, 5, 9, 596750) But why should we give up what is good in it?
('74', 317, 5, 10, 596796) The Working Committee should have the courage to lend its support to this much.
('74', 317, 5, 11, 596876) We must see the spirit [of the Law].
('74', 317, 5, 12, 596913) Why should we see only the letter of it?
('74', 317, 5, 13, 596954) I have been purposely silent because I could not have written fully in favour of the Princes.
('74', 317, 5, 14, 597048) I would be willing to write in their favour if they are agreeable to my suggestions.
('74', 317, 5, 15, 597133) Even there the condition would be that after reading the Act, you approve of my suggestions.
('74', 317, 5, 16, 597226) I do not know for certain that the [present] use of the sections is necessary.
('74', 317, 5, 17, 597305) If it is necessary, I would certainly say so.
('74', 317, 6, 18, 597351) From the Hindi original: Rajendra Prasad Papers.
('74', 317, 6, 19, 597400) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('74', 317, 7, 20, 597437) 1 The note has been placed in the source among items of 1938. It appears from the contents that it was written before the Working Committee’s resolution on Indian States drafted by Gandhiji on December 13, 1938; vide, ”Draftof Congress Working Committee Resolution on Indian States”, 13 12 1938
('74', 318, 0, 1, 597732) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 319
('74', 318, 1, 2, 597780) 422. INTERVIEW TO CELESTINE SMITH 1
('74', 318, 2, 3, 597816) [Before December 13, 1938] 2
('74', 318, 3, 4, 597845) I had never thought of a girl coming.
('74', 318, 3, 5, 597883) To take the responsibility of a girl so far away from her home would perhaps be a bit too much.
('74', 318, 3, 6, 597979) But as you can see I have plenty of girls around me here, and if a girl did come from America like that, I should not mind it a bit, i.
('74', 318, 3, 7, 598115) e., if she could put up with the incredibly simple life here as it would appear to her.
('74', 318, 3, 8, 598203) What she can learn from here and take back is the secret of simple living.
('74', 318, 3, 9, 598278) However simple life may be in America, it cannot come anywhere near the simplicity of life here.
('74', 318, 3, 10, 598375) I do not know if America can assimilate such simplicity, or wants it.
('74', 318, 3, 11, 598445) The other thing that she could take back is the spirit of non violence, to the extent that she can assimilate it without the help of any words or speeches, if there is non violence in the atmosphere here.
('74', 318, 3, 12, 598650) If there is no non violence in the atmosphere, no written or spoken word can make her understand it or grasp it.
('74', 318, 4, 13, 598763) Harijan, 31 12 1938
('74', 318, 5, 14, 598783) 423. DRAFT OF CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON INDIAN STATES 3
('74', 318, 6, 15, 598854) December 13, 1938
('74', 318, 7, 16, 598872) The Working Committee welcome the awakening of the people of Indian States in many parts of the country and consider this as a hopeful prelude to the larger freedom, comprising the whole of India, for which the Congress has laboured.
('74', 318, 7, 17, 599106) The Committee support the demand for civil liberty and responsible government under the aegis
('74', 318, 8, 18, 599200) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('74', 318, 8, 19, 599245) Celestine Smith was the Secretary of the Negro Section of the Young Women’s Christian Association, New York.
('74', 318, 8, 20, 599354) She was impressed with the Wardha scheme of education and wanted to know whether she could send one of her girls and, if she did, what she would learn and take back to America.
('74', 318, 8, 21, 599531) 2 A photograph of Gandhiji with Celestine Smith was published in The Bombay Chronicle of December 13, which would indicate that they had met before that date.
('74', 318, 8, 22, 599690) 3 The Indian Annual Register, in the Chronicle of Events, notes under the date December 13 that Gandhiji drafted this resolution.
('74', 319, 0, 1, 599820) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 320
('74', 319, 1, 2, 599862) of the Rulers in the States and express their solidarity with these move ments for freedom and self expression.
('74', 319, 1, 3, 599974) While appreciating that some Rulers of the States have recognized this awakening as a healthy sign of growth and are seeking to adjust themselves to it in co ope ration with their people, the Committee regret that other Rulers have sought to suppress these movements by banning peaceful and legitimate organizations and all political activity and, in some cases, resorting to cruel and inhuman repression.
('74', 319, 1, 4, 600380) In particular, the Committee deplore the attempt of some Rulers to seek the aid of the British Government in India to suppress their own people, and the Committee assert the right of the Congress to protect the people against an unwarranted use of military or police forces, lent by the British authorities, for the suppression of the legitimate movement of the people for responsible government within the States.
('74', 319, 1, 5, 600795) The Committee desire to draw attention afresh to the resolution of the Haripura Congress which defines Congress policy in regard to the States.
('74', 319, 1, 6, 600939) While it is the right and privilege of the Congress to work for the attainment of civil liberty and responsible government in the States, existing circumstances impose certain limitations on this work, and considerations of prudence prevent the Congress from interfering organizationally and directly in the internal struggles of the States.
('74', 319, 1, 7, 601281) This policy was conceived in the best interests of the people, to enable them to develop self reliance and strength.
('74', 319, 1, 8, 601398) It was also intended as a measure of the goodwill of the Congress towards the States and of its hope that the Rulers, of their own accord, would recognize the spirit of the times and satisfy the just aspirations of their people.
('74', 319, 1, 9, 601627) Experience has proved the wisdom of this policy.
('74', 319, 1, 10, 601676) But this was never conceived as an obligation.
('74', 319, 1, 11, 601723) The Congress has always reserved the right, as it is its duty, to guide the people of the States and lend them its influence.
('74', 319, 1, 12, 601849) With the great awakening that is taking place among the people of the States, there must be an increasing identification of the Congress with States’ people.
('74', 319, 1, 13, 602007) The policy laid down by the Haripura Congress, which has been so abundantly justified, must continue to be pursued.
('74', 319, 1, 14, 602123) While, therefore, the Working Committee welcome the movements in the States for the attainment of responsible government, they advise the people not belonging to the States concerned against taking part in civil disobe dience and the like.
('74', 319, 1, 15, 602363) Participation by such people will bring no real strength to the movement, and may even embarrass the people of the
('74', 320, 0, 1, 602478) VOL. 74: 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 321
('74', 320, 1, 2, 602526) States concerned and prevent them from developing a mass movement on which strength and success depend.
('74', 320, 1, 3, 602630) The Committee trust that all movements in the States will adhere strictly to the fundamental Congress policy of non violence.
('74', 320, 2, 4, 602756) Indian National Congress, February 1938 to January 1939, pp.

('74', 323, 5, 7, 606649) SION THAT THE ALLEGATIONS MADE AGAINST THE DEWAN
('74', 323, 6, 8, 606698) IN THE MEMORANDUM SUBMITTED TO HIS HIGHNESS SHOULD
('74', 323, 7, 9, 606749) BE UNRESERVEDLY WITHDRAWN IN THE INTEREST OF THE
('74', 323, 8, 10, 606798) LARGER STRUGGLE FOR RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT.

('74', 323, 11, 13, 606934) SELVES TO THE CAUSE AND TO THE PUBLIC IF WE DID

('74', 323, 13, 15, 607035) A FULL SENSE OF RESPONSIBILIT AND WITH A
('74', 323, 14, 16, 607076) BELIEF IN THEM AS FULL AS IT IS POSSIBLE TO HAVE IN A STATEMENT BASED UPON ONE SIDED EVIDENCE.
('74', 323, 14, 17, 607171) OUR BELIEF IN THE TRUTH OF THE ALLEGATIONS MADE PERSISTS BUT THE OPINION HAS FORCED ITSELF UPON US THAT FOR US TO PERSIST IN THOSE ALLEGATIONS WOULD BE TO HARM THE GREAT STRUGGLE FOR RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT IN TRAVANCORE.
('74', 323, 14, 18, 607392) WE THEREFORE WITHDRAW THE ALLEGATIONS AND ASK THE PUBLIC NOT TO BE AFFECTED BY THE ALLEGATIONS OR BY OUR BELIEF IN THEM.
('74', 323, 14, 19, 607513) IN CASE PROSECUTION IS PURSUED IN SPITE OF ABOVE WITHDRAWAL ADD LATER IN COURT AS FOLLOWS.
('74', 323, 14, 20, 607604) WE ARE SORRY THAT THE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR IS NOT SATISFIED WITH OUR WITHDRAWAL OF THE ALLEGATIONS.
('74', 323, 14, 21, 607701) WE SHALL CHEERFULLY UNDERGO ANY SENTENCE THAT MAY BE IMPOSED UPON US FOR OUR UNCONDITIONAL WITHDRAWAL MEANS THAT WE HAVE WITHDRAWN THE ALLEGATIONS NOT TO EVADE THE CONSEQUENCES OF THE LAW BUT FOR HELPING THE LARGER CAUSE OF RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT.
('74', 323, 14, 22, 607949) WE THEREFORE DO NOT PROPOSE TO ENTER UPON ANY DEFENCE AND AS WE HAVE WITHDRAWN THE ALLEGATIONS IT IS NOT POSSIBLE FOR US TO PLEAD GUILTY.
