('74', 449, 1, 2, 851196) 582. SPEECH AT MEETING OF PEASANTS 1
('74', 449, 2, 3, 851233) BARDOLI, January 26, 1939
('74', 449, 3, 4, 851259) I went through the resolutions you have passed before coming here.
('74', 449, 3, 5, 851326) Let me congratulate both the parties on it.
('74', 449, 3, 6, 851370) Sardar has said that you have passed these resolutions with God as your witness.
('74', 449, 3, 7, 851451) You have already had some experience of what happens when a man breaks his vow.
('74', 449, 3, 8, 851531) I do hope that you will fully adhere to these resolutions.
('74', 449, 3, 9, 851590) Quite often, when people do not make such resolutions of their own accord, law compels them to do so, which carries with it some kind of punish ment.
('74', 449, 3, 10, 851740) It is a good thing that you have passed these resolutions of your own free will.
('74', 449, 3, 11, 851821) It is not an ordinary thing that the Dublas have ceased to be serfs and have become free.
('74', 449, 3, 12, 851911) Of course, these resolutions gave me an impression that the peasants in this part are big businessmen for, through these resolutions they have indeed struck a big bargain.
('74', 449, 3, 13, 852083) What is so great about paying fair daily wages to the Dublas for the full quota of work whereas formerly they were made to work as much as the owners desired?
('74', 449, 3, 14, 852242) I am not greatly impressed by it.
('74', 449, 3, 15, 852276) According to me, any man or woman must get the minimum wage of 8 annas for 8 hours of work.
('74', 449, 3, 16, 852368) God willing, such conditions will be created in my lifetime.
('74', 449, 3, 17, 852429) You may find 8 annas a big thing; but it really is not so big.
('74', 449, 3, 18, 852492) But you have fixed 3 annas as the wages for a woman labourer, where as you will take the same amount of work from her.
('74', 449, 3, 19, 852611) Do you think
('74', 449, 4, 20, 852624) 1 The meeting, with an attendance of between 10 and 15 thousand landowners and Halis or Dublas, was held to approve the recommendations made by a committee of farmers and village workers, formed in the previous year to consider the question of the emancipation of Halis whose status was that of serfs.
('74', 449, 4, 21, 852926) The committee had made the following recommendations: (1) Every Hali to be emancipated, the wages from 26th January 1939 to be as.
('74', 449, 4, 22, 853057) 4/6 (for males) and as.
('74', 449, 4, 23, 853081) 3/ (for females); (2) every Hali who has worked on his master’s farm for twelve years or more is automatically free from all his debts to him; (3) such Halis as may have worked for less than twelve years to have credited to their account a twelfth of the debt for every year that they have worked; (4) an anna per day to be deducted from the wage, in the case of men, until the debt is repaid; (5) everyone to be declared free from debt on expiry of 12 years, whether the debt be paid or not; (6) every debt to expire with the debtor’s life; (7) a Dubla may engage himself on an annual wage of Rs. 80, and Rs. 15 may be deducted from his wage for repayment of a debt due if any; (8) a village committee to be appointed to settle all questions pertaining to debts.
('74', 450, 0, 1, 853845) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 451
('74', 450, 1, 2, 853894) those people will run away from you?
('74', 450, 1, 3, 853931) Hence, even while congratu lating you, I tell you that you have struck a bargain.
('74', 450, 1, 4, 854013) I would like to insist that you should not take the resolution too literally.
('74', 450, 1, 5, 854091) Do not think that you can never pay more than 4_ annas and 3 annas.
('74', 450, 1, 6, 854159) The very fact that you have made them free implies that they are free to work wherever they choose and earn the wages they can.
('74', 450, 1, 7, 854287) The great significance of this resolution is that they will remain where they are and your relations will be pure.
('74', 450, 1, 8, 854402) The fact that a Dubla ceases to be a serf and becomes a ploughman does not mean that the farmer will not plough the land.
('74', 450, 1, 9, 854524) The plough will belong to the farmer and the Dubla will use it for him.
('74', 450, 1, 10, 854596) But the real ploughman, in fact, is the tiller of the land and the ideal condition will be that in which both the farmer and the serf become ploughmen.
('74', 450, 1, 11, 854748) Further, the resolution does not mean that even when it has been a good year and there are bumper crops you will pay only 4_ annas as wages.
('74', 450, 1, 12, 854889) If you do so, I would say that you have not carried out your resolution.
('74', 450, 1, 13, 854962) You had taken the great vow of independence in 1921. You have not yet fulfilled the major part of it.
('74', 450, 1, 14, 855064) What you have done now should have been done in 1921. This means that you delayed what should have been done many years ago.
('74', 450, 1, 15, 855189) Nevertheless, I congratulate you as this is a meritorious act.
('74', 450, 1, 16, 855252) Agriculture is our basic occupation.
('74', 450, 1, 17, 855289) But we are not very good agriculturists, because our farming does not keep us busy throughout the year.
('74', 450, 1, 18, 855393) Nor does it give us enough to eat.
('74', 450, 1, 19, 855428) That is why I have described the charkha as Annapurna and praise it even today as much as I did formerly.
('74', 450, 1, 20, 855534) Hence, if the farmers want to make progress, they will have to supplement their income by taking to the charkha.
('74', 450, 1, 21, 855647) Thus you should devote all your free time to the charkha.
('74', 450, 1, 22, 855705) I hope the resolutions will be implemented by both the parties.

('74', 452, 7, 8, 857690) 587. DRAFT OF STATEMENT FOR JAMNALAL BAJAJ 1
('74', 452, 8, 9, 857735) BARDOLI, January 28, 1939
('74', 452, 9, 10, 857761) The Prime Minister of Jaipur is reported to have vowed to crush the Jaipur Rajya Praja Mandal and me.
('74', 452, 9, 11, 857863) In pursuance of that policy I have been put out of harm’s way as they may think.
('74', 452, 9, 12, 857944) Presently the same fate will overtake the members of the Mandal.
('74', 452, 9, 13, 858009) But if we are true to ourselves and our self imposed trust, though our bodies may be imprisoned or otherwise injured, our spirits shall be free.
('74', 452, 9, 14, 858154) As I go into enforced silence let me reiterate what we are figh ting for.
('74', 452, 9, 15, 858228) Our goal is responsible government under the Maharaja but our civil disobedience has not been taken up so as to influence the Durbar to grant us responsible government.
('74', 452, 9, 16, 858397) Civil disobedience is aimed at asserting the elementary right that belongs to all societies, to speak and write freely, to assemble in meetings, to take out proces sions, to form associations, etc., so long as these activities remain non violent.
('74', 452, 9, 17, 858644) We have been forced to resort to civil disobedience because this elementary right has been denied to us.
('74', 452, 9, 18, 858749) The moment this right is restored civil disobedience should be withdrawn.
('74', 452, 9, 19, 858823) Hence there is no question as yet of mass civil disobedience or a no tax campaign.
('74', 452, 9, 20, 858906) Seeing that the Mandal has been virtually declared an illegal
('74', 452, 10, 21, 858968) 1 This was to be issued by Jamnalal Bajaj at the time of his arrest.

('74', 453, 1, 2, 859135) body, let us regard our existing register to be abrogated.

('74', 453, 3, 13, 860137) 588. DISCUSSION WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF MUNICIPALITIES AND LOCAL BOARDS 2
('74', 453, 4, 14, 860211) BARDOLI, January 28, 1939
('74', 453, 5, 15, 860237) The first question they asked related to the question of taxation:
('74', 453, 6, 16, 860304) The Congress is pledged to the policy of reducing the burden of taxation.
('74', 453, 6, 17, 860378) Yet when Congressmen enter the local boards and municipalities, they required more money for carrying out their programme of beneficent municipal activity.
('74', 453, 6, 18, 860534) How can this be done without fresh taxation which the people naturally dislike?
('74', 453, 6, 19, 860614) How is the dilemma to be solved?
('74', 453, 7, 20, 860647) A. If I were a tax payer within the jurisdiction of a local board or a municipality, I would refuse to pay a single pie by way of addi tional taxation and advise others to do likewise unless the money we pay is returned fourfold.
('74', 453, 7, 21, 860877) Those who enter local boards and munici palities as people’s representatives go there not to seek honour or to indulge in mutual rivalries, but to render a service of love, and that does not depend upon money.
('74', 453, 7, 22, 861087) Ours is a pauper country.
('74', 453, 8, 23, 861113) 1 Omission as in the source 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Municipal Service and Non violence”.
('74', 453, 8, 24, 861207) About 200 representatives of municipalities and local boards had met Gandhiji to discuss the various knotty problems relating to their day to day work.
('74', 454, 0, 1, 861359) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 455
('74', 454, 1, 2, 861408) municipal councillors are imbued with a real spirit of service, they will convert themselves into unpaid sweepers, Bhangis and road makers, and take pride in doing so.
('74', 454, 1, 3, 861576) They will invite their fellow councillors, who may not have come on the Congress ticket, to join them, and if they have faith in themselves and their mission, their example will not fail to evoke response.
('74', 454, 1, 4, 861782) This means that a municipal councillor has to be a whole timer.
('74', 454, 1, 5, 861846) He should have no axe of his own to grind.
('74', 454, 1, 6, 861889) The next step would be to map out the entire adult population within the jurisdiction of the municipality or the local board.
('74', 454, 1, 7, 862015) All should be asked to make their contribution to municipal activity.
('74', 454, 1, 8, 862085) A regular register should be maintained.
('74', 454, 1, 9, 862126) Those who are too poor to make any money contribution but are able bodied and physically fit, can be asked to give their free labour.
('74', 454, 1, 10, 862260) Real India consists not of a few big cities and our Presidency towns, but of seven lakhs of villages.
('74', 454, 1, 11, 862362) It is there that the real problems of India have to be faced and solved.
('74', 454, 1, 12, 862435) We require better roads, better sanitation, better drinking water supply for our villages.
('74', 454, 1, 13, 862526) We shall never be able to get through even a fraction of this stupendous work if we proceed on a money basis.
('74', 454, 1, 14, 862636) But India has an inexhaustible reserve of manpower.
('74', 454, 1, 15, 862688) If we can mobilize that, we can transform the entire look of the country in an incredibly short time.
('74', 454, 1, 16, 862790) And the charkha is a means par excellence for effecting this mobilization of our labour resources.
('74', 454, 1, 17, 862889) It is a natural symbol of non violence too, which is the soul of all voluntary life giving corpo rate activity.
('74', 454, 1, 18, 863001) The popularization of the charkha thus has a definite place in any scheme of municipal work, whether it relates to the liqui dation of rural unemployment and the consequent penury and appa lling conditions of existence under which vast sections of our rural population live, or whether it refers to the amelioration of slum life that is the shame of our big cities.
('74', 454, 1, 19, 863367) But this presupposes a living faith in the charkha, a faith that should lead to an intelligent study and mastering of the science of spinning and its allied processes.
('74', 454, 1, 20, 863535) As it is, we today love to kill our time by going to cinemas and picture houses or even in idle talk.
('74', 454, 1, 21, 863637) Pursuits of making money without work interest us, but not the charkha.
('74', 454, 1, 22, 863709) Yet it is my faith that we shall advance towards our goal of non violence to the extent we succeed in universalizing the charkha.
('74', 454, 1, 23, 863839) By following the plan of work outlined above, we shall be able to return to the ratepayers whatever taxes they may have paid,
('74', 455, 0, 1, 863965) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 455, 1, 2, 864007) multiplied manifold, in the form of vastly improved services and municipal amenities, and they will not grudge the levying of addi tional taxes, too, should that become necessary.
('74', 455, 2, 3, 864187) A member of the Jambusar Municipality asked: “In our municipality there are 17 members, out of whom eight have been returned on the Congress ticket, the remaining nine are non Congress.
('74', 455, 2, 4, 864373) They can always outvote us and thwart our plans.
('74', 455, 2, 5, 864422) What should we do?”
('74', 455, 3, 6, 864442) G. That should present no problem.
('74', 455, 3, 7, 864477) If they want to proceed in the orthodox style and fill up their time with speechifying and so on and so forth, you need not imitate them, or waste your time like them; you may just put in your appearance at these meetings, but need not waste your time by taking part in idle controversy.
('74', 455, 3, 8, 864765) Instead, you should occupy all your time with useful service of the ratepayers, by yourself wielding the bucket and the broom, by working with the spade and the basket, by nursing and rendering medical aid to the sick and ailing, and by teaching the ratepayers who are illiterate, and their children, to read and write.
('74', 455, 3, 9, 865085) As a result, two things may happen.
('74', 455, 3, 10, 865121) Either your opponents will be infected by your example and will align themselves with you and there will be an end to all controversy.
('74', 455, 3, 11, 865256) Or the ratepayers will learn to know the sheep from the goats, and at the next election all the seventeen seats will be filled by Congressmen.
('74', 455, 3, 12, 865399) That is the non violent way of liquidating opposition.
('74', 455, 3, 13, 865454) It eliminates all conflict and clash and makes our way clear irrespective of what the other party may or may not do.
('74', 455, 4, 14, 865571) Q. Since in many places in Gujarat the National Week is being observed by inviting the people to take part in rural uplift or municipal service work, would it not be desirable to alter the dates of the celebration so that the week should fall within the bright phase of the moon?
('74', 455, 4, 15, 865851) This will enable mass operations to continue even after nightfall and economize lighting.
('74', 455, 5, 16, 865941) A. A multitude of calendars are at present in vogue in different parts of the country.
('74', 455, 5, 17, 866028) But for a national celebration it is desirable to follow a calendar which is universal.
('74', 455, 5, 18, 866116) If your civic zeal is not a vain show, beginning and ending with the National Week, you will have a series of municipal service weeks in addition to the National Week.
('74', 455, 5, 19, 866284) The dates for these weeks in each place can be fixed according to the requirement of the activity suited to that particular place.
('74', 455, 6, 20, 866415) “Which form of taxation is better for municipal purposes, direct or indirect?” asked a city father from Surat.
('74', 455, 7, 21, 866526) G. Indirect taxation is found to be more popular with the ratepayers, because its incidence is not directly felt.
('74', 455, 7, 22, 866640) But the direct
('74', 456, 0, 1, 866655) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 457
('74', 456, 1, 2, 866704) taxation has more educative value and will be found more handy when the object is to make the ratepayers municipal minded.
('74', 456, 2, 3, 866827) A friend from Kheda District complained: “We would like to introduce the Wardha scheme of basic education in the primary schools run by local boards.
('74', 456, 2, 4, 866977) The local bodies are willing, but the Inspectorate and the higher officials of the Education Department are still old fashioned in their outlook.
('74', 456, 2, 5, 867123) They have not developed faith in the Wardha principles.
('74', 456, 2, 6, 867179) How shall we circumvent this handicap ?”
('74', 456, 3, 7, 867220) G. That does not surprise me.
('74', 456, 3, 8, 867250) I should be surprised if the higher educational authorities developed faith in the Wardha scheme of education all at once.
('74', 456, 3, 9, 867373) Faith will follow experience.
('74', 456, 3, 10, 867403) In the mean time all I can say is that where there is a will there is a way.
('74', 456, 3, 11, 867480) I do not think there is any legal difficulty in the way of the Education Minister instructing his Director of Public Instruction to help, in every possible way, those who might wish to give effect to the Wardha scheme of education.
('74', 456, 3, 12, 867712) The C. P. Ministry has not found any difficulty in making the Education Department to fall into line with them.
('74', 456, 3, 13, 867824) But if a legal or technical difficulty is discovered, it can be removed in a legal way.
('74', 456, 4, 14, 867912) Q. In our schemes for adult education, should the aim be to promote the spread of literacy or to impart ‘useful knowledge’?
('74', 456, 4, 15, 868036) What about the education of women?
('74', 456, 5, 16, 868071) A. The primary need of those who are come of age and are following an avocation, is to know how to read and write.
('74', 456, 5, 17, 868186) Mass illiteracy is India’s sin and shame and must be liquidated.
('74', 456, 5, 18, 868251) Of course, the literacy campaign must not begin and end with a knowledge of the alphabet.
('74', 456, 5, 19, 868341) It must go hand in hand with the spread of useful know ledge.
('74', 456, 5, 20, 868403) But municipal bodies should beware of trying to ride two horses at a time, or else they are sure to come a cropper.
('74', 456, 5, 21, 868519) As for illiteracy among the women, its cause is not mere laziness and inertia as in the case of men.
('74', 456, 5, 22, 868620) A more potent cause is the status of inferiority with which an immemorial tradition has unjustly branded her.
('74', 456, 5, 23, 868730) Man has converted her into a domestic drudge and an instrument of his pleasure, instead of regarding her as his helpmate and better half !
('74', 456, 5, 24, 868869) The result is a semi paralysis of our society.
('74', 456, 5, 25, 868916) Woman has rightly been called the mother of the race.
('74', 456, 5, 26, 868970) We owe it to her and to ourselves to undo the great wrong that we have done her.
('74', 456, 6, 27, 869051) “You have expressed varying opinions on certain subjects at different times,” asked a friend from Kapadwanj, Kheda Dist.
('74', 456, 6, 28, 869172) “These are sometimes exploited by our opponents to oppose our current policies.
('74', 456, 6, 29, 869252) What should we do under these circums tances?”
('74', 456, 7, 30, 869299) G. The contradiction in these cases is only in appearance and
('74', 457, 0, 1, 869361) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('74', 457, 1, 2, 869403) easily capable of being reconciled.
('74', 457, 1, 3, 869439) A safe rule to follow would be that the latest utterance, in order of time, should be given precedence over all the previous ones.
('74', 457, 1, 4, 869570) But no utterance of mine, whether late or early, need bind you if it does not appeal to your heart and head.
('74', 457, 1, 5, 869679) That would not mean that my standpoint was wrong.
('74', 457, 1, 6, 869729) But it would be wrong to accept a standpoint which you cannot appreciate or assimilate.
('74', 457, 2, 7, 869817) Q. How to deal with people who commit nuisance by using any and every place for evacuations?
('74', 457, 2, 8, 869910) They defend the practice on the ground that it is enjoined by their religion.
('74', 457, 2, 9, 869988) Again, how to cope with the nuisance of flies, mosquitoes, rabid dogs and monkeys, etc.?
('74', 457, 2, 10, 870077) Their extermination is objected to by some on the ground of ahimsa.
('74', 457, 3, 11, 870145) A. With regard to the first, there are two ways of dealing with the problem—the apparently violent, and the non violent.
('74', 457, 3, 12, 870266) You can enforce the penalty of law against those who may infringe the laws of sanitation.
('74', 457, 3, 13, 870356) I have used the word ‘apparent’ advisedly.
('74', 457, 3, 14, 870399) Religious free dom, like liberty, becomes licence when it is indulged in at the expense of the health and safety of others, or in contravention of the principles of decency or morality.
('74', 457, 3, 15, 870585) If you want to claim unrestricted and absolute liberty for yourselves, you must choose to retire from society and take to solitude.
('74', 457, 3, 16, 870717) I call the practice of making evacuations anywhere and everywhere, regardless of the health and convenience of others, a travesty of ahimsa.
('74', 457, 3, 17, 870858) Where there is filth, whether physical or moral, there is no ahimsa.
('74', 457, 3, 18, 870927) The other way is to seek out the religious heads of the sects that indulge in these insanitary practices and to try to touch their heart and reason by patient argument.
('74', 457, 3, 19, 871096) As for the nuisance of flies, mosquitoes, street dogs and monkeys, etc., I in my individual capacity may choose to put up with it, but society as a whole cannot afford to do so if it at all wants to exist.
('74', 457, 3, 20, 871302) These pests are a result of our misdeeds.
('74', 457, 3, 21, 871344) If I feed the monkeys in a public place and thereby make life impossible for others, it is I who commit himsa, and society will have no choice but to exterminate the pest that my himsa has created.
('74', 457, 3, 22, 871542) The criterion of ahimsa is the mental attitude behind an act, not the mechanical act by itself.
('74', 457, 3, 23, 871638) A citizen who lets loose pests on others by indulging in a mistaken humanitarian sentiment is guilty of himsa.
('74', 457, 4, 24, 871749) Shrimati Mridulabehn Sarabhai, who is a keen social worker and founder of the Jyoti Sangh, an institution for the uplift and emancipation of women at Ahmedabad, put Gandhiji a few leading questions on the position of women in society: “The awakening of civil and political consciousness among Indian women has created a
('74', 458, 0, 1, 872069) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 459
('74', 458, 1, 2, 872118) conflict between their traditional domestic duties and their duty towards society.
('74', 458, 1, 3, 872201) If a woman engages in public work, she may have to neglect her children or her household.
('74', 458, 1, 4, 872291) How is the dilemma to be solved?” Basing his reply on a celebrated text of the Gita, Gandhiji remarked that it was always wrong to run after the ‘distant scene’ to the neglect of the more immediate duties that might have accrued to one naturally.
('74', 458, 1, 5, 872538) Neglect of present duty was the way to destruction.
('74', 458, 1, 6, 872590) The question was whether it is a woman’s duty to devote all her time to domestic work.
('74', 458, 1, 7, 872677) More often than not a woman’s time is taken up not by the performance of essential domestic duties but in catering for the egoistic pleasure of her lord and master and for her own vanities.
('74', 458, 2, 8, 872867) G. To me this domestic slavery of women is a symbol of our barbarism.
('74', 458, 2, 9, 872937) In my opinion the slavery of the kitchen is a remnant of barbarism mainly.
('74', 458, 2, 10, 873012) It is high time that our womankind was freed from this incubus.
('74', 458, 2, 11, 873076) Domestic work ought not to take the whole of a woman’s time.
('74', 458, 3, 12, 873137) MRIDULABEHN: At the elections your Congressmen expect all manner of help from us, but when we ask them to send out their wives and daughters to join us in public work, they bring forth all sorts of excuses and want to keep them close prisoners within the four domestic walls.
('74', 458, 3, 13, 873413) What remedy do you suggest?
('74', 458, 3, 14, 873441) G. Send the names of all such antediluvian fossils to me for publication in Harijan.
('74', 458, 3, 15, 873526) SEGAON, February 7, 1939 Harijan, 18 2 1939
('74', 458, 4, 16, 873570) 589. LETTER TO GENERAL SHINDE
('74', 458, 5, 17, 873600) BARDOLI, January 29, 1939
('74', 458, 6, 18, 873626) DEAR GEN.
('74', 458, 6, 19, 873636) SHINDE, I am obliged to you for your letter of the 25th inst.
('74', 458, 6, 20, 873698) I want unity between Maharashtrians and Gujaratis.
('74', 458, 6, 21, 873749) There is no reason whatsoever for a split.
('74', 458, 6, 22, 873792) If you have copies of Sardar Vallabhbhai’s speeches at Bhadran and Ena, 1 I would like to see them.
('74', 458, 6, 23, 873892) Sardar is not the man to foment dissensions between the two communities.
('74', 458, 6, 24, 873965) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('74', 458, 6, 25, 874025) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('74', 458, 7, 26, 874044) 1 The addressee in his letter had charged Sardar Patel with fomenting dissensions between Gujaratis and Maharashtrians by his speeches at Bhadran and Ena and by his Press statements.

('74', 459, 7, 9, 874716) 591. LETTER TO AMTUSSALAAM
('74', 459, 8, 10, 874743) January 29, 1939
('74', 459, 9, 11, 874760) DEAR DAUGHTER, I have your two letters.
('74', 459, 9, 12, 874800) How can I order you?
('74', 459, 9, 13, 874821) I have already said that you are free to do as you like as I do not know what is in your best interest.
('74', 459, 9, 14, 874925) It would be absurd for me to express any opinion under such circumstances.
('74', 459, 9, 15, 875000) So the best thing would be for you to do what you think proper.
('74', 459, 9, 16, 875064) I shall be content with that.
('74', 459, 9, 17, 875094) I write this neither in grief nor in anger, only with your good at heart.
('74', 459, 9, 18, 875168) I hope everyone there is well, including yourself.
('74', 459, 10, 19, 875219) Blessings from BAPU

('74', 460, 0, 1, 875279) VOL. 74 : 9 SEPTEMBER, 1938 29 JANUARY, 1939 461
('74', 460, 1, 2, 875328) 592. SPEECH AT MEETING OF PEASANTS 1
('74', 460, 2, 3, 875365) VARAD, [January 29, 1939] 2
('74', 460, 3, 4, 875393) There can be no two opinions that this is an auspicious occasion.
('74', 460, 3, 5, 875459) There was a time when we were faced with confiscation of our lands and when they were actually confiscated we declared times without number in our speeches that the Government would not be able to retain them, that they would be returned to the owners.
('74', 460, 3, 6, 875712) And now these lands have been returned.
('74', 460, 3, 7, 875752) Do not think that we have been able to get them back by our ceaseless efforts.
('74', 460, 3, 8, 875831) You would be making a great mistake if you thought so.
('74', 460, 3, 9, 875886) We have succeeded to the extent we adh ered to truth and non violence.
('74', 460, 3, 10, 875957) Chitta Patel 3 remained firm and never came to Varad.
('74', 460, 3, 11, 876011) He therefore completely fulfilled his pledge.
('74', 460, 3, 12, 876057) It is not that Chittabhai alone had taken such a pledge.
('74', 460, 3, 13, 876114) India abounds in such men and it is owing to their merit alone that we have got back our lands.
('74', 460, 3, 14, 876210) But we must know how to lose them again should an occasion arise.
('74', 460, 3, 15, 876276) To believe that restoration of lands means that we have won swaraj or that we have become fit for it is to commit a sin.
('74', 460, 3, 16, 876397) It suggests that for winning swaraj we have to tread the path which we have trodden so far.
('74', 460, 3, 17, 876489) Let us not delude ourselves that nothing remains for us to do now.
('74', 460, 3, 18, 876556) If we play the game guided by self interest and pecuniary motives, we are bound to lose.
('74', 460, 3, 19, 876645) I wish to warn you that a greater ordeal is yet to come.
('74', 460, 4, 20, 876702) Let us in all humility pray to God that He may bless us with strength a hundredfold of that which He has bestowed on us up to now, so that we may be able to stand more fiery ordeals.
('74', 460, 4, 21, 876885) We have had the courage to go to jail, to lose our homes and lands.
('74', 460, 4, 22, 876953) Let us now pray for the courage to go to the scaffold cheerfully or to become ashes in a consuming fire.
('74', 460, 4, 23, 877058) When we have exhibited that courage, swaraj will be ours, and no one dare rob us of it.
('74', 460, 4, 24, 877146) But if we forget the lesson today, we shall lose the battle and be bankrupt.
('74', 460, 4, 25, 877223) I hope and pray that none of us may be found wanting when the supreme test comes.
('74', 460, 5, 26, 877305) Harijanbandhu, 26 2 1939, and Harijan, 18 2 1939
('74', 460, 6, 27, 877354) 1 On the occasion of restoration of confiscated lands.
('74', 460, 6, 28, 877409) The text has been extracted from Mahadev Desai’s reports in Gujarati and English under the heading “Bardoli”.
('74', 460, 6, 29, 877519) 2 From Gandhi—1915 1948 3 Chitta Patel had vowed not to enter the British territories until the confiscated lands were restored.
('74', 460, 6, 30, 877648) 4 The paragraph that follows is from Harijan.
